commentText: February 17 2005Docket ClerkDOT400 7th Street SW. Room PL-401Washington DC 20590.Docket Number OST-2004-19482-1Dear Docket ClerkThe vast majority of comments received by the DOT in response to its Notice of Proposed Rule Making have focused on air travel with service or assistance dogs the most common type of service animal used by disabled or handicapped Americans. The center of attention has been the issue of said dogs being unable to fit in the floor space in front of passengers with disabilities.Current airline practices of providing an empty seat where space is available or asking a volunteer to share leg space with the dog have fostered wonderful working relationships between disabled passengers and the airlines.However the language recommended in the NPRM that suggests that a disabled passenger could be charged for an extra seat asked to take a later flight or have their assistance/service dog shipped in the cargo hold are perceived as threats by members of the assistance dog partner community (thus by the handicapped & disabled community) to their ability to travel by air. The three options cited in the NPRM would have a devastating impact on air travel by assistance/service dog partners for the following reasons: 1. Purchasing a second seat is not a viable option since the additional costs would exclude most disabled people (including myself) with large dogs from traveling by air. It would place an undue financial burden on us and would be seen as discrimination. The frequently cited statistic that 70% of the 54 million Americans with disabilities are unemployed and more than 40% rely on the federal welfare program shows that disabled/handicapped Americans are the most economically deprived of our population. And a second seat certainly wouldn't solve the problem if the flight is booked.2. Taking a later flight doesn't guarantee resolvement of this issue since we may encounter yet another booked flight with no room for our assistance/service dog partners.3. It is completely unacceptable to ship my assistance dog in a cargo hold.  In addition to being a hardship on both myself and my partner any such separation has already been declared a violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act by the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals in Crowder v. State of Hawaii. The suggestion of this option by the DOT is an outrage to those of us who depend on our assistance dogs in order to have any semblance of a "normal" life and for many of us to even leave our homes at all.Please listen to the IAADP's recommendation that the following be adopted as official advice to in-flight crews and counter agents:"You may offer the passenger sitting in a seat adjacent to the disabled passenger traveling with a large service animal a seat in the same class of service in another part of the cabin. If no seats are available in that class of service you may ask for a volunteer willing to occupy the seat next to the disabled passenger requiring sharing of leg room. If no volunteer is forthcoming and seats are available in another class of service in another part of the cabin you may ask the adjacent passenger or the disabled passenger to occupy a seat in that other class of service."This approach to the issue of an assistance dog being unable to fit in the floor space in front of a disabled passenger's seat would not be a financial burden for the airlines nor would it be an inconvenience to other passengers. Instead it would formalize current air carrier policies giving those of us with disabilities and handicaps the reasonable accommodation to which we are entitled. If a second seat charge is instituted the airlines would lose revenue due to fewer disabled/handicapped people being able to travel by air. It is my experience and has been proven time and time again that there is normally at least one other passenger willing to share floor space with a service dog when a flight is fully booked. This kindness by others who love animals and care about the disabled/handicapped community is evidenced in my daily life with my service dog partner.The DOT and air carriers might do better to focus on the issue of access in the Air Carrier Access Act. The proposed DOT rules noted in this letter would prohibit such access.Respectfully submittedKatherine I. Kinsey (and service dog partner Aimee without whom I would be unable to leave home let alone travel)
docketTitle: Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel - Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM)
title: Katherine I. Kinsey

commentText: Kimm VanSchoelandt Docket # OST-2004-19482-9  Dear Docket Clerk I am a disabled woman with a large mix breed dog that I use to assist me both in public and at home. I have taken my service animal on many flights to spend time with my family in Kansas. My dog has been welcomed by the airlines with open arms and was given wings. Despite his large size he was able to curl up by my feet we were even given the option of sitting in the bulk head seats. Current airline practices of providing an empty seat where space is available or asking for a volunteer to share leg space with the assistance dog have created excellent working relationships between disabled passengers and the airline industry. However the language recommended in the NPRM suggesting that the disabled passenger could be charged for an extra seat asked to take a later flight or have the assistance dog shipped in cargo are seen as threats by members of the assistance dog partner community to their ability to travel by air. The three options cited in the NPRM would have a devastating impact on air travel by assistance dog partners because: 1. Purchasing a second seat is not a viable option since the additional costs would exclude me from traveling by air. It would place an undue financial burden on me and would be seen as an overt form of discrimination. After becoming disabled I was forced to rely solely on my Social Security Disability checks for my three children and myself.  Finally if a flight is fully booked how would being charged for a second seat solve the problem? 2. Traveling on a later flight does not guarantee the issue will be resolved since the same circumstances may exist on the later flight. 3. As an IAADP member I agree with the stance that shipping the assistance dog in cargo is a totally unacceptable option. This again would make it unable for me to use air transportation due to the fact that my dog must be available to assist me during flight. A number of comments already submitted have indicated such separation was declared a violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act by the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals in the Crowder case against the state of Hawaii. That this option is even suggested by DOT is an indication of a lack of understanding of the work performed by guide hearing and service dogs and the relationship of these canine assistants to their disabled partners. Once again IAADP recommends the following language be adopted as official advice to in-flight crews and counter agents: "You may offer the passenger sitting in a seat adjacent to the disabled passenger traveling with a large service animal a seat in the same class of service in another part of the cabin. If no seats are available in that class of service you may ask for a volunteer willing to occupy the seat next to the disabled passenger requiring sharing of leg room. If no volunteer is forthcoming and seats are available in another class of service in another part of the cabin you may ask the adjacent passenger or the disabled passenger to occupy a seat in that other class of service." Using this approach to the issue of the assistance dog unable to fit within the floor space in front of the disabled passenger's seat would not be a financial burden for the airlines or an inconvenience to other passengers. It would formalize current air carrier policies and be a reasonable accommodation. If the second seat charge is instituted as stated in the NPRM it would lead to a further loss of airline revenue since fewer people with disabilities would be able to travel by air. Where every seat on a flight is occupied at least one other passenger would be willing to share floor space with a guide hearing or service dog. That has been my experience and theexperience of many other IAADP members. DOT and the air carriers should be focusing on the issue of access in the Air Carrier Access Act. The proposed DOT rules noted in this letter would work against such access. Respectfully submitted Kimm VanSchoelandtSurprise AZ
docketTitle: Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel - Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM)
title: Kimm VanSchoelandt

commentText: Title: Public Comment on ACAA's Service Animal RegulationsDate:2/17/2005 Docket Number: OST-2004-19482-9 To Whom It May Concern:I am a late-deafened woman who has a hearing service dog.  My dog is with me 24 hours a day seven days a week and serves as my ears.  My service dog is the one way I am able to live and function independently and safely. I do NOT approve of the new language in the DOT's Notice of Proposed Rule Making (NPRM) .The Department of Transportation's Notice of Proposed Rule Making (NPRM) contains an alarming change to the regulatory language about seating accommodations for assistance dog partners. The proposed rule grants airlines the right to require a passenger with an assistance dog to purchase a second ticket if the canine assistant is not small enough to fit in the floor space directly in front of the passenger's seat. Alternatively airlines may require the passenger to ship the dog in cargo or wait for a later flight. I do not believe this proposed policy is "a reasonable accommodation" for those of us traveling with assistance dogs. It penalizes disabled people working with large dogs for physical support guidance or wheelchair pulling. Even smaller dogs wearing backpacks containing medical supplies and equipment required by the disabled passenger may not fit into this space.I believe this inclusion of new regulatory language would violate the spirit of the Air Carrier Access Act which Congress passed to ensure the airlines would increase the accessibility of air travel to the disabled population.1.Purchasing a second seat is not a viable option since the additional costs would exclude most disabled people with large dogs from traveling by air. It would place an undue financial burden on them. A frequently cited statistic is that 70% of the 54 million Americans with disabilities are unemployed and more than 40% rely on the federal welfare program. Disabled Americans constitute the most economically deprived segment of the population. 2.Traveling on a later flight does not guarantee the issue will be resolved since the same circumstances may exist on the later flight. The prospect of being forced to delay the trip missing connections pick up times and appointments would be a huge disincentive to air travel. 3.Shipping the assistance dog in cargo due to the risk of trauma or loss is an unacceptable option. Such a separation was declared to be a violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act by the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals in the Crowder case against the state of Hawaii.Current airline practices of providing an empty seat where space is available or asking for a volunteer to share leg space with the assistance dog have created good relationships between disabled passengers and the airline industry. I believe the DOT's NPRM language would foster an adversarial relationship between disabled passengers with large assistance dogs and the airlines.Airplane seat sizes have been getting smaller and smaller with less and less leg room over the years.  The goal еР economy еР more people per plane.  Further cramping has then resulted from the average human increasing in size ( height/weight) as well over the years.  But I  believe air carriers must be made to modify their facilities to assure nondiscrimination. The airplane is their facility. The air carrier must modify its facility the aircraft to accommodate assistance dogs of all sizes at least in a few seats or specified areas.  My hearing dog is a physical necessity that must she be with me at all times.  Also By suggesting that airlines may charge for an additional seat if the service animal intrudes into the neighboring passenger's space DOT is violating basic principles of non-discrimination. In addition 382.67 permits carriers to comply with the wheelchair storage requirement by using a strap kit across two or three seats to store the wheelchair and if other passengers are bumped they receive compensation equivalent to denied boarding. No mention in this rule is made of additional charges for the extra seats provided for wheelchair stowage. Providing such an accommodation to the stowage of wheelchairs but not to the placement of service animals can be viewed as discrimination toward one class of disabled passengers. 382.11 Section 3 states: that whatever services are offered to one passenger must also be offered to disabled passengers. If wheelchair users are offered additional seats for the stowage of their wheelchairs then an equivalent accommodation should be made for assistance dog partners. Providing additional space for mechanical assistive devices and denying additional space for live assistive devices namely assistance dogs is discriminatory.Please try to put yourself in my position.  My service animal aids me in my major life activities.  She acts as alert mechanism and an extension of myself just as a cane crutch wheelchair etc. would for another individual.  I need my service dog with me at all times to maintain my safety and independence.  SincerelyDawn E. Denny I do NOT approve of the new language in the DOT's Notice of Proposed Rule Making (NPRM) .I am a late-deafened woman who has a hearing service dog.  My dog is with me 24 hours a day seven days a week and serves as my ears.  My service dog is the one way I am able to live and function independently and safely.

A few of these bags have been approved by airlines for just such a purpose. I am commenting primarily in support. My experience when I let it be known to fellow passengers is of acceptance if not joy of the encounter. docketTitle: Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel - Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM)
title: Ronald C. Yates

commentText: The vast majority of comments received by the Department of Transportation (DOT) in response to its Notice of Proposed Rule Making have focused on air travel with assistance dogs the most common type of service animal used by disabled Americans. In particular the issue of assistance dogs unable to fit in the floor space in front of passengers with disabilities has been the center of attention.Current airline practices of providing an empty seat where space is available or asking for a volunteer to share leg space with the assistance dog have created excellent working relationships between disabled passengers and the airline industry.However the language recommended in the NPRM suggesting that the disabled passenger could be charged for an extra seat asked to take a later flight or have the assistance dog shipped in cargo are seen as threats by members of the assistance dog partner community to their ability to travel by air. The three options cited in the NPRM would have a devastating impact on air travel by assistance dog partners because: 1. Purchasing a second seat is not a viable option since the additional costs would exclude most disabled people with large dogs from traveling by air. It would place an undue financial burden on them and would be seen as an overt form of discrimination. A frequently cited statistic is that 70% of the 54 million Americans with disabilities are unemployed and more than 40% rely on the federal welfare program. Disabled Americans constitute the most economically deprived segment of our nation's population. Finally if a flight is fully booked how would being charged for a second seat solve the problem?2. Traveling on a later flight does not guarantee the issue will be resolved since the same circumstances may exist on the later flight.3 Shipping the assistance dog in cargo is a totally unacceptable option for IAADP assistance dog partner members. A number of comments already submitted have indicated such separation was declared a violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act by the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals in the Crowder case against the state of Hawaii. That this option is even suggested by DOT is an indication of a lack of understanding of the work performed by guide hearing and service dogs and the relationship of these canine assistants to their disabled partners. Once again IAADP recommends the following language be adopted as official advice to in-flight crews and counter agents:"You may offer the passenger sitting in a seat adjacent to the disabled passenger traveling with a large service animal a seat in the same class of service in another part of the cabin. If no seats are available in that class of service you may ask for a volunteer willing to occupy the seat next to the disabled passenger requiring sharing of leg room. If no volunteer is forthcoming and seats are available in another class of service in another part of the cabin you may ask the adjacent passenger or the disabled passenger to occupy a seat in that other class of service."Using this approach to the issue of the assistance dog unable to fit within the floor space in front of the disabled passenger's seat would not be a financial burden for the airlines or an inconvenience to other passengers. It would formalize current air carrier policies and be a reasonable accommodation.If the second seat charge is instituted as stated in the NPRM it would lead to a further loss of airline revenue since fewer people with disabilities would be able to travel by air. Where every seat on a flight is occupied at least one other passenger would be willing to share floor space with a guide hearing or service dog. That has been my experience and theexperience of many other IAADP members. DOT and the air carriers should be focusing on the issue of access in the Air Carrier Access Act. The proposed DOT rules noted in this letter would work against such access.
docketTitle: Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel - Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM)
title: Linda J. Gore

docketTitle: Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel - Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM)
title: Todd Scheetz

commentText: We do not believe this proposed policy is "a reasonable accommodation" for those of us traveling with assistance dogs. It penalizes disabled people working with large dogs for physical support guidance or wheelchair pulling. Even smaller dogs wearing backpacks containing medical supplies and equipment required by the disabled passenger may not fit into this space.We believe this inclusion of new regulatory language would violate the spirit of the Air Carrier Access Act which Congress passed to ensure the airlines would increase the accessibility of air travel to the disabled population.Purchasing a second seat is not a viable option since the additional costs would exclude most disabled people with large dogs from traveling by air. It would place an undue financial burden on them. A frequently cited statistic is that 70% of the 54 million Americans with disabilities are unemployed and more than 40% rely on the federal welfare program. Disabled Americans constitute the most economically deprived segment of the population. Finally if a flight is fully booked how would being charged for a second seat solve the problem? Traveling on a later flight does not guarantee the issue will be resolved since the same circumstances may exist on the later flight. The prospect of being forced to delay the trip missing connections pick up times and appointments would be a huge disincentive to air travel. Shipping the assistance dog in cargo due to the risk of trauma or loss is an option unacceptable to the Council of the Blind members. Such a separation was declared to be a violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act by the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals in the Crowder case against the state of Hawaii. Current airline practices of providing an empty seat where space is available or asking for a volunteer to share leg space with the assistance dog have created excellent workingrelationships between disabled passengers and the airline industry. We believe the DOT's NPRM language would foster an adversarial relationship between disabled passengers with largeassistance dogs and the airlines. We would like to see the following language substituted by DOT as advice to in-flight crews and counter agents: "You may offer the passenger sitting in a seat adjacent to the disabled passenger traveling with a large service animal a seat in the same class of service in another part of the cabin. If no seats are available in that class of service you may ask for a volunteer willing to occupy the seat next to the disabled passenger requiring the sharing of leg room. If no volunteer is forthcoming and seats are available in another class of service in another part of the cabin you may ask the adjacent passenger or the disabled passenger to occupy a seat in that other class of service."Using this approach to the issue of the assistance dog unable to fit within the floor space in front of the disabled passenger's seat would not be a financial burden for the airlines or aninconvenience to other passengers.Please consider these comments from users of guide dogs for the blind.
docketTitle: Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel - Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM)
organization: Council of the Blind Lehigh Valley Chapter PA

docketTitle: Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel - Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM)
title: V. M. Morris

commentText: Being a disabled American with a service dog I am VERY concerned about the changes to the regulatory language about seating accommodations for assistance dog partners. The proposed rule grants airlines the right to require a passenger with an assistance dog to purchase a second ticket if the canine assistant is not small enough to fit in the floor space directly in front of the passenger's seat. Alternatively airlines may require the passenger to ship the dog in cargo or wait for a later flight. This language violates the spirit of the Air Carrier Access Act.Purchasing a second seat is not a viable option.  The cost is prohibitive. If a flight is fully booked how would being charged for a second seat solve the problem? Traveling on a later flight does not guarantee the issue will be resolved since the same circumstances may exist on the later flight. Shipping  my service dog cargo is NOT an option!This type of  separation was declared to be a violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act by the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals in the Crowder case against the state of Hawaii. IAADP would like to see the following language substituted by DOT as advice to in-flight crews and counter agents: "You may offer the passenger sitting in a seat adjacent to the disabled passenger traveling with a large service animal a seat in the same class of service in another part of the cabin. If no seats are available in that class of service you may ask for a volunteer willing to occupy the seat next to the disabled passenger requiring the sharing of leg room. If no volunteer is forthcoming and seats are available in another class of service in another part of the cabin you may ask the adjacent passenger or the disabled passenger to occupy a seat in that other class of service."I do take the train as much as posible but if Amtrak does not get its funding where does that leave me? As it is train travel is VERY LIMITED as far as desinations are concerned.Please do not take another freedom away from me! Tam Ilg

docketTitle: Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel - Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM)
title: Access to Independence

commentText: Dear Docket ClerkThe vast majority of comments received by the Department of Transportation (DOT) in response to its Notice of Proposed Rule Making have focused on air travel with assistance dogs the most common type of service animal used by disabled Americans. In particular the issue of assistance dogs unable to fit in the floor space in front of passengers with disabilities has been the center of attention.Current airline practices of providing an empty seat where space is available or asking for a volunteer to share leg space with the assistance dog have created excellent working relationships between disabled passengers and the airline industry.However the language recommended in the NPRM suggesting that the disabled passenger could be charged for an extra seat asked to take a later flight or have the assistance dog shipped in cargo are seen as threats by members of the assistance dog partner community to their ability to travel by air. The three options cited in the NPRM would have a devastating impact on air travel by assistance dog partners because: 1. Purchasing a second seat is not a viable option since the additional costs would exclude most disabled people with large dogs from traveling by air. It would place an undue financial burden on them and would be seen as an overt form of discrimination. A frequently cited statistic is that 70% of the 54 million Americans with disabilities are unemployed and more than 40% rely on the federal welfare program. Disabled Americans constitute the most economically deprived segment of our nation's population. Finally if a flight is fully booked how would being charged for a second seat solve the problem?2. Traveling on a later flight does not guarantee the issue will be resolved since the same circumstances may exist on the later flight.3 Shipping the assistance dog in cargo is a totally unacceptable option. A number of comments already submitted have indicated such separation was declared a violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act by the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals in the Crowder case against the state of Hawaii. That this option is even suggested by DOT is an indication of a lack of understanding of the work performed by guide hearing and service dogs and the relationship of these canine assistants to their disabled partners. Along with others I recommend the following language be adopted as official advice to in-flight crews and counter agents:"You may offer the passenger sitting in a seat adjacent to the disabled passenger traveling with a large service animal a seat in the same class of service in another part of the cabin. If no seats are available in that class of service you may ask for a volunteer willing to occupy the seat next to the disabled passenger requiring sharing of leg room. If no volunteer is forthcoming and seats are available in another class of service in another part of the cabin you may ask the adjacent passenger or the disabled passenger to occupy a seat in that other class of service."Using this approach to the issue of the assistance dog unable to fit within the floor space in front of the disabled passenger's seat would not be a financial burden for the airlines or an inconvenience to other passengers. It would formalize current air carrier policies and be a reasonable accommodation.If the second seat charge is instituted as stated in the NPRM it would lead to a further loss of airline revenue since fewer people with disabilities would be able to travel by air. Where every seat on a flight is occupied at least one other passenger would be willing to share floor space with a guide hearing or service dog. That has been my experience and theexperience of many other people who use seeing eye dogs. DOT and the air carriers should be focusing on the issue of access in the Air Carrier Access Act. The proposed DOT rules noted in this letter would work against such access.Respectfully submittedThomas H. Pruiksma
docketTitle: Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel - Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM)
title: Thomas H. Pruiksma

commentText: I am deeply concerned about the 3 changes proposed in the DOT's NPRM regarding passengers who use assistance dogs.  Charging for an extra seat being delayed to a later flight and shipping the canine partner in cargo all are unacceptable suggestions.  Separating service dogs from the human partners with whom they work was declared a violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act by the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals in the Crowder case against the state of Hawaii.  Why would you want to waste time and energy on a set of recommendations that already are outside legal boundaries discriminate against a certain set of people and worst of all send the message that people with disabilities do not deserve the same respect and treatment that the general airline passenger does?
docketTitle: Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel - Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM)
title: Anne Marie Rodgers

title: Nathan R. Thornton

commentText: In modern times of respect and consideration of all people it is only fair that we make special provisions for our nation's most disadvantaged populations. Guide dogs are integral parts of the functioning of our blind citizens and are intended to make their lives and the lives of those around them easier. I doubt the passengers of any plane would complain about the presence of a guide dog or object to the reasoning behind it. I for one would be more than happy to share my space with a guide dog as most animal-loving people would. We must stop favoring big corporations over the rights of private citizens. The three options cited in the NPRM would have a devastating impact on air travel by assistance dog partners because: 1. Purchasing a second seat is not a viable option since the additional costs would exclude most disabled people with large dogs from traveling by air. It would place an undue financial burden on them and would be seen as an overt form of discrimination. A subsequently cited statistic is that 70% of the 54 million Americans with disabilities are unemployed and more than 40% rely on the federal welfare program. Disabled Americans constitute the most economically deprived segment of our nation's population. Finally if a flight is fully booked how would being charged for a second seat solve the problem? 2. Traveling on a later flight does not guarantee the issue will be resolved since the same circumstances may exist on the later flight. 3. Shipping the assistance dog in cargo is a totally unacceptable option for IAADP assistance dog partner members. A number of comments already submitted have indicated such separation was declared a violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act by the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals in the Crowder case against the state of Hawaii. That this option is even suggested by DOT is an indication of a lack of understanding of the work performed by guide hearing and service dogs and the relationship of these canine assistants to their disabled partners. Once again IAADP recommends the following language be adopted as official advice to in-flight crews and counter agents: "You may offer the passenger sitting in a seat adjacent to the disabled passenger traveling with a large service animal a seat in the same class of service in another part of the cabin. If no seats are available in that class of service you may ask for a volunteer willing to occupy the seat next to the disabled passenger requiring sharing of leg room. If no volunteer is forthcoming and seats are available in another class of service in another part of the cabin you may ask the adjacent passenger or the disabled passenger to occupy a seat in that other class of service." Using this approach to the issue of the assistance dog unable to fit within the floor space in front of the disabled passenger's seat would not be a financial burden for the airlines or an inconvenience to other passengers. It would formalize current air carrier policies and be a reasonable accommodation. If the second seat charge is instituted as stated in the NPRM it would lead to a further loss of airline revenue since fewer people with disabilities would be able to travel by air. Where every seat on a flight is occupied at least one other passenger would be willing to share floor space with a guide hearing or service dog. That has been my experience and theexperience of many other IAADP members. DOT and the air carriers should be focusing on the issue of access in the Air Carrier Access Act. The proposed DOT rules noted in this letter would work against such access.
docketTitle: Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel - Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM)
title: Michele A. Marshall

commentText: The language for the DOT's Notice of Proposed Rule Making (NPRM) -- Docket Number OST-2004-19482-9 -- must to be reworded.The language for the DOT's Notice of Proposed Rule Making (NPRM) -- Docket Number OST-2004-19482-9 -- must to be reworded. 1. Requiring disabled people with large dogs to either purchase a second seat wait for another flight or to pay to ship their dog is an overt form of discrimination. Paying for a second seat would place an undue financial burden on them. 2. Traveling on a later flight does not guarantee the issue will be resolved since the same circumstances may exist on the later flight. 3. Shipping the assistance dog in cargo is a totally unacceptable option. Such separation was declared a violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act by the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals in the Crowder case against the state of Hawaii. I propose that the following language from IAADP be substituted: "You may offer the passenger sitting in a seat adjacent to the disabled passenger traveling with a large service animal a seat in the same class of service in another part of the cabin. If no seats are available in that class of service you may ask for a volunteer willing to occupy the seat next to the disabled passenger requiring sharing of leg room. If no volunteer is forthcoming and seat are available in another class of service you may ask the adjacent passenger or the disabled passenger to occupy a seat in that other class of service." (As a background I know many disabled people who require the use of service dogs. I've also been a volunteer puppyraiser for Canine Companions for Independence.) Sincerely J. Bradley

title: Lee Ann Hamilton

commentText: The proposed changes to the Air Carrier Access Act which prohibit assistance dog partners from traveling with their companion threaten the ability to travel of persons who rely on assistance dogs.  However the language recommended in the NPRM suggesting that the disabled passenger could be charged for an extra seat asked to take a later flight or have the assistance dog shipped in cargo are seen as threats by members of the assistance dog partner community to their ability to travel by air. The three options cited in the NPRM would have a devastating impact on air travel by assistance dog partners because: 1. Purchasing a second seat is not a viable option since the additional costs would exclude most disabled people with large dogs from traveling by air. It would place an undue financial burden on them and would be seen as an overt form of discrimination. A frequently cited statistic is that 70% of the 54 million Americans with disabilities are unemployed and more than 40% rely on the federal welfare program. Disabled Americans constitute the most economically deprived segment of our nation's population. Finally if a flight is fully booked how would being charged for a second seat solve the problem?2. Traveling on a later flight does not guarantee the issue will be resolved since the same circumstances may exist on the later flight.3 Shipping the assistance dog in cargo is a totally unacceptable option for IAADP assistance dog partner members. A number of comments already submitted have indicated such separation was declared a violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act by the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals in the Crowder case against the state of Hawaii. That this option is even suggested by DOT is an indication of a lack of understanding of the work performed by guide hearing and service dogs and the relationship of these canine assistants to their disabled partners. I as a disabled person would like to add my voice in support of the IAADP proposed language:"You may offer the passenger sitting in a seat adjacent to the disabled passenger traveling with a large service animal a seat in the same class of service in another part of the cabin. If no seats are available in that class of service you may ask for a volunteer willing to occupy the seat next to the disabled passenger requiring sharing of leg room. If no volunteer is forthcoming and seats are available in another class of service in another part of the cabin you may ask the adjacent passenger or the disabled passenger to occupy a seat in that other class of service."Providing accomodations to persons with disabilities so they may travel with a minimum of disruption and inconvenience is critical so that people with disabilities may have the opportunity to travel.Thank you for the opportunity to express my viewpoint.

title: Edwin M. Stone

commentText: The vast majority of comments received by the Department of Transportation (DOT) in response to its Notice of Proposed Rule Making have focused on air travel with assistance dogs the most common type of service animal used by disabled Americans. In particular the issue of assistance dogs unable to fit in the floor space in front of passengers with disabilities has been the center of attention.Current airline practices of providing an empty seat where space is available or asking for a volunteer to share leg space with the assistance dog have created excellent working relationships between disabled passengers and the airline industry.However the language recommended in the NPRM suggesting that the disabled passenger could be charged for an extra seat asked to take a later flight or have the assistance dog shipped in cargo are seen as threats by members of the assistance dog partner community to their ability to travel by air. The three options cited in the NPRM would have a devastating impact on air travel by assistance dog partners because: 1. Purchasing a second seat is not a viable option since the additional costs would exclude most disabled people with large dogs from traveling by air. It would place an undue financial burden on them and would be seen as an overt form of discrimination. A frequently cited statistic is that 70% of the 54 million Americans with disabilities are unemployed and more than 40% rely on the federal welfare program. Disabled Americans constitute the most economically deprived segment of our nation's population. Finally if a flight is fully booked how would being charged for a second seat solve the problem?2. Traveling on a later flight does not guarantee the issue will be resolved since the same circumstances may exist on the later flight.3 Shipping the assistance dog in cargo is a totally unacceptable option for IAADP assistance dog partner members. A number of comments already submitted have indicated such separation was declared a violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act by the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals in the Crowder case against the state of Hawaii. That this option is even suggested by DOT is an indication of a lack of understanding of the work performed by guide hearing and service dogs and the relationship of these canine assistants to their disabled partners. Once again IAADP recommends the following language be adopted as official advice to in-flight crews and counter agents:"You may offer the passenger sitting in a seat adjacent to the disabled passenger traveling with a large service animal a seat in the same class of service in another part of the cabin. If no seats are available in that class of service you may ask for a volunteer willing to occupy the seat next to the disabled passenger requiring sharing of leg room. If no volunteer is forthcoming and seats are available in another class of service in another part of the cabin you may ask the adjacent passenger or the disabled passenger to occupy a seat in that other class of service."Using this approach to the issue of the assistance dog unable to fit within the floor space in front of the disabled passenger's seat would not be a financial burden for the airlines or an inconvenience to other passengers. It would formalize current air carrier policies and be a reasonable accommodation.If the second seat charge is instituted as stated in the NPRM it would lead to a further loss of airline revenue since fewer people with disabilities would be able to travel by air. Where every seat on a flight is occupied at least one other passenger would be willing to share floor space with a guide hearing or service dog. That has been my experience and theexperience of many other IAADP members. DOT and the air carriers should be focusing on the issue of access in the Air Carrier Access Act. The proposed DOT rules noted in this letter would work against such access.

docketTitle: Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel - Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM)
title: Alan Kalish

commentText: The vast majority of comments received by the Department of Transportation (DOT) in response to its Notice of Proposed Rule Making have focused on air travel with assistance dogs the most common type of service animal used by disabled Americans. In particular the issue of assistance dogs unable to fit in the floor space in front of passengers with disabilities has been the center of attention. Current airline practices of providing an empty seat where space is available or asking for a volunteer to share leg space with the assistance dog have created excellent working relationships between disabled passengers and the airline industry. However the language recommended in the NPRM suggesting that the disabled passenger could be charged for an extra seat asked to take a later flight or have the assistance dog shipped in cargo are seen as threats by members of the assistance dog partner community to their ability to travel by air. The three options cited in the NPRM would have a devastating impact on air travel by assistance dog partners because: 1. Purchasing a second seat is not a viable option since the additional costs would exclude most disabled people with large dogs from traveling by air. It would place an undue financial burden on them and would be seen as an overt form of discrimination. A frequently cited statistic is that 70% of the 54 million Americans with disabilities are unemployed and more than 40% rely on the federal welfare program. Disabled Americans constitute the most economically deprived segment of our nation's population. Finally if a flight is fully booked how would being charged for a second seat solve the problem? 2. Traveling on a later flight does not guarantee the issue will be resolved since the same circumstances may exist on the later flight. 3 Shipping the assistance dog in cargo is a totally unacceptable option for IAADP assistance dog partner members. A number of comments already submitted have indicated such separation was declared a violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act by the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals in the Crowder case against the state of Hawaii. That this option is even suggested by DOT is an indication of a lack of understanding of the work performed by guide hearing and service dogs and the relationship of these canine assistants to their disabled partners. Once again IAADP recommends the following language be adopted as official advice to in-flight crews and counter agents: "You may offer the passenger sitting in a seat adjacent to the disabled passenger traveling with a large service animal a seat in the same class of service in another part of the cabin. If no seats are available in that class of service you may ask for a volunteer willing to occupy the seat next to the disabled passenger requiring sharing of leg room. If no volunteer is forthcoming and seats are available in another class of service in another part of the cabin you may ask the adjacent passenger or the disabled passenger to occupy a seat in that other class of service." Using this approach to the issue of the assistance dog unable to fit within the floor space in front of the disabled passenger's seat would not be a financial burden for the airlines or an inconvenience to other passengers. It would formalize current air carrier policies and be a reasonable accommodation. If the second seat charge is instituted as stated in the NPRM it would lead to a further loss of airline revenue since fewer people with disabilities would be able to travel by air. Where every seat on a flight is occupied at least one other passenger would be willing to share floor space with a guide hearing or service dog. That has been my experience and theexperience of many other IAADP members. DOT and the air carriers should be focusing on the issue of access in the Air Carrier Access Act. The proposed DOT rules noted in this letter would work against such access.
docketTitle: Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel - Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM)
title: Michael A. Grassi

commentText: There has to be an equitable solution to keeping assistance dogs and their owners together on airlines.  They are the eyes ears or limbs of someone who is trying to remain independent and be a useful part of society. Yes it may be a little inconvenient for some of us for a short while but it's not forever.  The person who has to live with that forever situation has to rely on that dog so that forever is not unbearable.  Separating the two would be like experiencing the disability all over again.   Sue W . Cert. Vision Rehab. Therapist
docketTitle: Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel - Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM)
title: Anonymous Submitter

commentText: This concerns an NPRM on the issue of how to deal with a situation in which a service dog is too large to fit into the floor space in front of the disabled person.  Please DO NOT include shipping the dog as "cargo" as an option for the air carrier.  Service dogs are not equipment like a wheelchair or hearing aid.  Service dogs are trained to assist their human companion in many different situations; and in case of an emergency requiring evacuation of the plane the service animal would be left in the cargo hold (perhaps to burn or to sink) while his/her human companion would be trying to evacuate without the assistance of the service dog.   Please DO NOT suggest that airlines charge a full extra seat for large service dogs because many disabled persons are on low or fixed income and charging an extra fee would mean that they would not be able to travel by air as frequently (or perhaps not at all). thank you for providing the opportunity for comment.

commentText: I am a volunteer puppy raiser with Support Dogs Inc a St. Louis based organization that provides service dogs to disabled persons free of charge. That this option is even suggested by DOT is an indication of a lack of understanding of the work performed by guide hearing and service dogs and the relationship of these canine assistants to their disabled partners. Once again IAADP recommends the following language be adopted as official advice to in-flight crews and counter agents:"You may offer the passenger sitting in a seat adjacent to the disabled passenger traveling with a large service animal a seat in the same class of service in another part of the cabin. If no seats are available in that class of service you may ask for a volunteer willing to occupy the seat next to the disabled passenger requiring sharing of leg room. If no volunteer is forthcoming and seats are available in another class of service in another part of the cabin you may ask the adjacent passenger or the disabled passenger to occupy a seat in that other class of service."Using this approach to the issue of the assistance dog unable to fit within the floor space in front of the disabled passenger's seat would not be a financial burden for the airlines or an inconvenience to other passengers. title: Patricia A. Manhart

commentText: I believe this inclusion of new regulatory language would violate the spirit of the Air Carrier Access Act which Congress passed to ensure the airlines would increase the accessibility of air travel to the disabled population.   1.  Purchasing a second seat is not a viable option since the additional costs would exclude most disabled people with large dogs from traveling by air. It would place an undue financial burden on them. A frequently cited statistic is that 70% of the 54 million Americans with disabilities are unemployed and more than 40% rely on the federal welfare program. Disabled Americans constitute the most economically deprived segment of the population. Finally if a flight is fully booked how would being charged for a second seat solve the problem?   2. Traveling on a later flight does not guarantee the issue will be resolved since the same circumstances may exist on the later flight. The prospect of being forced to delay the trip missing connections pick up times and appointments would be a huge disincentive to air travel.   3. Shipping the assistance dog in cargo due to the risk of trauma or loss is an option unacceptable to IAADP assistance dog partner members. Such a separation was declared to be a violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act by the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals in the Crowder case against the state of Hawaii.Current airline practices of providing an empty seat where space is available or asking for a volunteer to share leg space with the assistance dog have created excellent workingrelationships between disabled passengers and the airline industry. IAADP believes the DOT's NPRM language would foster an adversarial relationship between disabled passengers with largeassistance dogs and the airlines.
