commentText: My name is Anne-Elizabeth Straub. I am a Clinical Social Worker an educator and a person with a disability affecting my mobility. I've been partnered with an assistance dog a large Golden Retriever named Meka for the last two years.  I maintain a small private practice and have significant volunteer commitments.  I have occasion to travel by air on business; my own on behalf of non-profits for whom I volunteer and also less frequently for vacations with my family.  In the past two years my assistance dog and I have flown together six times.I am a member of International Association of Assistance Dog Partners as well as a number of other service dog organizations but I am writing primarily as an individual who travels by air.Upon reading the Notice of Proposed Rule Making I am pleased with the extension of the AACA accessibility requirements to foreign air carriers and the requirement for all airline and air travel related companies to make their websites accessible to blind and visually impaired travelers using screen readers.  I am most concerned however about the language which grants the airline the right to charge a disabled passenger for an extra seat put the dog in cargo or make the team get off the plane if the service animal cannot fit in the small space allotted directly in front of the passenger's seat.  I object to this proposal in the strongest manner possible.  I find none of the solutions in the proposed language to be acceptable.  Should the airlines be allowed to charge me for a seat for my service dog I  would not be able to afford to fly.  Like the majority of people with disabilities my income is quite limited and I have significant medical expenses.  It would be more than an inconvenience; it would be a complete bar to travel.  This singles out one class of people with disabilities most of whom have limited financial resources and proposes that they bear a significant and unfair proportion of the costs.  It is not an "accommodation" at all.  Up until now Meka has been able to get under the space in front of my seat but it is a very tight fit.  The fit also varies as it does for the human passengers depending on the planes' configurations which change regularly (usually getting smaller not larger)..  Should the space get tighter or should my next dog be larger I might find myself faced unacceptable alternatives.  Bulkhead seating used to be available for this purpose but now the bulkhead seating is mostly at exit locations and not available to us or to people with legs that don't bend.  These are decisions that are made by the airlines when they configure their planes they are not laws of nature.  Having made decisions with no regard for accessibility they would like us to pay for a second (inadequate) seat to compensate for their "planning".One of the services my dog provides is assistance with support and balance.  It is one of the reasons that I require a larger dog.  Another service he provides is to carry some of the items to which I require access such as ID and medication.  His harness and backpack add to his size.  If I remove them and allow them to be placed in overhead storage I do not have access to them if I need them.  I believe this is discriminatory because it applies only to people with disabilities who use dogs of a particular size.  It also discriminates between people who use mechanical equipment and those who use live assistance devices; assistance dogs since 382.67(of Title 14 of current FAA regulations) allows for stowage of wheelchairs in the cabin by using a strap kit across two or three seats to store the wheelchair and if other passengers are bumped they receive compensation equivalent to denied boarding. No mention in this        rule is made of additional charges for the extra seats provided for wheelchair stowage.  Why should there not be an equivalent  accommodation for assistance dog partners?  Perhaps parallel language could also be adopted for example: "If other passengers are bumped because of a service animal they receive compensation equivalent to denied boarding." Putting my assistance dog in cargo is totally unacceptable for several reasons.  In fact this was deemed as a violation of ADA by the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals in  Crowder vs. the State of Hawaii.If the dog is in cargo he is not available to me for the services I require.  Also the nature of our relationship is one of consistency and trust.  We are together twenty-four hours per day and are mutually dependent upon each other.  To suddenly disrupt such a relationship and place him alone in an unfamiliar environment in uncertain circumstances and expect him to be unaffected by this and still function is not only unrealistic but potentially damaging to my dog's health and to our relationship. The prospect of being removed from a flight and placed "on a later flight" because my dog does not fit under the seat in front of me is appalling!  There appear to be no limitations or guidelines about how  this "other" flight might be determined nor any acknowledgment that a person partnered with an assistance dog might have a schedule to maintain or  that such a delay might have a negative impact on the individual.  One of the ways that I manage my symptoms is to manage my schedule and my stress levels.  Going to an airport and planning to be on a scheduled flight at this point in history requires that one arrive at the airport anywhere between one and three hours in advance in order to account for possible traffic delays and security demands.  To then find that one cannot travel on one's scheduled flight and to end up on another possibly hours (or more) later would wreak havoc on any attempt to maintain a level of energy much less a business schedule.  I can not imagine requiring any class of individuals to agree to such conditions!In short what the adoption of these proposed changes would mean to me would be the loss of the ability to travel by air which would be tantamount to leaving me unable to do any long distance travel.  This would reduce my ability to participate in activities that the rest of the population takes for granted. I would be unable to participate in my own business and educational activities and in the volunteer activities that require travel.  This would have a significant impact on my quality of life and the contribution I can make to society.I suggest the Department of Transportation remove that section in the NPRM and replace it with language which does not discriminate against me as a member of a class of individuals with disabilities who use large assistance dogs or place me in the position of having to accommodate the carriers rather than having them comply with the ADA by providing reasonable accommodation to me the person with the disability.   I agree with the language proposed by IAADP which I quote below:"You may offer the passenger sitting in a seat adjacent to the disabled passenger traveling with a large service animal a seat in the same class of service in another part of the cabin. If no seats are available in that class of service you may ask for a volunteer willing to occupy the seat next to the disabled passenger requiring sharing of leg room. If no volunteer is forthcoming and seat are available in another class of service you may ask the adjacent passenger or the disabled passenger to occupy a seat in that other class of service." I would like to be sure that pre-boarding remains an option available to me and my dog.  It allows me to settle him in.  It seems to me that the time between pre-boarding and regular boarding has become shorter and shorter.  At the time of my last two trips I no sooner got to my seat when other passengers were coming up the aisle.Also I would like to see some statement establishing a coherent practice with regard to establishing areas where the partner can take the dog for elimination and urination.  It would be ideal if one could take care of this without having to check back through security. I have had several different experiences in this regard some where it had been well thought through and some where it had not.  Given the amount of time it takes to get to the airport through the security waiting time  and the flight itself there is substantial addition to  travel time. However taking the break should still be the decision of the person with the disability since they know their own and their dogs' requirements.Please make the regulations reflect a real and continuing effort to increase accessibility of air travel to people with disabilities.Sincerely Anne-Elizabeth Straub LCSW CFT
docketTitle: Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel - Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM)
title: Anne-Elizabeth W Straub

commentText: We are outraged to learn that the DOT's еТNotice of Proposed Rule MakingеУ contains a change to the regulatory language about seating accommodations for assistance dog partners. This proposed change will allow airlines the right to require a passenger with an assistance dog to purchase a second ticket if the canine assistant is not small enough to fit in the floor space directly in front of the passenger's seat.  If the passenger elects not to purchase a second ticket he/she then has the option to ship the dog in cargo or wait for a later flight. We are opposed to this proposed regulation because purchasing a second seat places an undue financial burden on the disabled.  Shipping the assistance dog in cargo is unacceptable since this separation was declared a violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act by the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals in the Crowder case against the state of Hawaii. We propose substituting the following language:  "You may offer the passenger sitting in a seat adjacent to the disabled passenger traveling with a large service animal a seat in the same class of service in another part of the cabin. If no seats are available in that class of service you may ask for a volunteer willing to occupy the seat next to the disabled passenger requiring sharing of leg room. If no volunteer is forthcoming and seats are available in another class of service you may ask the adjacent passenger or the disabled passenger to occupy a seat in that other class of service." We are hopeful that the DOT will rethink its currently proposed regulatory change.  Thank you for your consideration.
docketTitle: Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel - Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM)
title: Debbie Carson and Glenn Carson

commentText: Dear Docket ClerkThe vast majority of comments received by the Department of Transportation (DOT) in response to its Notice of Proposed Rule Making have focused on air travel with assistance dogs the most common type of service animal used by disabled Americans. In particular the issue of assistance dogs unable to fit in the floor space in front of passengers with disabilities has been the center of attention.Current airline practices of providing an empty seat where space is available or asking for a volunteer to share leg space with the assistance dog have created excellent working relationships between disabled passengers and the airline industry.However the language recommended in the NPRM suggesting that the disabled passenger could be charged for an extra seat asked to take a later flight or have the assistance dog shipped in cargo are seen as threats by members of the assistance dog partner community to their ability to travel by air. The three options cited in the NPRM would have a devastating impact on air travel by assistance dog partners because: 1. Purchasing a second seat is not a viable option since the additional costs would exclude most disabled people with large dogs from traveling by air. It would place an undue financial burden on them and would be seen as an overt form of discrimination. A frequently cited statistic is that 70% of the 54 million Americans with disabilities are unemployed and more than 40% rely on the federal welfare program. Disabled Americans constitute the most economically deprived segment of our nation's population. Finally if a flight is fully booked how would being charged for a second seat solve the problem?2. Traveling on a later flight does not guarantee the issue will be resolved since the same circumstances may exist on the later flight.3 Shipping the assistance dog in cargo is a totally unacceptable option for IAADP assistance dog partner members. A number of comments already submitted have indicated such separation was declared a violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act by the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals in the Crowder case against the state of Hawaii. That this option is even suggested by DOT is an indication of a lack of understanding of the work performed by guide hearing and service dogs and the relationship of these canine assistants to their disabled partners. Once again IAADP recommends the following language be adopted as official advice to in-flight crews and counter agents:"You may offer the passenger sitting in a seat adjacent to the disabled passenger traveling with a large service animal a seat in the same class of service in another part of the cabin. If no seats are available in that class of service you may ask for a volunteer willing to occupy the seat next to the disabled passenger requiring sharing of leg room. If no volunteer is forthcoming and seats are available in another class of service in another part of the cabin you may ask the adjacent passenger or the disabled passenger to occupy a seat in that other class of service."Using this approach to the issue of the assistance dog unable to fit within the floor space in front of the disabled passenger's seat would not be a financial burden for the airlines or an inconvenience to other passengers. It would formalize current air carrier policies and be a reasonable accommodation.If the second seat charge is instituted as stated in the NPRM it would lead to a further loss of airline revenue since fewer people with disabilities would be able to travel by air. Where every seat on a flight is occupied at least one other passenger would be willing to share floor space with a guide hearing or service dog. That has been my experience and theexperience of many other IAADP members. DOT and the air carriers should be focusing on the issue of access in the Air Carrier Access Act. The proposed DOT rules noted in this letter would work against such access.
docketTitle: Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel - Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM)
title: Sabrina J. Ragan

commentText: I am writing regarding the proposed regulatory changes to the Air Carrier Access Act.  These changes are very troubling to me both as the Executive Director of an Indpendent Living Center and as a private individual.  As an individual I have flown to all parts of the US on numerous occasions over the past 20+ years.  This has never been an easy experience but the proposed changes will make it even more difficult for people with disabilities.  As a wheelchair user who is unable to stand I am particularly concerned about the proposed elimination of bulkhead seating and the regulations which allow aircraft to not provide accessible restrooms unless they have more than one aisle.Have you ever had to restrict your fluid intake and not eat anything for several hours prior to a flight continuing to not partake during the flight? This is necessary when one can't get to the restroom for several hours - until a layover or change of planes.  On long flights this can be several hours.  This concern is one of the reasons I've never flown overseas!  Anyone who has ever had surgery that allowed them to have "nothing by mouth" after meidnight knows how uncomfortable this is!  Furthermore this causes me to become de-hydrated my legs swell and I feel generally miserable by the time I reach my destination - not a good way to start a vacation or business trip!Trying to board a plane when you can't walk is another uncomfortable humiliating and sometimes dangerous experience.  Being lifted and dragged on a "straightback" (a skinny little chair with no wheels and a high back which fits down the aisle of the aircraft)is bad enough but at least bulkhead seating is close to the front and allows the chair to be maneuvered so I can transfer to the seat.  This is not possible in other seating meaning that attendants who are often not trained and not very strong have to lift me into the seat.  This is dangerous for me and them!  Bulkhead seating also gives a bit more room so I can get my legs up keeping swelling (from air pressure and lack of fluids) to a minimum.  Eliminating this seating will also make it nearly impossible for s person with a service dog to fly since there is no room for the animal in regualr seating.  As an agency we have had several complaints from individuals using oxygen who had great difficulty flying.  The proposed regulations will make this even more difficult!  A person is not allowed to take their own oxygen onboard the plane (which is understandable for safety reasons) but many airlines also don't provide oxygen in flight.  What is this individual supposed to do?  I recently spoke with a person who had to pay an extra $100 per flight to have oxygen available to them.  The cost for oxygen ($400) was more than the cost of the airline ticket to Florida!I am also concerned that we are taking a huge step backwards by letting airport terminals and gates fall under the requirements of the ACAA rather than the ADA.  People with disabilities have fought for many years for the protections that the ADA provides only to find that it is being ignored in this circumstance!  Jetways are notoriously unsafe with steep ramps (not meeting code) that end abruptly.  Once again many airline staff are not trained to navigate a wheelchiar safely in this environment.  The proposed regulations will also eliminate the person's right to sue when they have a serious problem while flying as they have under the ADA.Thank you for this opportunty to comment on the proposed regulations.  Plese contact me if further information is required.SincerelyMary Ewing
docketTitle: Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel - Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM)
title: Mary E. Ewing

commentText: I am a 50 year old with severe scoliosis.  Due to the curvature of my spine my chest cavity is smaller than an average person.  Since my lungs do not have enough space to expand my lung capacity is only 25% of what it should be.  Fortunately I am able to function quite well.  I use supplemental oxygen at night but I rarely need it during the day.  I work 40 hours a week at the Cortland County Probation Department in New York State where I have been employed for 23 years.  At the end of 2002 I was appointed the Director of the Probation Department.     As a member of a ten person team from my community involved in establishing a Drug Court I traveled to Charlotte NC in March 2005 for a training.  The training is funded by a federal grant through the Department of Justice.  On the return flight from Charlotte I had a great deal of difficulty breathing.  My heart was racing and I knew my blood oxygen level was going lower and lower as the flight went on.  I was so relieved when the plane started the descent.  It took me over 3 weeks to recover from that episode.  I had flown before but I had never had such a hard time.  I decided at that time that I would make arrangements to have oxygen on any future flight I might need to take.      The next part of the Drug Court training was scheduled in Traverse City MI from August 9 to August 12.  As soon as I received the flight arrangements through the federal grant program I tried to make arrangements for oxygen on the flights.  I estimate that I made over 50 phone calls attempting to arrange for oxygen.  I was not successful.  I have now learned that an airline does not have to allow oxygen if the airline does allow oxygen it doesn't have to allow it on every flight if the airline allows oxygen on a flight it can limit the number of passengers permitted to use it and the airline can decide to not allow oxygen if its supplies are low.  Also I learned that the airline can charge very high fees for oxygen on each flight.      After I realized I could not travel with my team members I located an airline out of another airport that allowed oxygen on a flight I could use.  After the red tape of getting approval from the funding source to make different travel arrangements I contacted the airline to inform the officials that I needed oxygen on that flight.  I was told oxygen would not be available on the flight since the airline's supplies were running low.  The charge for oxygen on each flight was $100 (the total for my trip would be $400 since I had 4 flights for the round-trip).  I figure the size canister I needed for one flight costs me about $5 when I have it delivered to my home.  When I need oxygen delivered I call the supplier located about 30 miles from my home and the oxygen can be delivered the next day.  I suggested to the airline that with the $95 extra being charged for the oxygen perhaps the supplier could be asked to deliver more.  I was told that the airline orders in bulk and extra deliveries were not possible.      The bottom line is that I did not go to the training.  When I reported to my team that I could not make the necessary travel arrangements they were shocked.  Our leader Judge Thomas Meldrim decided to try his hand at getting the travel arranged.  He met the same barriers.  He also contacted US Senator Charles E. Schumer from NY to see if he could assist.  I appreciate Judge Meldrim's efforts but I did not want to become "a cause."  I am a regular person trying to work hard participate in community efforts and attend trainings with my colleagues.  One of the most upsetting aspects of this entire saga is that it has made me feel more handicapped than I have ever felt in my life.  I've always been able to accept my limitations but I have never been excluded from a normal activity that I am capable of participating in.  I apologized to the County officials for being unable to carry out my duties.     It is essential that persons needing medical oxygen during air travel have access to it.  More and more people will be needing this assistance as the population ages.  In this age of trying to eliminate discrimination and encourage inclusion the current regulations and the proposed regulations do just the opposite - they create a whole class of outsiders and "second class" citizens.      The Air Carrier Access Act must give ACCESS to travel for all citizens.  I urge the policy makers to amend the regulations and allow oxygen on all flights at a reasonable cost.
docketTitle: Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel - Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM)
title: Jane E. Goldner

commentText: Docket ClerkDepartment of Transportation400 7th Street SW. Room PL-401Washington DC 20590.Docket Number OST-2004-19482-1 Dear Docket Clerk The vast majority of comments received by the Department of Transportation (DOT) in response to its Notice of Proposed Rule Making have focused on air travel with assistance dogs the most common type of service animal used by disabled Americans.  In particular the issue of assistance dogs unable to fit in the floor space in front of passengers with disabilities has been the center of attention. Current airline practices of providing an empty seat where space is available or asking for a volunteer to share leg space with the assistance dog have created excellent working relationships between disabled passengers and the airline industry. However the language recommended in the NPRM suggesting that the disabled passenger could be charged for an extra seat asked to take a later flight or have the assistance dog shipped in cargo are seen as threats by members of the assistance dog partner community to their ability to travel by air. The three options cited in the NPRM would have a devastating impact on air travel by assistance dog partners because:  1. Purchasing a second seat is not a viable option since the additional costs would exclude most disabled people with large dogs from trae dogs from traveling by air. It would place an undue financial burden on them and would be seen as an overt form of discrimination. A frequently cited statistic is that 70% of the54 million Americans with disabilities are unemployed and more than 40% rely on the federal welfare program. Disabled Americans constitute the most economically deprived segment of our nation's population. Finally if a flight is fully booked how would being charged for a second seat solve the problem? 2. Traveling on a later flight does not guarantee the issue will be resolved since the same circumstances may exist on the later flight. 3. Shipping the assistance dog in cargo is a totally unacceptable option for IAADP assistance dog partner members. A number of comments already submitted have indicated such separation was declared a violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act by the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals in the Crowder case against the state of  Hawaii. That this option is even suggested by DOT is an indication of a lack of understanding of the work performed by guide hearing and service dogs and the relationship of these canine assistants to their disabled partners.  Once again IAADP recommends the following language be adopted as official advice to in-flight crews and counter agents:      "You may offer the passenger sitting in a seat adjacent to the disabled passenger traveling with a large service animal a seat in the same class of service in another part of the cabin.  If no seats are available in that class of service you may ask for a volunteer willing to occupy the seat next to the disabled passenger requiring sharing of leg room.  If no volunteer is forthcoming and seats are available in another class of service in another part of the cabin you may ask the adjacent passenger or the disabled passenger to occupy a seat in that other class of service." Using this approach to the issue of the assistance dog unable to fit within the floor space in front of the disabled passenger's seat would not be a financial burden for the airlines or an inconvenience to other passengers. It would formalize current air carrier policies and be a reasonable accommodation. If the second seat charge is instituted as stated in the NPRM it would lead to a further loss of airline revenue since fewer people with disabilities would be able to travel by air.  Where every seat on a flight is occupied at least one other passenger would be willing to share floor space with a guide hearing or service dog. That has been my experience and theexperience of many other IAADP members.  DOT and the air carriers should be focusing on the issue of access in the Air Carrier Access Act. The proposed DOT rules noted in this letter would work against such access.  As a person with multiple sclerosis I depend on my service dog to alert me prior to an episode. Her alerts give me an opportunity to advise the flight crew that I will be experiencing certain symptoms and to have a wheelchair ready for me when we land. She has traveled on numerous flights with no problems and no complaints by either crew or passengers.  In fact she is better behaved than most passengers; ie she doesn't drink she doesn't get loud and she certainly doesn't kick the seat in front of her. I live on railroad retirement disability.  How can I afford to buy two seats on an airplane?  Isn't it enough that I have to spend over $400 a month on medication alone just to keep me alive?Perhaps you should walk a mile in our shoes.  People staring at you; walking around you pretending you don't exist; sticking out like a sore thumb and then being questioned on just what disability to I have. Look at your own actions with disabled people.  Do you treat them the same as non-disabled people?  Or do you talk loud and slow as if we didn't have a brain in our head.  Well my IQ is 167.  What is yours?

commentText: My name is Susan Harber and and I am interested in the regulatory language about Seating Accommodations in the Plane Cabin for Disabled Persons with Assistance dogs.I do not approve of the new language in the DOT's Notice of Proposed Rule Making (NPRM) that grants the airlines the right to charge a disabled passenger for an extra seat put the dog in cargo or make the team get off the plane if the service animal cannot fit in the small space allotted directly in front of the passenger's seat.  This is obsured.  I am not disabled no one in my family is disabled requiring the assistant of a dog but I am very pleased that we have been able to act as caring individuals to those who are in need and have provided for them on the airlines to this point.  My objections follow:Purchasing a second seat is not a viable option since the additional costs would exclude most disabled people with large dogs from traveling by air. It would place an undue financial burden on them. A frequently cited statistic is that 70% of the 54 million Americans with disabilities are unemployed and more than 40% rely on the federal welfare program. Disabled Americans constitute the most economically deprived segment of the population. Finally if a flight is fully booked how would being charged for a second seat solve the problem? Traveling on a later flight does not guarantee the issue will be resolved since the same circumstances may exist on the later flight. The prospect of being forced to delay the trip missing connections pick up times and appointments would be a huge disincentive to air travel. Shipping the assistance dog in cargo due to the risk of trauma or loss is an option unacceptable to IAADP assistance dog partner members. Such a separation was declared to be a violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act by the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals in the Crowder case against the state of Hawaii. You may offer the passenger sitting in a seat adjacent to the disabled passenger traveling with a large service animal a seat in the same class of service in another part of the cabin. If no seats are available in that class of service you may ask for a volunteer willing to occupy the seat next to the disabled passenger requiring sharing of leg room. If no volunteer is forthcoming and seat are available in another class of service you may ask the adjacent passenger or the disabled passenger to occupy a seat in that other class of service.It is never too much to ask to treat a person with a disability with the highest respect and to provide for them an the most acceptable of manner.RegardsSusan Harber228 Hillside AvenueAtlantic Highlands NJ  07716
docketTitle: Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel - Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM)
title: Susan J. Harber

commentText: My name is Suzan Morris and as a disabled citizen contemplating the acquisition of an Assistance dog I am concerned about the proposed change to the regulatory language regarding Seating Accommodations in the Plane Cabin for Disabled Persons with Assistance dogs. I do not approve of the new language in the DOT's Notice of Proposed Rule Making (NPRM) that grants the airlines the right to charge a disabled passenger for an extra seat put the dog in cargo or make the team get off the plane if the service animal cannot fit in the small space allotted directly in front of the passenger's seat. It penalizes disabled people working with large dogs for physical support guidance or wheelchair pulling. Even smaller dogs wearing backpacks containing medical supplies and equipment required by the disabled passenger may not fit into this space.  As a young woman with Multiple Sclerosis receiving disability income this would place an undue financial burden on me and millions of other Disabled Americans. Traveling on a later flight does not guarantee the issue will be resolved since the same circumstances may exist on the later flight. The prospect of being forced to delay the trip missing connections pick up times and appointments would be a huge disincentive to air travel.  Shipping the assistance dog in cargo due to the risk of trauma or loss is an  unacceptable option. Such a separation was declared to be a violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act by the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals in the Crowder case against the state of Hawaii.I believe this inclusion of new regulatory language would violate the spirit of the Air Carrier Access Act which Congress passed to ensure the airlines would increase the accessibility of air travel to the disabled population.I would like to propose the following substitute language: "You may offer the passenger sitting in a seat adjacent to the disabled passenger traveling with a large service animal a seat in the same class of service in another part of the cabin. If no seats are available in that class of service you may ask for a volunteer willing to occupy the seat next to the disabled passenger requiring sharing of leg room. If no volunteer is forthcoming and seat are available in another class of service you may ask the adjacent passenger or the disabled passenger to occupy a seat in that other class of service."Using this approach to the issue of the assistance dog unable to fit within the floor space in front of the disabled passenger's seat would not be a financial burden for the airlines or an inconvenience to other passengers.SincerelySuzan D. MorrisOld Orchard Beach Maine USA

commentText: The Department of Transportation's Notice of Proposed Rule Making (NPRM) contains an alarming change to the regulatory language about seating accommodations for assistance dog partners. The proposed rule grants airlines the right to require a passenger with an assistance dog to purchase a second ticket if the canine assistant is not small enough to fit in the floor space directly in front of the passenger's seat. Alternatively airlines may require the passenger to ship the dog in cargo or wait for a later flight. IAADP does not believe this proposed policy is "a reasonable accommodation" for those of us traveling with assistance dogs. It penalizes disabled people working with large dogs for physical support guidance or wheelchair pulling. Even smaller dogs wearing backpacks containing medical supplies and equipment required by the disabled passenger may not fit into this space.We believe this inclusion of new regulatory language would violate the spirit of the Air Carrier Access Act which Congress passed to ensure the airlines would increase the accessibility of air travel to the disabled population.Purchasing a second seat is not a viable option since the additional costs would exclude most disabled people with large dogs from traveling by air. It would place an undue financial burden on them. A frequently cited statistic is that 70% of the 54 million Americans with disabilities are unemployed and more than 40% rely on the federal welfare program. Disabled Americans constitute the most economically deprived segment of the population. Finally if a flight is fully booked how would being charged for a second seat solve the problem? Traveling on a later flight does not guarantee the issue will be resolved since the same circumstances may exist on the later flight. The prospect of being forced to delay the trip missing connections pick up times and appointments would be a huge disincentive to air travel. Shipping the assistance dog in cargo due to the risk of trauma or loss is an option unacceptable to IAADP assistance dog partner members. Such a separation was declared to be a violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act by the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals in the Crowder case against the state of Hawaii. "You may offer the passenger sitting in a seat adjacent to the disabled passenger traveling with a large service animal a seat in the same class of service in another part of the cabin. If no seats are available in that class of service you may ask for a volunteer willing to occupy the seat next to the disabled passenger requiring the sharing of leg room. If no volunteer is forthcoming and seats are available in another class of service in another part of the cabin you may ask the adjacent passenger or the disabled passenger to occupy a seat in that other class of service."Using this approach to the issue of the assistance dog unable to fit within the floor space in front of the disabled passenger's seat would not be a financial burden for the airlines or aninconvenience to other passengers.

The proposed rule grants airlines the right to require a passenger with an assistance dog to purchase a second ticket if the canine assistant is not small enough to fit in the floor space directly in front of the passenger's seat. Alternatively airlines may require the passenger to ship the dog in cargo or wait for a later flight. IAADP does not believe this proposed policy is "a reasonable accommodation" for those of us traveling with assistance dogs. It penalizes disabled people working with large dogs for physical support guidance or wheelchair pulling. Even smaller dogs wearing backpacks containing medical supplies and equipment required by the disabled passenger may not fit into this space.We believe this inclusion of new regulatory language would violate the spirit of the Air Carrier Access Act which Congress passed to ensure the airlines would increase the accessibility of air travel to the disabled population.Purchasing a second seat is not a viable option since the additional costs would exclude most disabled people with large dogs from traveling by air. It would place an undue financial burden on them. A frequently cited statistic is that 70% of the 54 million Americans with disabilities are unemployed and more than 40% rely on the federal welfare program.
