commentText: Florida Department of Transportation Comments and Response to the U.S. Department of Transportation еТNotice of Regulatory ReviewеУ (Docket No. OST-2005-20112-1)Thank you for the opportunity to suggest regulatory revisions that will improve the effectiveness of existing rules and identify new rules that may be needed.  Our recommendation relates to 23 CFR 750.707 issued by Federal Highway Administration which deals with outdoor advertising control.  We believe that the current regulations accurately reflect the intent of Congress in 1965 when the Highway Beautification Act (Title 23 U.S. Code Section 131) was initiated.  However the passage of forty (40) years has demonstrated that the regulations prohibiting modifications to nonconforming signs guarantee continuation into the foreseeable future of unsightly and old outdoor advertising signs adjacent to the National Highway System and frustrates stateеХs attempts to reduce the number size and height and to improve spacing distance between these signs.We appreciate your consideration of this suggestion.Kenneth M. Towcimak DirectorOffice of Right of WayFlorida Department of Transportation Recommendation:The Florida Department of Transportation recommends that 23 CFR 750.707 issued by the Federal Highway Administration be modified to remove specific requirements prohibiting the modification of nonconforming outdoor advertising signs and that a provision be added requiring that each state develop its own requirements for control with the objective of 1) reducing the overall number of nonconforming signs and 2) improving the appearance of roadways on which nonconforming signs remain.Discussion:The Highway Beautification Act 23 USC е¤ 131 (HBA) was developed with the intent that nonconforming signs would be removed by requiring the states to purchase them.  To facilitate this funding was to be provided so that the Federal share of the required sign compensation would be 75% of the cost.  So strong was this provision that specific language was included providing that unless the Federal funds were made available the removal requirement was tolled.  Because of the basic premise that nonconforming signs would be purchased and removed nothing in the HBA itself addresses the long term policy toward nonconforming signs.  It simply assumes they will cease to exist.Federal funding for purchase of nonconforming signs has never been made available in amounts necessary to substantially reduce the numbers of these very expensive structures.  Even at the time of the original drafting of the Federal Regulations in 23 CFR Subpart G it had become apparent that the Federal share would not be forthcoming anytime soon.  However in anticipation of the future funding the regulations in 23 CFR 750.707 were written from the standpoint of prohibiting changes to the nonconforming signs so that their value would not be enhanced and the required level of future Federal funding for purchase increased.After almost forty (40) years it is doubtful that the extremely large amounts necessary for the Federal share of funding for the removal of nonconforming signs in the states will be forthcoming.  Although ISTEA included provisions allowing states to use their general highway appropriations for the removal of nonconforming signs the Dire Emergency Supplemental Appropriations Act of 1992 inserted language in 23 USC е¤ 131(n) making it clear that the use of such funds for this purpose is a state prerogative and is not the еТFederal shareеУ which would trigger the nonconforming sign purchase requirements of the HBA.  The effect is that Congress has stated that the purchase and removal of nonconforming signs is purely at the discretion of the state.  In addition the regulatory assumption that the cost of structural materials in the sign constitute the major factor in the signеХs value does not consider the widely varying national methodology for determining the value of nonconforming signs.  Several state courts have ruled that valuation of the signs for purchase must consider the income producing potential of the sign not just its depreciated reproduction cost.  Where such a rule is in effect as in Florida the current regulations on sign modifications do little to control the value of the signs.  Under this method of valuation the important issue is the amount of traffic passing by the sign that is its view potential not the nature of the construction materials in the sign.Although the regulations had a valid purpose at their initiation that purpose no longer exists.  Rather than providing a mechanism for the states to improve highway beautification the current regulations place barriers in the way of statesеХ highway beautification efforts.  Regulations intended to control the cost of acquisition now preserve the status quo and impede highway beautification efforts where eliminating and moving nonconforming signs is required.Signs actively maintained under normal industry standards will exist in perpetuity.  By requiring signs to remain еТsubstantially the same as it was on the effective date of the State law or regulationsеУ and without providing funding to remove them the regulation ensures that these unsightly old signs will continue to exist into the future.  Achieving effective highway beautification in this circumstance is extremely difficult for the states.In announcing the America the Beautiful initiative in January 1965 President Lyndon B. Johnson said еТI want to make sure that the America we see from these major highways is a beautiful America.еУ  Although the HBA was the cornerstone of this initiative it should not be forgotten that the original goal was the beautification of highways not just the elimination of signs.  Considering that the removal of nonconforming signs by purchase is discretionary with the state and state laws regarding valuation methods vary the reasonable conclusion is that the states should be given the opportunity and flexibility to develop their own regulations for dealing with nonconforming signs within the overall objective of achieving the original goal of the HBA the beautification of highways.
docketTitle: Notice of Regulatory Review
organization: Florida Department of Transportation Office of Right of Way
title: Florida Department of Transportation

commentText: My husband and I are small businessowners.  We are in the insurance business.  By far we deal with Chicago insurance carriers over any on the east coast.  It will be very detrimental to our business should Indiana follow Eastern time.  Small businesses are the back bone of the United States.  Why does it seem like it's the large corporations are the ones driving the change to Eastern over Central.  Please follow Central.  Thank you.  Sue Peters
docketTitle: Time Zone Boundaries in the State of Indiana
title: Susan H. Peters

commentText: My husband and I both wish to be in Central Time Zone. We went to the meeting at the court house-which was a waste of time-we weren't even allowed to vote and they said it wouldn't do any good anyhow-they would just let the higher ups take care of it. Like it's all cut and dried already anyhow. What kind of AMERICANISM is that anyhow?
docketTitle: Time Zone Boundaries in the State of Indiana
title: Anne C. Devitt

commentText: This is a petition being submitted on the behalf of the citizens of Benton County in the Central far Western part of the State of Indiana.  I am Mel A. Budreau President of the board of commissioner in Benton County.  A public hearing was held on August 29th at 6:30 PM at the Benton County Court House to discuss and listen to the publics wishes regarding which time zone would best serve the citizens of Benton County.  Supplies and goods are shipped equally in our estimation to the West and East.  TV and radio are received from both Illinois and Indiana (Indianapolis and Chicago) along with local radio.  No bus or rail is availble in the County. These services would be available in both Lafayette In. and Danville Il. Lafayette being a few miles closer. Equal distance between O'Hare Airport in Chicago Il. and Indianapolis Int. airport in Indianapolis In.(100 miles one way to each) Midway Airport is actually the closest regional airport just south of Chicago Il. Approximately 60% of commuting residents commute to Tippicanoe County and the other 40% commute to Newton White Warren and Fountain Counties in In. and Iriquois County in Il. We are a very rural agricultural county with very little industry with a stable population since the 2000 census. Weather and commodity prices determines much of our economy.  Benton County has several churches to serve our residents.  We have a newly constructed consolidated elementary school next to our county consolidated high school which was consolidated in 1968.  Health care is available within our county.  We have Dr.'s in 3 of our 5 small incorporated towns. (Fowler Otterbein and Oxford) Hospitals used are in Tippicanoe County Warren County and Iraquois County in Hoopston Il.  Benton County has had petitions located at the Benton County court house since August 29th and the results of those petitions are as follows.  23 for Eastern 59 for Central and 14 for which ever Tippicanoe County chooses located to our Southeast.  As President of the Benton County commissioners I have collected information from businesses and citizens that reflect a vast majority requesting Benton County to go with Central Time.  Since I am an elected official I feel it is my responsibility to petition to the DOT that Benton County go with Central Time Zone.  It is a very difficult decision as we do have more citizens commute to Tippicanoe County and it was just reported that Tippicanoe County is requesting Eastern Time Zone.  Our local TV news does come from Tippicanoe County as well as a Daily paper.  However many Benton County residents do receive weekly newspapers from Benton County White County and Iriquois County in Illinois. I am requesting the DOT to issue a NPRM on the behalf of Benton County and its citizens who responded to the time zone issue.  This issue has put myself as well as my fellow commissioners in a very difficult position.  We hope you will respect our request and allow a Benton County a public hearing.  Thank You for your respect and consideration.  Mel A. Budreau President Benton County Commissioners
docketTitle: Time Zone Boundaries in the State of Indiana
title: Mel A. Budreau

commentText: 9-15-05--Indiana should remain on Eastern STANDARD time year round and not go on daylight savings time.--Indiana is on the west edge of the Eastern time zone and there is quite a difference of sun rise and sun set times in Indiana and the sun rise and sun set times that affect those states further east in the Eastern time zone.  It can be as much as two hours difference.--People say moving Indiana to daylight savings time will "save" energy costs.  That is simply not true as we will incur the same expenses for the early morning hours energy useage that many people will incur as they get up and about.  The early morning people will forever be in the dark and not get to enjoy the early morning sunlight.  Not everyone operates on "banker's hours."--The Indiana state representatives/congress people and the Washington-wanna-be-governor state it is essential to go on daylight savings time for business purposes and to keep up with the companies and other states in the Eastern time zone.  Geesh!  What utter nonsense.  With the internet conference calls/meetings email fax overnight delivery etc. the business folks should be able to coordinate their schedules to get done what they need to during the business day.  If not let THEM adjust their work hours and quit messing with the lives of the rest of us!  --I guess the businesses governments and economy of all states west of Indiana aren't able to properly function since they're not in the Eastern time zone. --With the forced change to daylight savings time the kids will be going to school in the dark/morning dusky dawn which makes it more dangerous for the kids.  I guess the kids aren't as important as the business people having their extended evening sunlight hours.--As it is now as of late August through mid-September and beyond we are already not seeing any sunlight until almost 7:00 AM or later.  On cloudy days it is even worse.  With daylight savings time it will be almost 8:00 AM or later before we'll have sunlight and there'll be kids already out waiting for busses and/or walking to school in the extended morning darkness.  So much for the professed concern and care for the children eh?--With the extension of daylight savings time to begin in March and extend through to the end of November morning daylight matters will be even worse.  It may help those on the eastern portion of the Eastern time zone but not those of us on the western edge of the Eastern time zone.  For that matter it affects each "east edge v. west edge" time zone in that manner.--With the forced change to daylight savings time the extended light during the evening hours is desired by business people for golf or other social events.  How many of those business people will extend their evening work hours.  Not many if any.  They just want more play time.  It's not actually about business it's the play time/party time they want.--Locally the county officials had to hold a public meeting for "citizen input" although they had already decided to submit their response for the county to go on daylight savings time.  The citizens knew their input would not matter and few appeared at the meeting.--The entire issue of Indiana going on daylight savings time should have been put to a vote for all citizens of Indiana to have a true voice in this touchy subject.  However despite appeals to do so Indiana's representatives/congress people would not put the issue on the ballot for a referrendum vote by the citizens of Indiana.  Talk about legislation without TRUE representation!--Hopefully the issue of daylight savings time will be reviewed in upcoming sessions of Indiana government and either put on the ballot for a referrendum vote by ALL citizens of Indiana or somehow get the 2005 legislation overturned and keep Indiana on Eastern STANDARD time.  Then our state won't have to be divided into sections of Eastern and Central times.--And just why do people find it so hard to accept Indiana being on "standard" time while others are on "daylight" time?  To "conform" to daylight savings time just so folks don't have to know the time is silly.  Do we all want to be sheep and follow the crowd?  --Kudos to Arizona and Hawaii for standing their ground and not caving in to daylight savings time!!--The issue of Indiana on daylight savings time would have been moot had the representative not gone against his word given to his constituents that he would not vote for it; at the last minute much to the detriment of the folks he said he would "represent" he turned tail and voted for daylight savings time.
docketTitle: Time Zone Boundaries in the State of Indiana
title: Karen Van Every

commentText: To Whom It May Concern:          From looking at the entries on DOT docket number 22114 it is clear that a good number of Indiana businesses have been for Eastern Time.     It is also more than clear; that the average Hoosier adult is for Central Time for all of the human reasons.               Indiana clearly has had a long-term problem of which time zone it wants to be in because businesses have been very greedy in wanting both DST and Eastern Time even though we are no where near the Eastern Time Zone Line!       However it is the vote of the people that will eventually count the most.               With the addition of 5 more weeks of Daylight Savings Time to be imposed on us by the FEDs this will put the Indiana sun coming up at about 8:20 a.m. in November of 2007; this is entirely out of place and will become unacceptable to most Hoosiers.         It is my projection that if the State of Indiana is not placed into the Central Time Zone as a large percentage of Hoosiers want we may again re-live the history of the early 1970s.      In the Early 70s Indiana was placed on DST by the state legislature the people of Indiana were not happy with DST on EST and they forced the legislature through public outcry to take Indiana out of DST the following cycle.              It is the greed of the Fortune 500 type of companyеХs that may well put an end to Day Light Saving Time in Indiana for the second time.     Should this projection come to pass Governor Daniels has no one to blame but himself for misleading the people of Indiana along with sidestepping the wishes of the Indiana State Legislature!         Steve L WilsonSteve Wilson Enterprises46 E Court StreetPaoli IN  47454812-723-2345
docketTitle: Time Zone Boundaries in the State of Indiana
title: Steve L. Wilson

The meal will be delivered to the plane with your name on it. Should you need a wheel chair look in the coat closet every airliner carries one on every flight.  The FA is required to get a person that needs help getting to the toilet by doing everything but holding it for the passenger.  How nice a еТserviceеУ at no charge. YS: If that means you travel by bus or - gasp! - don't travel at all then so be it. It is NOT the responsibility of the airline industry to accomodate customers with supplemental oxygen. People that need supplemental oxygen have a еТresponsibility to pay taxes to pay for the guaranteed payment of all this infrastructure for 20 - 30 years and you are saying the airlines donеХt have a responsibility to permit them to ride on the airline.  Great logic. Every Airline that opts out of making it available is a low ball low cost carrier.  For the most part they are lucky to get a bag to baggage claim and management didnеХt want to burden them beyond there limited capabilities.  They hide behind the rule when it was set up for oxygen that permitted airlines using small 12-15 passenger airplanes not to have the heavy old bottles in them.   YS:  ....they do not carry the extremely hazardous pressurized O2 that you get from your tank at home.<<< Not quite.  Each airline contracts with a local supplier to provide filled tanks.  The oxygen is processed in the same manner whether it goes on a plane or to a customers home.  Filled by exactly the same process and еТoxygenеУ that the portable oxygen bottles on every commercial jet are filled in accordance with.  The portable bottles in the cabin and in the cockpit ARE NOT considered еТhazardousеУ.  YS:   By the way want to know why the airline oxygen costs so much? Let me educate you on just some of the reasons:<<<<< your еТeducationеУ leaves a lot to be desired.  It has been proven that the world is not flat.   YS: 1. It's special reduced-humidity O2 and not the stuff you get at home <<< not true - medical oxygen is processed exactly the same whether for home airline or hospital.  Humidifiers are provided at the point of use.  YS:  2. Each tank is carefully monitored to ensure structural integrity. We can't have even the SLIGHTEST possibility of a valve stem breaking off and having that O2 cylinder turn into a shiny metal torpedo streaking through the cabin of the plane.<<< quality control is done by the supplier that also supplies home oxygen.  Legally they do not want a еТmetal torpedo streaking throughеУ a house.  The electric generated units in this еТRule MakingеУ that have been approved by the FAA are not pressurized. commentText: I am so glad to see that the International Air Transport Assoc. wants more time to develop еТtheir factsеУ concerning safety and costs.  The safety concern is as apple pie as Motherhood no one dare said anything against the dread safety aspect no matter how erroneous it may be. Safety - Fact1.  Airlines have been providing supplemental oxygen in the passenger cabin for years on 1st rate airlines with NO safety problems.Note: These have been the old style heavy metal oxygen bottles that are continuous flow. This amendment proposed is dealing with the NEW type of supplemental oxygen generator that does not store oxygen.2.  Not included in this amendment but should be are the personal liquid oxygen bottles that are far safer than the old bottles proven safe by use for 30 some years.The LOX bottles are safer than the presently used bottles as they are under a far smaller amount of pressure like 20 psi versus 2000 psi plus. They have a pressure relief valve in the event of an airplane depressurization.  They weigh less than 10 pounds and are less of a threat to safety during turbulence than most carry on luggage in the cabin.  Most important they can be set on demand and cannot be emptied all at once to become a terrorist threat like a another method (s) I can think of and I am not even a terrorist looking for a method.  Cost - Adding the new electric oxygen generators should cost about the same as the heart defibrillators as they are similar in price.  Perhaps even less as the training for the FAеХs will be less.  Less cost than carrying a wheel chair on every commercial airliner on every flight everyday for how many years?  Weight on any airplane in motion is paid for by added fuel burn.  Interesting that the airlines have unilaterally added the heart defibrillators and the wheel chairs at no cost to those that use them.  Yet for people with a disability of needing supplemental oxygen the airlines have NOT filled that need on every commercial flight at no cost.  Oh I forgot the government  in there wisdom did not get the need for supplemental oxygen covered in the Disabilities Act. Great job of lobbying by the airlines.   In the rest of the world a person needing supplemental oxygen IS considered a disability.  With the airlines catering to еТsomeеУ disabled passengers unilaterally we now have a clear cut case of discrimination in the civil courts.  Here is a way to eliminate any extra costs for the еТover burdenedеУ airlines.  Add to this amendment the portable oxygen bottles such as Helios and Spirit.  That way a passenger would provided his own oxygen that would take him from curbside to the plane through the flight and to curbside on arrival.  These and other units can provide oxygen for anywhere from 4 hours up to 20 hours which give the passenger the independence they want and of course the joy for the airlines of NO COST.  We do not need any further delays in implementing this amendment and adding the portable bottles.

commentText: To Whom this may concern: I live in Mishawaka about 5 minutes south of Michigan who is on Eastern Time. I'm also directly north of Kentucky on the Eastern zone time side. I own a business that supports customers networks. Currently I only have Michigan to deal with for about 1/2 the year due to the daylight savings time. Now there saying that St.Joseph county may go to Central Time and Elkhart will stay Eastern. Now if that happens now not only will I have to deal with Michigan but also Elkhart. That means that my customers in Michigan and Elkhart will have to go without support for an hour due to the time change (7:00am in Mishawaka=8:00am in Michigan and Elkhart). In order for me to cover that hour I would either have to pay my employees OT which I don't like or they will have to come in at 7:00am which they don't like plus if I go to a 7-4 time then my client in St.Joseph county will have no support from 4:00-5:00pm. I find this absolutely ridiculous and only idiots could come up with such a plan. St.Joseph county is going to stick out like a sore thumb just another reason to call this state backwards. Folks look at the MAP and the timezones of the states surrounding Indiana. It doesn't take a rocket scientist to figure this one out. With disgustRaymond BaslyB.N.C.Basly Network Consulting INC.Raymond P. Basly MCNE MCSE 5617 Ottawa Court Suite 1B Mishawaka IN 46545 Ph. commentText: TIME ZONES INDIANA   I would like to support the idea that if we have to switch to daylight savings that the majority of the state go to central time. As a teacher I find that so many children already are  sleep deprived and struggling to stay awake in class. With the sun setting later at the end of the day ( with eastern daylight time) the children will be going to bed even later than now and have greater difficulty in getting  up because it will be darker in the morning. If we are so concerned about providing optimal conditions for learning then having a time zone that does not tempt people to stay up later is best. Many adults as well suffer from sleep deprivation so why encourage everyone to stay up later at night?  I would imagine that sleep deprived employees cost businesses millions of dollars not to mention the accidents that are a result of tired drivers workers etc. If we can not be on central/ central daylight time then let's stay the way we are and drop the idea of daylight savings.  Sue Hunter

commentText: This e-mail is to express my concerns about the time zone issue now facing St. Joseph County Indiana. My main concern is a state-wide one related to how business and transportation occur on a nationwide scale. As I understand it the goal of IndianaеХs being put in a given time zone and moving back and forth from standard to daylight time like virtually everyone else is so that other states know what time we are on because we move as they do twice a year and this will make it easier to do business with Indiana.  It seems to me that еТcarving upеУ the state between Central and Eastern times anymore than it already is will only confuse those in business and transportation services around the country all over again. For example if St. Joseph County is placed on Central time it becomes different from counties to our south and east and from Michigan immediately to our north. Someone in say Texas or New York must somehow know not just that we are in Indiana but that for reasons he/she doesnеХt care about we are not on eastern time like virtually all the rest of the state.  Of course Indiana already has a few counties actually adjacent to business centers such as Chicago that follow those time zones and that no doubt may confuse out-of-state business persons even now. If such persons have to make themselves aware of even more deviations that seem to exist for no obvious reason (we are in the exact CENTER of the state after all) I canеХt help but think it would not help Indiana in interstate commerce but hinder it. The state should be in one time zone with--I suppose--the exceptions that already exist--in order to truly be as much as possible in sync with most of the rest of the country.I am a freelance writer and at times need to call and receive calls from editors in all kinds of time zones. I canеХt imagine their reaction if thinking Indiana is generally in this or that time zone they call only to find they had the time wrong. I also occasionally take part in conference calls and it would be puzzling to those who set them up as well. My interstate dealings are small and still I do not look forward to the prospect of having to deal with this confusion. I can only imagine what larger businesses would face.My preference for IndianaеХs actual time zone would be Eastern for reasons no doubt already cited by thousands of other e-mails. But in any case pleas do not attach St. Jos. County to the northwest corner! (Once again--we are not even in the western part but in the center of the state.) Place us on the same time as the rest of the state. ItеХs the only solution that would be a solution!Thank you.Sincerely yoursPamela H. Peterson936 Simon CourtSouth Bend IN 46615P.S.I am also intensely concerned about what being singled out this way may mean in terms of confusion for many aspects of life if St. Joseph Co. opts to go to Central time and that is approved. St. Joseph and Elkahrt CoеХs truly are ONE economic unit with huge numbers of workers going both directions to work and home each day. Shopping business education and many others activities flow back and forth between these two populous counties. Having lived in both Elkhart and South Bend I am aware of this first-hand. There is not nearly as much of this kind of interface between citizens of St. Jos. Co. and LaPorte County to our west.
docketTitle: Time Zone Boundaries in the State of Indiana
title: Pamela H. Peterson

commentText: It is the mission of the Office of the Cass County Michigan Sheriff to provide professional law enforcement and crime prevention service to all citizens in accordance with the highest possible standards of integrity and fairness.  We have daily interaction with our Indiana law enforcement colleagues whether it is fellow detectives road patrol officers corrections personnel or prosecutors.  Our contacts include several counties in Indiana but the majority by far involve Elkhart and St. Joseph counties.  We work together with our Indiana counterparts to investigate criminal activity to pursue offenders to transport those offenders apprehended and/or serving sentences among our jurisdictions.  To say that putting Elkhart county into a different time zone from St. Joseph county would be inconvenient would be an understatement.  It has been more than difficult each year to deal with the semi-annual adjustment that our difference as to Daylight Savings Time has created.  To compound that by putting St. Joseph on Central Time and Elkhart on Eastern Time would be patently ridiculous.  This action if taken by the Federal government would have a seriously detrimental affect on our operations.  The potential for an increase in overtime pay for transport officers would be created; confusion will reign supreme when it comes to knowing the correct time of day in order to make meetings conduct joint investigations transport offenders complete extradition procedures attend court proceedings.  It would be our preference that the entire state of Indiana remain on Eastern Standard Time observing Daylight Savings Time as does Michigan.  However we recognize that several counties proximate to Chicago prefer Central Time;  therefore we strongly urge the Department of Transportation to keep BOTH St. Joseph and Elkhart counties in the SAME time zone most preferably the Eastern Standard Time Zone.
docketTitle: Time Zone Boundaries in the State of Indiana
title: Joseph Underwood, Jr.

commentText: Having lived my entire life in the state of Indiana White Lake and Newton counties respectivly I sincerely feel that the entire state should be on one time THE SAME TIME NOT EACH COUNTY ON IT'S OWN TIME. Half of Jasper county is on one time and the other half on a different time. Shipping to Newton Benton White Jasper Tippicanoe and Carroll counties jumping back and forth from one time zone to another multiple times with one semi delivery these are things that make Indiana look ridiculous to the rest of the states. Not to mention being a nightmare for the person scheduling delivery. I feel having parts of the state on a different time 5 months of the year is stupid.  I do not see how there can be anything financially beneficial to the way things are at present. Thank you.

commentText: Regarding the Indiana Time Zone debate:  I think that had a large portion of the population known what a debacle the daylight savings time measure was going to be My Man Mitch would not have been elected - this comes from one of the voters favoring him.  As an attorney it is difficult to coordinate schedules with courts of different counties with two different time zones proposed.  I actively practice in St. Joseph County Elkhart County Marshall County LaPorte County Lake County Starke County and others.  Seminars are frequently held in Marion County. I think it is imperative that regardless of the zone chosen that the entire state be on the same time.  I'd prefer Central.  Add to the mix the following: My working hours start at 7:00 a.m. in St. Joseph County. My husband who works in Elkhart County takes our two kids to preschool each morning. They cannot be to preschool earlier than 7:30 a.m. Therefore if St. Joseph and Elkhart County are split on time zones he will no longer be able to take the kids and my hours will of necessity have to change. commentText: TO:United States Department of TransportationAttn: Time Zone CommitteeDATE: November 21 2005FROM:Marie L. Warsko12256 Settlers Cove CourtGranger  IN  46530I am strongly in favor of Eastern Daylight Savings Time Zone for St. Joseph County IN.  The officials in the State of IN must continue to strive to make this a better place to live and work.  It appears the Chamber of Commerce and several local businesses are looking at the economic benefit of St Joseph County staying in the Eastern Time Zone.  It also appears the local politicians are looking at a political issue of getting even with Mitch Daniels (Governor of IN) for promoting Daylight Savings Time.  Recommendations should not be made on a selfish political basis but rather on what is best for the community. Studies have been conducted that show a greater number of employees travel between St. Joseph County and the counties to the East and South and also to the State of Michigan than from the neighboring Western counties and the City of Chicago.  Let us promote a healthy economic area by staying in the Eastern Time Zone. Energy will be conserved if we have the extra hour in the evening.  In a world where family values are constantly challenged let us help families play together.  Families do not play together at 5:00 in the morning. By keeping the St. Joseph County in the Eastern Time Zone families will have that extra evening hour to shoot hoops ride bikes play ball etc. without adding extra cost for outdoor lighting. During the winter months with Eastern Time the sunsets at 5:21 PM EST.  If St. Joe County would change to Central Time Zone the sun would be setting at 4:21 PM.  Winter is a dark time of the year in this area with little sunshine.  It does not make sense to compound the problem. Let children come home from school with a little extra daylight hours remaining. For both economic and lifestyle reasons I strongly believe Eastern Time would be best for Elkhart and St. Joseph Counties.MARIE WARSKO
docketTitle: Time Zone Boundaries in the State of Indiana
title: Marie Warsko

commentText: I think DOT has more to worry about with Indiana then time zones. Currently you have Indiana truck drivers who are being court ordered by Indiana courts to violate DOT laws in order to pay thier child support. And why does Indiana force truck drivers to violate DOT laws...and thus endanger the lives of everyone on the highway? According to the Indiana Child Support Agency in Indiana DOT isn't going to do anything...as I was told that contacting the DOT 'wouldn't do any good'.Instead of worrying about time zones the DOT needs to start pulling the support orders of Indiana truck drivers involved in accidents/fatalities if they want to see where a real danger is.
docketTitle: Time Zone Boundaries in the State of Indiana
title: Renee' Thomas

commentText: When Mr. Yoder said that St. Joseph COunty should withdraw their petition by a vote of 4 to 2. Three Elkhart officials and one ST. Joe. He was wrong. The vote should be 14  take into account all the officials from the other counties that would like to become part of the Central time zone. If we are going to combine counties we would have to combine all the counties in question. Not just two. Plus supreme court decisions are often times on a split vote so why not a county decision. Central time is the best option for the couinties involved. Mr. Yoder knows that and is just trying everything he can to have his way. Why does he want the other counties to follow him.
docketTitle: Time Zone Boundaries in the State of Indiana
title: Larry Laskoski

commentText: Two of our three county commissioners voted to make St. Joseph Co. a "Central Time Zone peninsula" which makes no business sense locally.  Economically medically socially and scholastically St. Joe Co. has much more in common with five of the seven surrounding counties which will be Eastern Time and the rest of Indiana which will also be Eastern Time.  I hope our St. Joseph Co. Commissioners have enough common sense to retract their appeal for Central Time after they listen to all the evidence presented to keep St. Joe and the majority of surrounding counties in ONE TIME ZONE (which by default now must be Eastern Time).  If not then I request that the DOT reverse its decision that granted St. Joe Co. Central Time so we may be united with the majority of our neighboring counties on Eastern Time.
docketTitle: Time Zone Boundaries in the State of Indiana
title: Tim Durham

commentText: I am the Chief Judge of the U.S. Bankruptcy Court for the Northern District of Indiana located in South Bend.  We get lawyers and litigants from all over the Midwest and indeed the entire country coming here for legal proceedings.  In the past the fact that most of Indiana did not observe Daylight Savings Time caused great confusion for many people coming here but at least that problem has been put to rest by the state legislature's recent action.  We will still have lawyers and litigants members of the public showing up for trials and other legal proceedings an hour early or an hour late unless you standardize the time zone for the entire state.  If that cannot be done at least keep St. Joseph County in the Eastern Time Zone since we are surrounded on three sides by states and counties that are on Eastern Time.  It would be unwise to have St. Joseph County on different time than Elkhart County (very closely linked to us in terms of employment etc.) different time than the state of Michigan adjoining us to the north and on different time than our state capital in Indianapolis.  The connection of St. Joseph County to Chicago is vastly overrated especially when you balance that with our connections commercially and culturally to Elkhart Marshall Kosciusko Fulton and Marion Counties in Indiana which I understand will all be on Eastern Time.  Thank you.
docketTitle: Time Zone Boundaries in the State of Indiana
title: Harry C. Dees

commentText: As our local elected leaders have made this issue political and are ignoring our county's constituents' requests I am making a direct appeal to the state and federal governments in favor of EASTERN time zone for St.Joseph County.Thank you.
docketTitle: Time Zone Boundaries in the State of Indiana
title: T. Anastasiou

commentText: IеХm the director for the Nappanee Indiana 911 Center I service 125 sq mile in BOTH Elkhart County and Kosciusko County in North-Central Indiana.  The way the different County Commissions are debating back and forth on what time zone they want to be in I could actually have my CITY LIMITS in TWO different zones. My computer programs are not set up to divide into different time zones on the same active call area.  I along with 7 other law enforcement agencies in Elkhart County had have spent a couple million dollars on this project over the last few years making all of our Law Enforcement and 911 Centers being able to interact with each others mobile units Records and 911 systems.  Putting the Counties on different time zones would make this useless.  I would be sending an ambulance to my city address located in Kosciusko County and have it arrive at our nearest hospital in Elkhart County and the computer would be showing that they arrived at the hospital 20 minutes BEFORE our 911 center ever received the call.  What a mess that would be and then get a lawsuit involved from the call and none of the times would be corresponding.  I have not heard anyone talking about these kind of situations in the debate wars.As the 911 Director for the City of Nappanee I believe it would be beneficial for the ENTIRE State of Indiana to be on one time zone no matter if it is Eastern or Central time zone.
docketTitle: Time Zone Boundaries in the State of Indiana
title: Tod Schmucker

commentText: After considering this proposal for some time I believe that there are two issues that the DOT needs to address in making an affirmative decision on the proposal.  The first is the approval of specific devices by brand and model.  There are already a number of devices especially in the cpap autopap and bi-pap field that have been approved for use by major international airlines such as Qantas as well as the FAA.  There is a need for airlines to be provided with lists continually updated of approved products. There is also a need for airlines to be required to maintain the updated list either electronically or in a hard copy format at each airport gate where they will be boarding passengers.The other issue I think needs to be addressed is the legal issue.  I have a strong feeling that the legal departments at the airlines have been taking a very conservative approach to devices such as the cpap.  By prohibiting all use they feel they will avoid litigation related to an inability to provide power or having the devices fail.  It may be very helpful for the DOT to provide standardized procedures for use of these devices and if the airline is in compliance with these procedures to provide the airline with protection from litigation.  Procedures such as pre-boarding and testing the power outlet (and providing a different seat if the power outlet does not work) will go a long way in accommodating the needs of both the airlines and the passengers.
docketTitle: Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel - Medical Oxygen and Portable Respiration Assistive Devices
title: Ken McLaughlin

commentText: As a private citizen I could care less what time zone we are in but as a County Clerk I would certainly appreciate that Marsall County and all surrounding counties at least be in the same time zone.  Do you know what it does to the court calendars when we are all in different time zones not to mention the time my staff spends on the telephone just answering the question "what time is it in your county?????"Respectfully Jan FisherMarshall County Clerk
docketTitle: Time Zone Boundaries in the State of Indiana
title: Jan S. Fisher

commentText: Changing the time zone in Indiana is supposedly based on business and economics.  We do business with Chicago so we should go central - or we do business with New York so we should go eastern.  Based on that we so go pacific we do business with California.  This is ridiculous.Indiana has been managing fine for decades the way it is right now - yes it can be confusing - for about a day!  Then everyone gets used to it and all is fine.I'm frustrated that the thing our new govenor thought was MOST important was this.  I can only imagine how much money has been wasted on this issue that could have been better spent elsewhere.Utterly ridiculous.thank you for your time.sue higgins.
docketTitle: Time Zone Boundaries in the State of Indiana
title: susan higgins

commentText: I write to strongly support St. Joseph County Indiana's request for Central Time.  Please consider the following important information:1)  A very high percentage of Notre Dame students interview and accept positions in Chicago.  And many companies from Chicago recruit and attend events at Notre Dame making Central Time very important.2)  Notre Dame offers an E-MBA program in Chicago which requires substantial professional interaction between Chicago and South Bend (St. Joseph County) residents.3)  I work part-time for a federal judge who has chambers in Indiana but I must travel to Chicago for court hearings.  Additionally I must communicate with the clerk's office and staff in Chicago and differing time zones creates difficulties.
docketTitle: Time Zone Boundaries in the State of Indiana
title: Margot J. OBrien

commentText: As a resident of La Porte County Indiana and a member of the staff of the La Porte Circuit Court I want you to know how difficult it is for Indiana to be on two separate time zones.  I lived in La Porte County (Central Time Zone) and attended law school at Notre Dame (Eastern Time Zone)  I would regularly have to leave my home at 6:00 a.m. to get to an 8:00 class in South Bend.  (It is a 45 minute trip).  While this was a hassel for me during my education it is a real detriment in conducting business throughout the State of Indiana.  Our office hours begin at 8:00 a.m. that means anyone in the majority of the State of Indiana cannot contact us until 9:00 a.m.  There is a two hour block in the day during the lunch hours for Eastern and Central Time that it is nearly impossible to conduct business and at the end of the day most of the state closes an hour before we do.  In addition with the difference in time during elections most important races are called for Indiana prior to the closure of the polls in La Porte Lake and Porter Counties.  This discourages people from going out to vote.I would like to reccomend that the entire State of Indiana be placed on the Central Time Zone (as it had been until 1961) as a result of your rulings.  Thank you very much.Krista Smith MacLennan
docketTitle: Time Zone Boundaries in the State of Indiana
title: Krista MacLennan

commentText: As a resident of St. Joseph County I ask the DOT to please considerthe majority decision of the residents to move the Central Time Zone.Also please consider the fact that it is a STATE law that the countymakes the final appeal and not the outsiders including the Governorand adjacent counties. The waiting of children for the school bus in the dark is a major reason for the change. Please rule in favor of the a vast majority of citzens of St. Joe County
docketTitle: Time Zone Boundaries in the State of Indiana
title: David Horvath

commentText: Governor Daniels is now officially in violation of Ind. Code 1-1-8.1-3 which states: Sec. 3. The state supports the county executive of any county that seeks to change the time zone in which the county is located under the procedures established by federal law.The St. Joseph County Board of Commissioners is seeking under the procedures established by federal law to change the time zone in which St. Joseph County is located. That means the state has to support them in their efforts right? Well apparently only if you're of the opinion that Governor Daniels is obliged to obey the law. Governor Daniels has submitted a letter to you opposing the St. Joseph County Commissioners' efforts to change time zones. In other words he is doing exactly the opposite of what the law requires him to do. The pertinent part of his letter to you is: I recommend the Department decline the petition of St. Joseph County to move from the Eastern to the Central Zone.Nevermind that he makes bogus statements about the "clear preference" of Hoosiers generally to remain in the Eastern Zone and of Elkhart County residents specifically. The statements are bogus because no mechanism has been made available to most Hoosiers to express their preference. In fact the Republican leadership has made clear its opposition to a referendum that would put this "clear preference" to the test. Nevermind that he continues his recent insistence that time zones are a "local matter." Nevermind that he forgets his campaign preference for statewide Central Time. Nevermind that he sat on his hands until the eleventh hour before offering an opinion to the public and to the USDOT.Forget all that stuff for now. He is breaking the law. The Daylight Saving Time bill added a section to the Indiana Code that specifically required the state to support a county executive's efforts to switch time zones. Instead of supporting the St. Joseph County Commissioners as the law requires Mitch Daniels is opposing their efforts. This is simply outrageous. He wasn't ignorant of that provision of the law. His spokesperson was recently asked about it and offered up an explanation of that provision with which only an illiterate could agree alleging that the provision required support only of the process not the county executive seeking to change time zones. He wasn't required to offer his opinion to the USDOT. He could have remained silent and presumably not run afoul of the law. Instead he went out of his way to violate IC 1-1-8.1-3. Just outrageous. If I were the St. Joseph County Commissioners I'd be headed to court to seek an injunction of the whole Daylight Saving Time law delaying its implementation until such time as the Governor corrects his violation or the legislature repealsIC 1-1-8.1-3.
docketTitle: Time Zone Boundaries in the State of Indiana
title: George Neiswander

commentText: I have no preference for Eastern or Central time but I feel strongly that Elkhart and St. Joseph County should be in the same time zone.  My husband has a home in St. Joseph County I have a home on the lake in Elkhart County so we are back and forth between both places particularly in the summer.  We both work in Elkhart County.  As my husband practices law he often appears in Federal Court located in St. Joseph County.  Having to adjust schedules and determine times between the 2 counties will be a nightmare.  I think I like many others thought one of the purposes of switching to Day Light Savings Time was to put us all in the same time zone.  Obviously that was not the case.  If you put St. Joseph County on Central time then please do the same for Elkhart.  When we switched area codes that was something people could adjust to.  Putting 2 counties so closely connected on 2 separate time zones will not be something one will be able to adjust to it will only create more problems.  Thank you.Patricia B. Banik
docketTitle: Time Zone Boundaries in the State of Indiana
title: Patricia Banik

commentText: I think the complete state of Indiana (except for 5 exempt counties) and the entire state of Michigan should be on CENTRAL time because of where the sun is on the earth.  We are going against the Earth and Sun as it naturally occurs--Longitude.  I also think it would be more beneficial to be on Central for economic reasons. I am sorry to see politics enter the debate (Daniels siding with the Republicans in Elkhart County).  I hope you will realign our time with where we are on the planet. Thank you for reading my comments!
docketTitle: Time Zone Boundaries in the State of Indiana
title: Sue Kesim

commentText: I would like to say that despite the last minute appeal by Governor Daniels to put Dubois County on Central Time it was clear at the DOT hearing in Jasper that the entire business community as well as the schools in Dubois County support Eastern time for Dubois County and the surrounding Counties.  This was made clear by the Chamber of Commerce directors and the Mayor of Jasper.  As a businessman in Dubois County and Jasper City Councilman I would ask you to consider the wishes of the local business community who represent the commerce of this area.  Respectfully submittedBrad SegerVice-PresidentWabash Valley Produce Inc.Jasper City Councilman
docketTitle: Time Zone Boundaries in the State of Indiana
title: Brad Seger

commentText: Re:  OST Docket Number 2005-22114Dear Ms. KaletaI appreciate your facilitating the recent hearing on the issue of the time zone petition on behalf of St. Joe County.  I was given the opportunity to speak but I would like to supplement my comments with additional information that I was not able to present in the allotted 3 minutes.I would also like to cite additional letters --many of which have already been posted to the DOT website--which buttress the "convenience of commerce" argument in support of Central time.This includes statements from: еб  Steel mills in Northwest Indiana-USX and you have previously received the letter from the General Manager of IN/Tek-In-Koteеб  Trade association-the Metal Service Center Institute with headquarters in the Chicago areaеб  The largest steel distribution Coop with headquarters in the Chicago area-NASAеб  Customers such as Lapham-Hickey Champion Resources of Chicago; Case Corporation in Fargo North Dakotaеб  Suppliers of materials including metal banding (Signode Corporation--Chicago area) and contractors (Shoffner--LaPorte In)You have received a thorough letter from our traffic manager Mr. Marvin Jurjevic regarding the disadvantage we will face in securing trucking services which primarily emanate from the Central Time zone.  Another important factor is impact of product that moves from the Port of Indiana at Portage Indiana. Hundreds of thousands of tons of steel is imported into the Midwest through Portage Indiana.  Many of these tons are shipped into St. Joseph County.  By forcing St. Joe County to go to Eastern Time we are in effect penalized by one hour every working day of the year.  We cannot begin to pick up material and ship into South Bend Mishawaka or Elkhart without losing time and money.  This also restricts the total amount of product that we can bring into our facility.  Much was discussed about rail traffic.  The South Shore can speak for themselves as they make a compelling case regarding the link between Chicago and our county.  In addition there is very important information and data found in the INDOT website that speaks to the importance of our link to Chicago (2.0 Current Rail System in Indiana) in which it states "The current rail system in Indiana is structured to primarily handle east-west traffic flows across northern Indiana to and from ChicagoеУ ...(my italics).  Further in the study there are also important points made about "future intercity rail passenger service Indiana would be served by the Federal Railroad Administration's presently designated high-speed routes between the western hub at Chicago (my italics) and Detroit Cleveland Cincinnati and Cleveland."  There are obvious benefits of using rail to help address the national goal of reducing fuel consumption and costs and to promote growth into our state. Furthermore if one was to review Table 2-3 еТIndiana Rail Freight Commodities in 1999еУ you would see that the railroad transported 11.6 million tons of Primary Metal products which originated in Indiana.  Although I could not find the specific geography of where the steel moved from it would make sense that it originated from either the Port (Portage) USX (Gary) Mittal (Indiana Harbor) In Tek (New Carlisle) or perhaps Nucor Steel (Crawfordsville)--virtually all in the central time zone.  Once again the connection to points west--Central time-- are compelling.   The service and distribution business is extremely vital to our economic well being.  According to MACOG St. Joe county enjoys a growing service and distribution economy and jobs.  Businesses such as Tire Rack Town Air Freight and Woodwind/Brasswind ship and do business all over the country.  Being placed in the "time zone" center of the country is an economic benefit to those growing businesses and their employees.  In fact it can easily be argued that many places of business in the Eastern time zone do not even start until 9:00 am so that first hour of the day presents a sub-optimal option compared to later in the day.Our legislators were told that the state would be required to support the decision made by the counties.  The pressure that the Governor is placing on DOT to rescind the valid petition is an insult to the local constuents and our elected officials.  The logic that the Governor uses is odd:еб  Every county is entitled to petition in accordance with its best interest.еб  Except when your neighboring county disagrees with you.еб  Then you must forgo your interest and do what is best for your еТregionеУ.  Furthermore this decision will NOW be taken out of your hands.LetеХs take a step back to understand how we got to where we are today.In response to why State Senator John Broden voted in favor of Daylight Savings Time he commented that еТAnother critical factor in determining my favorable vote for this legislation was the fact it requires that the Governor petition the federal Department of Transportation to conduct hearings to determine where the time zone boundaries should be drawn in Indiana.  Further the legislation requires the State to support any county in its efforts to seek a change in its time zone if the local elected officials of the county believe the county is in the wrong time zone.еУ  And so the process began.  Our County St. Joseph County was charged with the responsibility of determining what is best for their constituents.  Here is a basic time line of events that took place:еб  Saint Joseph County was 1st to file a letter with the United States Department of Transportation (USDOT) on May 26 2005 signed by the mayors of South Bend and Mishawaka.еб  Saint Joseph County was 1st to hold an open public meeting on June 29 2005 at the Century Center.еб  Resolutions were discussed voted on and passed by a majority the following governmental bodies:      oCity of South Bend Common Council July 25 2005      oCity of Mishawaka Common Council August 15 2005      oSaint Joseph County Council August 23 2005      oSaint Joseph County Commissioners September 13 2005еб  On October 31 2005 the United States Department of Transportation (USDOT) tentatively granted Saint Joseph Counties petition for Central Time Zone status.As we examine what makes common sense (it is said that there is nothing common about common sense) St. Joe County should be in the Central Time Zone.  LetеХs look at some basic facts:еб  7 months of the year we were already on Central Time (people can call it Eastern Standard Time but it is really Central Time).  It will be a very simple transition to increase from 7 months to 12 months.еб  The Federal government has divided the country into regions and most regional offices for all of Indiana are in Chicago including:     oUS Department of Justice     o7th Circuit Court of Appeal     oHUDеб  Travel еР We support our local Michiana Regional Airport however there are significant problems with the number of airlines servicing our airport.  We are often forced to drive to Chicago in order to fly to our destination.  The South Shore is also linked to the Central Time Zone with South Bend being the only stop in a different time zone.еб  Media еР We support our local newspaper television and radio however we often receive our news from Chicago newspapers television and radio.What about the benefits to business?I will speak about our business - Steel Warehouse Company Inc.  We are a Steel Service Center with a significant manufacturing and distribution commitment to our area and we are located on South BendеХs west side.  In addition our South Bend facility is the corporate headquarters for processed steel tubing and fabricated products with facilities in South Bend Rock Island IL Oak Creek WI Portage IN Memphis TN and Conway AR.Here are some of the numbers:еб  Continuous ownership and operation in South Bend for close to 60 years.еб  Total Employment in South Bend 708 (including Steel Warehouse and Lock Joint Tube)еб  Total Employment Corporate 1552еб  Annual Payroll $33000000 (for the South Bend facility only)еб  Taxes $887000 (Real Estate and Personal Property)In the past 40 years our city and region were ravaged by loss of manufacturing jobs.  Gone are Studebaker Bendix Brake and Allied Products (South Bend Stamping division).  Businesses like South Bend Range and South Bend Toy have also left some relocating to the South.  And so for us to grow and survive we must follow the businessеЙmost of which is toward the greater Midwest and the South.  We are fortunate to count among our customers many fine companies like Caterpillar Case International Truck and John Deere ALL located in the Central Time Zone.  There is also significant business growth in Wisconsin (Racine is the corporate headquarters for Case) Iowa Minnesota (Crenlo / Division of Dover Industries) and points west and southwest.  This growth enables us to have a significant work force and capital investment in St. Joe County.How much steel is shipped in to our business?еб  Our annual corporate spend is close to 1000000 tons     oThat equates to 12500 rail cars еР 52 per day                         Or     o50000 truckloads еР over 200 per dayThat is a tremendous amount of merchandise coming in to our facility.  Most of which is from steel mills whose facilities and offices are located in the Central Time Zone.And what about our employees?  We must be immune from the commuter issue (I am not trying to demean this problem) but out of 498 employees at Steel Warehouse there are 31 that reside in LaPorte Porter or Lake County and only 3 reside in Elkhart.We do business in both time zones.  However in order for us to service our customers to the West we would need to keep people here until a minimum of 6:00pm.  That means that they do not get home to their families for supper or school events until at least 6:30pm.  When you factor in family time helping with homework and attending school activities it is simply to late in the evening to get it all done.Conversely our employees are more than willing to come in at 7:00am to handle commercial requirements for customers who are in the Eastern Time Zone.  So our normal workday of 8:00am еР 5:00pm would be sufficient IF we were on Central Time.We implore the DOT to allow the petition that was submitted in a fair democratic process by our County political leaders to remain in the Central Time Zone.PleaseеЙdo not put us a good corporate citizen at a competitive disadvantage.  We are in a very competitive environment and we along with our valued employees are looking to grow because we are in a global economy.  Yes with all respect we all of us are looking beyond our County or Counties.There has been significant testimony by political leaders of Elkhart County of the time zone that makes sense for them.  They are entitled to consideration provided by the DOT as they look to be in the Eastern Time Zone.  Their position which they feel is appropriate to their self-interest should not override what has been done in a fair and democratic way in St. Joe County.We donеХt think it is good representative government to allow one county to in effect have a veto power over its neighbors.We are all for cooperation but we are all against capitulation.In summary letеХs understand the opportunities and realities for growth to the West and the South.  LetеХs focus on a broader and greater economic unit not just Michiana.  LetеХs be inclusive and invite all of our good county neighbors to be a part of the potential economic prosperity and realities by reconsidering their own time zone to join this greater economic unit.LetеХs stay together if we can and become more successful more dynamic and a more united economic region in the Central Time Zone.Please excuse the length of this request.  I know that you have been besieged with data and that you are doing the best job possible to be fair. But in the end it gets down to this:еб  Does the county know what is in it's best interest -- in spite of the rhetoric of aneighboring county--or is the best decision (which has already been granted onceby the DOT) to overturn the process that was outlined by State law and take it away from the local constituents?еб  Does the GovernorеХs last minute plea for еТunityеУ in the North-Central Indiana region require that our county needs to accept the еТlowest common denominatorеУ or whichever zone is best for itеХs neighbor to the East in order to preserve that еТunityеУ?  (Please remember the pleas of officials from Marshall and Fulton Counties to be aligned with St. Joe County on Central time.)еб  In the overall scheme which allows some counties to be the еТedgeеУ of that time zone why isnеХt St. Joe county allowed to be that Eastern most edge in the Central time zone?We hope you consider these arguments and uphold the previous decision to grant St. Joseph County the right to determine that Central Time serves our area better than the alternative.SincerelyMichael LermanPresidentSteel Warehouse Company Inc.
docketTitle: Time Zone Boundaries in the State of Indiana
title: Michael Lerman

commentText: To:  United States Department of TransportationAttn:  Hon. Norman Mineta Secretary Dear Mr. Mineta:I am a resident of South Bend Indiana and I currently work and live in St. Joseph County.  Our county commissioners and the mayor of South Bend have petitioned the Department to designate this area in the central time zone.I urge you to grant this request.  As a business person with clients in the Midwest and West I have found the central time zone the most "forgiving" when dealing with customers outside the zone.  There is just  one hour difference to account for east one hour difference with those on Mountain time and two for those  on Pacific.  In addition the entire state of Indiana falls into the Central time zone region and the federal agencies that serve our state are for the most part based in Chicago (the Social Security Admin. the Federal Court system Immigration offices etc.)  Business is conducted with these agencies daily.Finally Gov. Daniels supports the eastern time zone stating that it will attract and keep business in Indiana.  Unfortunately  for our citizens the facts do not support this.  Although Indiana will be on DST next year  businesses continue to move from the state at an alarming rate including several manufacturing-based businesses moving from Elkhart County.  (Elkhart County St. Jospeh County's eastern neighbor has chosen to keep eastern time and is trying to impose its will on St. Jospeh County as well.) Many  of these businesses are moving to states in the Central time zone or offshore.  The management of these companies apparently find no economic advantage tied to the time zone but rather to the wage and educational levels of the labor force.  In addition  there  is no quantitative or qualitative evidence that one single company will move here based upon the Eastern time zone.Based on above it seems clear that the entire state should be on the Central time zone.  But since this is not the process to be followed as determined by Gov. Daniels I urge you to grant St. Jospeh County's  request to move to the Central time zone.  Thank you  for your  consideration.RespectfullyMarianne BlackPrincipalMaxx Communications
docketTitle: Time Zone Boundaries in the State of Indiana
title: Marianne Black

commentText: We live in Michigan just across the state line from South Bend Indiana  St. Joseph county where my husband works.  Having St Joseph county in the Central time zone would be extremely inconvenient.  We would have to cope with two different times year round.  The debate in Indiana has always been about whether there should be daylight saving time not which time zone.  The daylight saving time debate has been rested with the decision to go with daylight saving time for St. Joseph county in Indiana.  The primary backers of Central time in the county seem to be politicians who maybe trying to court the business vote in the area.  The residents are more in tune with the Eastern time zone and have been living that way for many years.  Please do not switch St. Joseph county to the Central time zone.  Thank you.  Diane Nichols
docketTitle: Time Zone Boundaries in the State of Indiana
title: Diane Nichols

commentText: I am writing in response to the time zone debate. I think St Joe County should be on CENTRAL TIME!  Govenor Daniels doesn't work or live in No. Indiana and has no idea what time we should be on. I would ask you honor our request to be moved to CENTRAL TIME. thanks!Sue Rice
docketTitle: Time Zone Boundaries in the State of Indiana
title: Sue E. Rice

commentText: I would strongly appeal to the DOT to set South Bend and the county in the Eastern Time Zone.  As a businessman and resident of Michigan I find  it very difficult to work out scheduling of appropriate tests or to cross the state line.  The city seems to think it is more closely aligned with Chicago than Michigan.  It would be interesting to see how much commerce comes from Berrien Cass and Van Buren Counties to the area.  It would also be advantageous to my children to be able to see the national news in the morning.  We get virtually no Michigan news or national news as we are solely dependent on South Bend for local broadcasting.  This is a disservice to the education and maturation of Michigan Children.  I urge you to put St. Joseph county in the Eastern Time Zone.  Robert C. Ward III D.O.
docketTitle: Time Zone Boundaries in the State of Indiana
title: Robert Ward

commentText: While section 11143 of SAFETEA-LU charges the Secretary of Transportation with allocating a set $15 billion among qualified highway or surface freight transfer facilities nation-wide it does not list criteria he is to take into consideration when doing so. For example is there a priority determined as to projects? What about the deteriorating conditions and/or life spans of projects are these considered? I would also want to ensure money is distributed equally between states to ensure that the entire amount isn‰ЫЄt allocated to projects in only one or two states? Ultimately I believe that having such criteria for the allocation process is extremely important as it will allow you to give an explanation of why you have denied/approved someone for funds and will cut down on the appearance of bias. Likewise is there an appeal process for the individuals denied qualified highway or surface freight transfer facility funds? Simply saying you‰ЫЄre denied when there is no set criteria and at the pure discretion of one person doesn‰ЫЄt usually sit well and or seem right without some sort of appeal process in place. It also seems troubling that the Department states ‰ЫПThe Department is not specifying any form for an application.‰Ыќ I do believe that uniformity in the application process would not only be easier for the applicant but also be more cost efficient for the individuals on the other end who are processing such. Thank you for you time and consideration.With RegardsHillary Pate
docketTitle: Notice of Solicitation for Requests for Allocations of Tax-Exempt Financing and Requests for Comments
