commentText: I support Hawaiian Airlines in its dispute with the Governor of American Samoa. Hawaiian Airlines has done a superb job in providing friendly dependable service to the people of American Samoa. I believe this unpopular Governor is running a campaign that appeals to the baser instincts of a minority of the electorate with no thought or care of the outcome of his recklessness.
docketTitle: Hawaiian Airlines, Inc. - Petition for Declaratory Order Regarding American Samoa Executive Order 05-2006
title: Donald L. Vargo

commentText: I fully support Governor Togiola's action against Hawaiian Airlines.  The citizens of American Samoa has been treated unfairly by Hawaiian Air for so long since they became the only airline servicing American Samoa. I have flown Hawaiian Air several times and I do feel very frustrated when only American Samoans are asked to stay out of the gate area at the Honolulu International Airport until they are called to board the plane.  This practise is discrimi discriminatory.  In March 2006 I flew to Honolulu on Hawaiian Air.  During the flight I asked for a free HeadSet because I was entitled to it as a frequent flyer bonus in my Premier Card.  The Flight Attendant asked for my Card and my Passport before I was given the headset.  However when I boarded the flight to San Jose all I have to do was to show my Premier Card.  This is a discriminatory to SAMOANS.THE AIRFARE BETWEEN PAGO PAGO AND HONOLULU IS OUTRAGEOUS.  HAWAIIN AIR IS TAKING ADVANTAGE OF THE SAMOAN PEOPLE BECAUSE THEY HAVE THE MONOPOLY ON THIS ROUTE THAT IS THE ONLY EXPLANATION TO THIS WHOLE FIASCOT
docketTitle: Hawaiian Airlines, Inc. - Petition for Declaratory Order Regarding American Samoa Executive Order 05-2006
title: John Ah Sue

commentText: I have flown on numerous airplanes where they show movies. This aggravates me because these movies are NOT closed captioned. there were cases where the pilot would make announcements I have no clue what they are saying. What if there was an emergency? I would not know. Also there is a rule where we are not allowed to stand too close to the first class section when we need to go to the restroom. It is a verbal rule and how do i know that? I may not understand what the stewardess is trying to relay the fear i have if I cannot understand I might be overpowered by several people and be arrested for not "obeying" the spoken rule.I believe the movies should be captioned (most movies are already closed captioned you only need a chip placed inside your movie devices it is NOT expensive.  I believe the announcement should also be typed so Deaf people can read from the seats. Think about it a deaf individual can sue DOT and that can be far more expensive than just adding few accessible tools.
docketTitle: Accommodations for Individuals Who Are Deaf, Hard of Hearing, or Deaf-Blind
title: Victoria L. Detweiler

commentText: Its suggested that u comply with ADA s regulations and law that we(the deaf community) be given access to close captioning on all movies or announcements on tv circuts at the airports..  Do u think it s fair for us to spend all that money to travel and not have access to understand what s being watched on the movies.  How about other announcements that is not shown on captioned tv circuits and we get the wrong location information or  warnings as a bomb threat and we are walking around not knowing what s going on when people are asked to leave the area or location til investigations are over or reason why the schedules of our flight has been postponed or cancelled? Why are u treating us with so much defense as we give u business when we travel to the airport and take flights out?  Give us a break and give us the necessary access to make our trip to the airport and flight pleasant.
docketTitle: Accommodations for Individuals Who Are Deaf, Hard of Hearing, or Deaf-Blind
title: Sue Cameron

commentText: You have to stop saying "not me not us etc" Have to learn to take the responsibilities and give consumers greatly satisfication on your services.  If you do notthen it will cost you more like lawsuit than you provide captions.  Captions are for everyone like Deaf Hard of Hearing Late Deafened and also to HEARING.  HEARING may not hear well on TV sound due to noisy surroundings.  Hearing may have some hearing loss later and may need captions at the airport facilities as well as airlines too.  Think about it.
docketTitle: Accommodations for Individuals Who Are Deaf, Hard of Hearing, or Deaf-Blind
title: Sara S. Patterson

commentText: Dear Sirs Central time is the best for Pulaski County. I drive freight in and out of Chicago twice every day from Francesville. Back and forth..When the good citizens of this county decided on their own to stay on Eastern It really threw my schedule into a mess..When I needed to go to the Post Office they were not opened..Same with the Banks and the Court House too..They said they were on "Commerce" time..(what ever that is)..It has been a real inconvenience to say the least.   I travel to the rail yards in Chicago and of course they are on Central time..All my work comes from Chicago not Indianapolis..If you decide to put the county on Eastern Time it will slow my work down and harm my business..We are thriving on Central time..   A hand full of decision makers decided to take the law into their own hands and operate most of our county on Eastern time. I believe they were breaking the law..I don't believe they should be rewarded for their actions by defying your original ruling.  Please keep Pulaski County on Central time..It's good for our commerce our businesses and for all our citizens...              Thank You..              Ronald R Huff
docketTitle: Standard Time Zone Boundary in Pulaski County, Indiana
title: Ronald R. Huff

commentText: The whole issue of time in Indiana---I have lived in Knox Co. my entire life until 4 years ago.  I've always had to deal with the change in time from my county to Gibson and Vanderburgh.  It was a nightmare the entire time my children were growing up and is still a nightmare that my family still lives in Knox Co. and me in Gibson and working in Vanderburgh and attending church (church organist) in Knox.  If Indianapolis people had to put up with the difficulties we encounter here in the part of the state they would care more about this issue.  I DON'T CARE WHICH TIME WE ARE ON (prefer Central) BUT ALL OF INDIANA SHOULD BE ON THE SAME TIME!  I work in a law firm and we have MULTIPLE headaches trying to schedule hearings trials etc. (which sometimes are months/years out) because we never know what time the county our attorneys are traveling to is on.  We have had attorneys miss hearings completely be up to an hour late or hour early whichever the case may be.  Even they are confused on how to handle this problem.  When we are talking to other attorneys/courts in other counties we actually have to say "what time does your clock say right now and in such and such month what will it say."  It's ridiculous.  PLEASE put the issue up to a people in a referendum and give us the chance to make our case.  INDIANAPOLIS does not seem to care.  Mitch Daniels bullied this through our state government without asking anyone (after he campaigned that he wouldn't).  So please let the people decide.  If you let the remaining counties (Knox Daviess Pike Dubois) go back to eastern time it will be just one more hardship for our citizens to put up with.  Show us that SOMEONE in government has the sense to let the citizens decide!  Thank you.
docketTitle: Standard Time Zone Boundary in Southwest Indiana
title: Pam Harvey

commentText: We have been waiting patiently since our county commissioners filed the appeal to go to Eastern Time thinking there was not a problem with the DOT granting this request.  This request should be granted by the DOT before the spring time change.  Daviess Martin Dubois and Knox Counties need to be on Eastern Time as requested. The petition has been filed so citizens should not have to bombard you with supportive e-mail.  We were not informed it was a numbers game on this docket as was indicated with Pulaski Co.
docketTitle: Standard Time Zone Boundary in Southwest Indiana
title: Jana S. Streepy

commentText: How might customers and passengers benefit from the information covered by the NTSB recommendation in making their air-taxi service purchase decisions?There will be no benefit to passengers or customers unless the operator does not have the crew on there staff and payroll.  If the owner of the aircraft is paying the crew for most of their salary I feel operational control is lost by the operator.  The ops specs leave too much of a loop whole.  The FAA has not closed the door.  Typical and then we still have a problem. Should any notice requirement if adopted also apply to air charter brokers and other ticket agents who arrange for air transportation for air-taxi customers?NO. There are too may rules that will need to be enforced which just give legal counsel too much ammo.  To what extent is each of the notices recommended by the Safety Board already provided in the normal course of business to persons who travel on air taxis? If such notice is not currently routinely provided what if any practical difficulties would the on-demand air taxi industry likely face in providing the notice?If an operator uses an aircraft the way the rules are now that the crew is not on the payroll of the Operator then the passenger and the broker should be aware of such information.  The crew will always be loyal to who is paying his salary full time.  The occasional day pay or trip pay does not cut it.  This practice should be terminated.  If aa aircraft owner wants to charter then he should pay an operator for crew management and services.  Other than that he should stay out of the charter business.  Then we have Operation Control locked up tight.What costs if any would the recommended changes impose on the industry? Would there be any paperwork burdens? Would there be a significant economic impact on a substantial number of small entities?I am not sure of the cost but there would be time lost and I would bet in many circumstances the information would not make it to the end user as a result of the short time line that charters are initiated and run.  It is just giving someone fodder to sue because they did not get the word or info.  Then it would cost plenty and the FAA would wash there hands of the whole mess and just violate someone.How might the disclosure of the names of the owners of the aircraft involved in the arranged flights be useful to customers and passengers? What if any practical or privacy concerns would be raised by such a requirement?This is just a bad idea.  If they don't change the requirement of crew payroll status then the owner should be revealed.  If the operator haas the crew on his payroll then the owner should be able to maintain his privacy.At what point in time must any notice if required first be provided to be effective e.g. in printed and Web site advertisements to potential customers when they are seeking information anytime prior to entering into a contract upon signing the contract or anytime prior to boarding the aircraft?Again see the previous answer.  This is a bad idea.  This could have competing charter operators get involved in predatory solicitation.  We don't need this. The whole reason of the two incident causing all the furor is the lack of oversight on an already illegal operation.  Don't add morer regs.  Uphold what you have.If adopted what form should any notice requirement take? That is is verbal notice sufficient or must the notice be in writing? I don't want this to pass.  If it does then verbal would be sufficient.  If the customer claims he was not notified then too bad.  It is a he said she said.Finally what are the practical problems in requiring notice to individual passengers of an on-demand air taxi? Would any notice requirement be sufficient if provided to the person contracting for the flight e.g. the customerеХs broker/agent a corporationеХs travel department or an executiveеХs assistant who arranged the flight?Read this question yourself.  Do you not see the complications you are creating here.  Read all eight of the questions.  I don't even know where to begin to answer.  I am trying to run what wasa a simple charter operation and now has turned into a monster with all this about operational control which was not enforced and now is being readjusted.  I don't even know what I am saying.  What a mess.
docketTitle: Consumer Information Regarding On-Demand Air Taxi Operations - Advance Notice of Proposed Rulemaking
title: Aero Charter

commentText: What You Should Know About Our Service ...Travel ... what a great experience from every day life! Enjoy other countries and learn about other peoples' traditions and culture.  Careful planning and set-up of your trip is fundamental for a successful journey. We at Hibiscus Travel plan and prepare each trip according to your needs and desires whether you travel with a group as an individual or with a corporation. We are happy to assist you with any special requests. For our vision- and hearing-impaired as well as our wheelchair bound clients we provide useful information including which cruise lines or hotels are wheelchair accessible where TTY telephones are provided or where menus in Braille are offered. We look forward to booking your next trip and delivering our personal and distinct service. Hibiscus Travel is a member of:  Kerstin Fox is a member of:  TRAVEL INSURANCEWhich insurance is right for your trip? We recommend strongly that you purchase travel insurance with your trip.Be prepared in the event of an accident illness or loss of luggage when traveling.Protect yourself in case of trip cancellation. We also offer coverage for pre-existing medical conditions. Donation for Deaf Seniors of America Conference 2007The Deaf Seniors of America (DSA) is an organization created for seniors by seniors. The 9th Biennial DSA Conference took place in Orlando Florida April 9-15 2007. The local host the Palm Beach County Association of the Deaf (PBCAD) did a tremendous job to make this conference happen. It is amazing what volunteers can do if they are passionate about something. The goal was to have a wonderful one week meeting for deaf seniors and turn it into an unforgettable event.  Kerstin Fox is presenting the donation Donation Poster Indeed the PBCAD achieved this goal by offering very informative work shops lively entertainment interesting tours in Orlando and many social meetings. Our agency in cooperation with Royal Caribbean International had the pleasure of donating a 7-night Eastern Caribbean cruise for two on the brand new Liberty of the Seas. The Liberty will have her maiden voyage in May 2007. The cruise was auctioned off during the live auction during the night show the last day of the conference. The lucky bidder was a couple from Miami who soon will have the joy to go on this marvelous cruise. Congratulations! Kerstin Fox is presenting the donation DSA Thank You Letter HELP TO IMPROVE THE CRUISE EXPERIENCE FOR DEAF PASSENGERS Play Video Following up on a Supreme Court ruling in 2005 the Department of Transportation (DOT) has formally proposed to issue a new package of regulations to extend the Americans with Disabilities Act to passenger vessels including foreign-flagged cruise ships. Foreign-flagged cruise ships would only be covered when the ship picks up or discharges passengers at US ports its possessions territories or commonwealths. Foreign-flagged cruise ships would NOT be covered by those rules if the cruise does NOT pick up or discharge passengers in a US port like on a cruise in Europe or Asia. In a Notice of Proposed Rulemaking the DOT asked for industry and public comment on the plan by April 23 2007. Please submit your comments to improve the legal situation of deaf people on cruises sailing in US or international waters. WE NEED YOUR VOICE!!! The proposed rules are posted online at http://dms.dot.gov/reports/fr.htm Scroll down to the section OST. In the fourth column click on OST 2007-26829. In the next window go to the first row with the document type еТFederal Register PublicationеУ and click on PDF in the far right column. The 19 page PDF document will be opened. The first half of this document is a section by section analysis and explanation of the proposed rules. This part stretches from page 2833-2843. The second half of it is the proposed rules on page 2843-2851. To save you quite a bit of time I read all 19 pages and picked the issues that are particularly important for deaf passengers aboard a cruise ship. However I would like to encourage you to read all of the proposed rules since you might have some valuable input to make a cruise more enjoyable for the deaf in the future. Please read the following passages and submit your comments by April 23 2007: Paragraph 39.5 - analysis and explanation on page 2835 - proposed rule on page 2845 Here you have the chance for a statement that interpreter service should be provided not only on US sailings but also on all other sailings like cruises in Europe or Asia even that the cruise did not start and/or terminate in a US port. Paragraph 39.85 and 39.89 - analysis and explanation on page 2840 - proposed rule on page 2850 Here you can voice your opinion regarding closed captioning on TVs videos and in the onboard movie theater. When you are ready to submit your comments click on the Comments/Submissions button in the upper horizontal bar. On the next page go to the left box еТUnregistered UsersеУ and click on Register and follow the instructions. Please forward this message to your hearing and deaf friends and ask them for their participation. Thank you for your support. Kerstin FoxSIGN LANGUAGE INTERPRETER SERVICE FOR CRUISES As a travel agent with Hibiscus Travel I attended CLIAеХs (Cruise Lines International Association)cruise 3sixty in Ft. Lauderdale Florida last week. Events like cruise 3sixt are always a great chancefor travel agents to talk to the cruise linesеХ CEOs. Since I specialize in cruises for the deaf traveler I am well aware of the sign language interpreter problem. The ADA (Americans with Disability Act) a law that is effective in U.S. territories including U.S. waters requires that hearing impaired clients have an equal opportunity to enjoy the goods services accommodations and amenitiesoffered by places of public accommodation like a cruise ship. Furthermore effective means of communications like sign language interpreters are necessary to ensure an effective communication with deaf clients. Activities on board of the ships shows or shore excursions can not be communicated by written materialsor exchanging notes since it is not considered an effective communication for this type of entertainment.Certain cruise lines do a wonderful job providing sign language interpreter services on their cruises if requested whether the ship is sailing in U.S. waters or abroad. They provide the service for groups and single traveling passengers alike. It is a good example that providing sign language interpreter service does not cause an undue financial or administrative burden for a cruise line. Deaf clients need sign language interpreter service to equally enjoy a cruise. It is hard to understand why a service that is required by law in U.S. territories including U.S. waters is not being provided. Also to my knowledge no other minority would be denied a service that is guaranteed by law within the U.S. when those passengers go on a cruise sailing abroad. Why is it then that the deaf clients are denied interpreter service on cruises abroad?I felt obligated to address this problem with some of the cruise line CEOs present at cruise 3sixty. I asked them to establish a policy in their company that guarantees sign language interpreter service for deaf clients traveling as individuals or in groups to U.S. destinations or abroad if requested by a travel agent or the individual client. I talked to Micky Arison CEO of Carnival Corp. (member cruise lines are cruise lines like Princess Cruises Carnival Cruise Lines Costa Cruises Holland America and Cunard Line) and to Colin Veitch CEO of Norwegian Cruise Lines. Both gentlemen ask me to submit my request for sign language interpreter service in writing via e-mail. Mr. Arison explained that he will forward my request to all member cruise lines of the Carnival Corp. My request via e-mail went out to Mr. Arison and Mr. Veitch on October 4 2005. Kerstin FoxPlease contact us if you have any questions:kerstin@kerstinstravel.com
docketTitle: ADA - Passenger Vessels
title: Vicki G. Saltzman
