commentText: Comments regarding NPRM  for D.O.T. 49CFR Part 39Docket OST 2007 268299RIN 2105-AB87Transportation for Individuals With Disabilities: Passenger VesselsI Barry King am submitting these comments with regard to the impact of the proposed rule making on the operation of sailing vessels certificated as passenger vessels.  My wife and I own and operate a traditional sailing vessel the schooner Mary Day offering week long overnight adventure vacations along remote sections of the Maine coast. While I am only one vessel owner I am specifically concerned about the Maine windjammer fleet and other traditional sailing vessels at risk if the rules proposed by this docket are accepted without due regard for the historic nature of these vessels the adventure learning opportunities they provide and the role they play in tourism related activities here in the Maine.  While these rules will severely impact Maine based vessels there are dozens of vessels with ties to the Maine sailing and boatbuilding industry that will also be impacted.While no one in the world of small sailing passenger vessels would chose to discriminate against any one for any reason there are limits placed upon vessel owners and operators of small sailing passenger vessels.  Passenger safety is of paramount importance to any vessel operator.  The Maine windjammer fleet works under the careful scrutiny of the United Sates Coast Guard and maintains a remarkable safety record.  These vessels are all owner/ operated small business entities that rely on the day-to-day careful watch of each vesselеХs captain and crew to maintain a vigilant respect for the variety of people who come aboard to experience an adventure vacation.  The experiences these vessels provide are as far from a cruise ship experience as one can get.  There are no itineraries.  We take our guests to parts of the coast that most visitors ashore can only read about where islands are still wild where anchorages are largely unvisited and where respect for the wonders of our pristine environment can be discovered.  These 14 windjammers range in size from 46 feet to 132 feet and all carry less than 49 passengers on multi-day overnight voyages.  9 of these vessels are National Historic landmarks.  10 of these vessels have no inboard means of propulsion and work to the rhythm of wind and tide.  Life aboard is simple no cell phones no computers no fax machines and no hair dryers.  Each week is an unpredictable exercise in simplicity and a voyage back in time as much as it is a voyage in the present. While this docket clearly defines that all passenger vessels including еТcruise ships and ferriesеУ are subject to the requirements set forth in the ADA I donеХt believe the writers of the ADA could have foreseen how dramatically this large piece of legislation could impact this tiny еТMom and PopеУ windjammer fleet.  We are not a form of public transportation.  We provide a discretionary adventure vacation experience with no set itinerary and operate in unpredictable conditions. Many of us carry passengers with disabilities at our discretion taking into account the particular characteristics of our vessels the environment in which we operate and the disabilities of those requesting to be aboard.  To sacrifice this discretionary ability an authority granted to us and expected of us by the USCG flies in the face of everything we have ever learned as prudent mariners.  To say that these vessels can be reconfigured to adapt to passengers with disabilities is also imprudent.  These vessels have been built and rebuilt under careful USCG supervision according to accepted marine practices utilizing time honored traditional techniques.  It is no accident that Maine is where these vessels have survived and where people from around the world come to have new sailing passenger vessels built and rebuilt.  One real threat to our industry lies with the vision that if these rules pass physical accessibility standards will be adopted requiring the reconfiguration of small sailing passenger vessels and the future construction of historical American watercraft will be all but impossible. The recent multi-million dollar launchings from Maine boat yards of the newly constructed historic vessels Lynx and Godspeed in Rockport would be a thing of the past.  The current multi-million dollar rebuild of the replica vessel Bounty would be gone from the ways at Boothbay.  We need to recognize now that small sailing passenger vessels are a very unique part of the American merchant marine and have very different operating requirements.Passenger with disabilities come in many varieties and the proposed rules do not clearly define disabilities over which we might have discretion without fear of litigation and for which we will be expected to fit out our vessels and crew.  It is unrealistic to accept the notion that these financially marginal vessels can sacrifice passenger carrying capacity and incur greater operating expenses to accommodate people of all abilities.  Just as human beings have their limits; these vessels have limits as well.  And were it possible to build the perfect small sailing passenger vessel accessible to all it would not be a windjammer. The history would be gone. The wildest islands would still be inaccessible and the adventure would have to be tamed from the thrill of sailing feeling the roll of the waves and the heel of the vessel as she carried her guests away to a simpler time and a wilder place.In response to the query about whether there should be limits to the size and capacity of  vessels covered by this docket unequivocally YES!  I would recommend the limits currently being observed in the first round of the creation of physical accessibility standards.  Vessels carrying less than 150 day or 49 overnight passengers should be exempted.  This would cover most if not all sailing vessels operating under U.S. flag.  S/S 36.21 asks if accommodating some disabilities would fundamentally alter the nature of what we do? YesеЙso let us use our discretion to carry as many disabilities as possible without jeopardizing the history the adventure the untamed nature of what we offer to our guests.  Give us the ability to limit the number of disabled guests we can accommodate (S/S 39.25). S/S 39.33 would allow guests to board without notifying me of any pre-existing conditions that could potentially put at risk all guests and crew.  We donеХt ask guests for their medical history but surely I need some recourse when I discover I have a suicidal schizophrenic aboard.  S/S 39.61 asks if floating docks need different treatment.  When the tidal range is in excess of 12 feet you bet.  S/S 39.91 discusses service animals (seeing eye dogs) and all the care they require a situation not feasible abaord a 46 foot schooner?   I could go on section by section but I hope my point is clear.  Small passenger vessels cannot be expected to meet the letter of this NPRM. The intent of any vessel owner and operator is to carry as many passengers as feasible and to comply with the intent of the ADA where possible.  No operator wants to turn away anyone including a person with a disability.  But the DOT and the ADA must recognize there are feasibility and operational restrictions.   While this DOT NPRM offers the opportunity for waivers upon application relief from undue burdens recognizes some disabilities as еТdirect threatsеУ to passenger safety and mentions еТhistoricеУ vessels in the context of physical standards this docket also makes the assumption that these rules will еТnot create significant added burdensеУ and еТwould have very low costs.еУ  In response to the query as to whether there is a need for review of еТsmall entity-related issuesеУ I believe a thorough review of our operations needs to be conducted by the SBA.  While the DOT does еТnot expect any significant economic impactsеУ I do!  I would be glad to bring representatives of our industry together with DOT and SBA representatives to review this docket and explain in detail the impacts it will have on our industry.  The only DOT financial impact studies I have found record of are over 10 years old and no one in the world of small sailing passenger vessels that I have met has any knowledge of where the DOT came up with it $30000 estimate.  We could not revamp our dockside facilities which we do not even own for that price tag.  Please keep in mind that most of the Maine windjammer fleet operates only 4 months of the year because of navigation limits set by our CG Certificates of Inspection.  That reduces our income generating capacity to one quarter of that of a year round vessel operation that can migrate with the seasons or is permanently based in warmer climates.In closing I ask that the DOT recognize small sailing passenger vessels for the unique vessels they are.  These are not cruise ships or ferries and cannot be expected to conform to the same rules.  Respectfully submittedCaptain Barry KingPresident Penobscot Windjammer CompanyOwner/Operator Schooner Mary Day
docketTitle: ADA - Passenger Vessels
title: Barry P. King

commentText: OST-2007-26829Our Lake George Steamboat Company offers sightseeing tours every day for six months of each year with 3 boats whose capacity ranges from roughly 300 to 1000.We offer the following comments on the proposed rule entitled еТTransportation for Individuals with Disabilities: Passenger VesselsеУ.We agree with the comments posted on April 19 2007 by Tennessee Riverboat.  Our company too has always done everything we could in order to accommodate all types of passengers.  I personally also agree and understand as an Occupational Therapist with over 20 years experience working with neurologically involved clients that all limitations of function cannot be overcome especially by a small company with limited resources.  In the Discussion area Background:It is stated that this will apply to vessels with a capacity of over 150 passengers.  Depending upon the age of the passenger boat and its configuration some of the proposed rules will be very difficult to implement on our boats.Subpart A Section 39.3:Your suggested definition of a еФcommon wheelchairеХ is еТsuch a device which does not exceed 30 inches in width and 48 inches in length measured two inches above the ground and does not weigh more than 600 pounds when occupied.еУIf the еТcommon wheelchairеУ as defined above was all we were asked to accommodate we would be happy.  However we are seeing more passengers coming in extra wide wheelchairs (which measure more than 30еУ) and in scooters (which weigh more than 600 pounds when occupied).  We have also had passengers brought on board in reclining wheelchairs or Barco loungers (more than 48еУ in length when reclined).  Any device more than еТcommon wheelchairеУ as defined in your draft will require that the passenger in the device actually takes up more than еТone passenger spaceеУ.  In fact a reclining wheelchair ends up taking at least 3 additional dining spaces (behind and on the sides).  These additional spaces we cannot put other paying customers into and we cannot charge the passenger in the wheeled device.Subpart B Section 39.25: еТAs a PVO you must not limit the number of passengers with a disability on your vesselеУ.  Our boat configuration will not allow unlimited passengers in wheelchairs or scooters in the dining room as we must factor in emergency access pathways waitstaff lanes for serving food etc.  Our table configuration must be changed (extra space provided between the tables etc.) when we need to accommodate someone in a reclining wheelchair or an extra wide wheelchair.  Section 39.33:  еТAs a PVO you must not require a passenger with a disability to provide advance notice of the fact that he or she is traveling on or using a passenger vessel.еУ  There are specific accommodations for which advance notification is needed in our business.  As above our tables must be moved to accommodate larger mobility vehicles; our passenger capacity decreases as we accommodate these vehicles (due to boat deck configuration).  If we do not have notification in advance we may simply not have the ability to change things after other passengers are boarded and seated at their dining tables.  The only table left once most of the other customers are seated might be the table that cannot be physically reached by a passenger with a mobility device that requires a wider travel lane or large turning radius. This is not easily understood by the passenger whom we cannot accommodate.  Their travel plans might not allow them to wait until the next cruise or come back the next day etc.  Section 39.37: еТmust not require that a passenger with a disability travel with another person as a condition of being provided transportationеУ with the following situations excepted: a) a passenger mentally cannot comprehend safety instructions b) is unable to assist in his or her own emergency evacuation from the vessel c) is unable communicate with boat personnel on safety information or d) is unable to perform personal tasks.  What if the caregiver for such an individual determines that they are capable of caring for 3 or 4 such passengers and then one of the passengers requires complete assistance with toileting leaving the other 2-3 passengers completely unattended?  Are we allowed to require an attendant with each?  If we do not know in advance how are we to provide crew to be designated as the еТpersonal or safety assistant role in such a caseеУ?Section 39.53:  The requirement for a TTY service on information and reservation services is overly burdensome. Many other technologies are used instead.  People making reservations from home are typically on their computers and if adaptation for visually impairment or mobility impairment is required it has already been done.  I think this accommodation is best done at the consumerеХs computer level.Subpart E: Accessibility of Vessels:It concerns us that this section is not thought out prior to some of the other requirements in these proposed rules as the other requirements clearly deal with accessibility.As stated previously there are certain inherent shape issues with a boat as compared with a square empty room.  There are also requirements from Coast Guard and other governmental agencies dealing with passenger vessel safety emergency situations fire etc. which must be complied with before a single passenger sets foot on board.Subpart F Section 39.83: (a) states еТyou must not require such a passenger with a disability [who can readily get on or off a passenger vessel without assistance] to accept assistance from you in getting on or off the vessel.еУThe boat company would be the one involved in litigation should a passenger think he or she could disembark safely contrary to the trained crewеХs determination and come to harm.Yet (b) states that the PVO еТmust promptly provide assistance that ensures that the passenger can get on or off the vessel.еУHow is this determination to be made еР between the passenger who is еТnot able to get on or off a passenger vessel without assistanceеУ and one who can еТreadily get on or off a passenger vessel without assistanceеУ?** Also the Discussion has comments about emergency situations but the proposed rules do not.Section 39.89:  In the Discussion section the Department seeks comments on any special accommodations for getting safety information communicated to persons with cognitive disabilities.  As an Occupational Therapist I think it would be impractical to say any special accommodations should occur beyond what is already done and what is provided for any member of the general public or child or older person.  If the passenger has a cognitive disability of any significance there should be a caregiver with this passenger one on one in order to ensure that passengerеХs safety.Section 39.9: Service animals.This is an area of concern as people do want to bring their pets on board.  If our company is required to take the еТcredible verbal assurances of a passenger with a disability using the animalеУ we will have problems.  First of all we cannot ask a person if they are disabled now we are required to believe their assurances that they need the animal. This could easily turn into a person claiming to need an animal that was indeed only a pet for help with a pretend disability.  How do we accommodate other passengers on that same cruise who have allergies to dog hair or are terribly afraid of animals?Subpart G Section 39.101:  Complaints Resolution officials.We are a relatively small company with many cruises.  I have many years experience as an Occupational Therapist working with clients with neurological diagnoses (adult and children).  еТTraining to proficiencyеУ as described in your Discussion (p.2842) еТincluding how to distinguish among the differing abilities of individuals with a disabilityеУ would be not an easy job.  I think certifying the training or drafting a training curriculum would be quite difficult and actually unnecessary.  Cannot you just recommend minimal common courtesy and sensitivity from both sides: the passenger with a disability and the passenger vessel personnel who make our living by being accommodating to the public (with disabilities or without old or young etc.)One last comment about your Discussion on p. 2842.  You state that this NPRM does not impose significant costs.  For our situation it would most definitely have an economic impact as described previously in the situation of the dining area taken up by extra large wheelchairs etc.  By these rules we would not be allowed to know a large number of passengers needing wheelchairs were coming we would not be allowed to limit the numbers at the same time that we were losing several seats in the effort to accommodate the wheelchair and we would not be allowed to charge for the seats lost.You state that the NPRM focuses on prohibiting unnecessary practices eliminating policies that prevent or inhibit travel by persons with disabilities.  Yet it seems to cover far more than that and it seems to add an economic burden to those of us who are smaller.Our company is already accommodating people in the best way we can.  We added wheelchair lifts to two of our boats in order to allow more access (adding one required adding an additional 34еХ to the center of the boat еР not an easy task!).  This was not mandated we did it to provide service to our customers.  To require more indeed to require the same sort of accommodation from us as from large corporations running large cruise ships is overly burdensome.In your Discussion p. 2843 the Small Business Administration size standards are mentioned (i.e. under 500 employees is a small business entity).  This is a good standard for determining that a company doesnеХt have the resources of a large corporation or cruise line and therefore should not be subjected to these proposed rules (especially the ones such as Sections 39.25 39.37 39.53 and others requiring definite economic outlay in terms of additional employees handouts to customers etc.)
docketTitle: ADA - Passenger Vessels
title: Lake George Steamboat Company

commentText: The concept of overbooking originated when reservations were made by phone with no obligation to pay.  Now all reservations must be paid in full.  If I pay for a seat and I fail to show that seat is still paid for.  To resell the paid seat is just plain greed.  To then deny another person his paid seat is the epitome of gluttony.  How can this possibly be legal?!  If a cruise line theater or any other reserved seat venue followed this practice there would be lawsuits.  I strongly request that the airlines pay the maximum penalty for their voracity еР a minimum of double the cost of any ticket plus any and all expenses incurred by delay of travel.
docketTitle: Air Transport Association of America, Inc. - Petition for Rulemaking
title: William Haderer

commentText: HiI would like to suggest that all of the options presented in docket OST-01-9325 ("increasing the $200 compensation limit to $624 and the $400 limit to $1248; increasing the compensation limits to $290 and $580 respectively; doubling the compensation limits to $400 and $800; eliminating all compensation limits and making compensation equal to the value of the ticket with the payment doubling for longer delays; or leaving the current limits in place.") are too limited.  However amongst those options I like the $624/$1248 option the best."Eliminating all compensation limits and making compensation equal to the value of the ticket with the payment doubling for longer delays" should only be done if the value of the reference ticket is calculated as (not the value of your purchased ticket but) the cost of the most expensive fare in your class of travel for your specific flight(s).  When you purchased your ticket you traded off flexibility for a cheaper price; the airline traded a lower fare for some guaranteed revenue.  Since they "cheated" (breaking their end of your contract once they realized that they had underestimated demand for your specific flight) and overfilled the flight they should have to give involuntarily bumped passengers money based upon the true value of their ticket at the time of the involuntary bumping.  This rule should specifically include "frequent flier" miles tickets and those tickets from "opaque" booking sites (Priceline hotwire etc) but could reasonably exclude "employee (reduced) travel" tickets or "standby" type tickets.  Double this compensatin amount for each 4 hours of a delay.  Passengers would have the right to refuse this cash compensation still be transported to their destination on an alternate flight and could then bring a case in small claims court to recover actual damages (a missed cruise etc) based upon the airline breaching of contract.Business airline tickets can routinely top $800 depending on the city pairs and advance booking time yet the current involuntary booking compensation limit is still $200/$400.  I would ideally suggest that a better option would be for the airline in an involuntary bump situation to have to compensate each affected passenger $100 cash for every hour (or fraction thereof) that the passenger is late getting to their final destination (based upon published schedules and whichever flights you are reprotected on at no charge) with no cap.  A 50% discount could apply if the airline gets you to your destination within 2 hours of your original arrival time.  This would encourage airlines to minimize delays to affected passengers in a very substantial way while still allowing them to make money by overselling a flight to a high-fare passenger and getting the (presumably lower fare) involuntarily bumped passenger to their destination quickly and with fair compensation for their (hopefully short) time inconvienance.With the increase in regional jet and propeller fliying by the major airlines these rules should also apply to commuter airlines of at least 30 seats.  If the airline chooses to run a smaller plane for any reason the involuntary bumping rules should still apply (the airline still broke its end of the contract and should not be able to cherry pick the highest fares for travel without compensation to the distressed passengers).Thanks you for taking the time to read my comments.
docketTitle: Air Transport Association of America, Inc. - Petition for Rulemaking
title: Douglas L. Friday

commentText: Bumping passengers is a violation of the contract between the airline and the passenger. The passenger pays for a service and makes plans depending on that service being performed. Contrary to air traffic disruptions poor weather terrorist attacks and similar events bumping is fully under the airline's control so there is no justification for this violation of a passenger's right to a service. Airlines' claim that they need to be able to bump passengers in order to make up for "no-shows" is bogus: they could simply charge the no-shows. They choose not to. So they should be responsible for missed revenues and they should not be allowed to make up for missed revenues by violating other passengers' right to a service that has been paid in full.The only adequate rule in response to airline bumping is to make bumping illegal and to hold airlines liable in court for any damage to passengers that ensues directly or indirectly from bumping. Limited monetary reimbursement (often inferior to the airfare itself) is by no means sufficient to compensate passengers. In all other fields a company who accepts payment is then obliged to perform in accordance to contract unless prevented by factors beyond its control. There is no legal or moral reason to make an exception for airlines. As one of so many travelers victims of airlines prevarication I ask you to make bumping illegal and to make airlines liable in court for damages if they bump passengers.
docketTitle: Air Transport Association of America, Inc. - Petition for Rulemaking
title: Francesca di Poppa

commentText: As a person who travels for three different types of companies with over 70+ stores my time is valuable.  Instead of bumping me off my flight and putting me on another one that is four hours later put me on a different airline.  So wether I am flying airline A and I get bumped put me with airline B and I will be a happy camper.  This way I am happy and get to my destination airline is happy because their customer service does not hae to deal with an irate customer and chances are that this new airline I fly with will appeal to me more than the other free enterprise and all that.
docketTitle: Air Transport Association of America, Inc. - Petition for Rulemaking
title: Amy

commentText: To whom it may concern:  Once again the people of Indiana are being run over roughshod.  The facts are that the longitude meridians mark the center of time zones in the U.S.  Upon looking at a map of North America one can clearly see that Indiana is firmly in the Central time zone.       The DOT is interested in how time zones effect commerce.  Commerce is effected by the people who are employed by businesses. Two of the largest businesses in Dubois County are Kimball and MasterBrand Cabinets.  Both of these companies have plantscustomers and vendors worldwide.  Both of these companies therefore have people working for them 24 hours a day.       The people of Dubois County want to be on Central time.  On Eastern time the sun would rise in July about 6:40 am and set about 9 pm.  If one is outside until 9 PM and has to be at work by 6:30 AM one cannot get the recommended 8 hours of sleep per night. This lack of sleep has been shown to cause problems with memory loss and lack of good decision skills.Government services are part of economic impact.  Many of the regional offices of the federal government for Indiana are in Chicago. This includes the U.S. Department of Justice and the 7th Circuit Court of Appeals. The U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development has its Region V office in Chicago as well.Personally I propose that you force the rest of Indiana to change to Central Time the natural time for our state.  However since that is unlikely I hope that you will stay with your first correct judgement and leave Dubois County in the Central Time zone.  Finally I would like to point out that those of us who played by the rules preferred Central Time.  Why is it that these bullies and whiners who did not get their way are now allowed to come back and change the rules?  Is that the American Way?
docketTitle: Standard Time Zone Boundary in Southwest Indiana
title: Melissa G. Lingwall Swartz

commentText: I live in Shoals Martin County IN.  When Martin County converted to Central Time it affected the children at the Community School because the vocational school the high school children attend is in Lawrence County IN which is on Eastern Time.  I use the Louisville KY and Indianapolis Airports which are on Eastern Time because the flights out of and in to the Evansville Airport in the Central Time Zone are more expensive and/or do not service my points of destination.  I have clients who live in Lawrence and Orange Counties and the time difference has created substantial scheduling problems.  I am an attorney and work in several different counties.  The time differences create a conflict and at times I am forced to reschedule court hearings. Often times I am unable to work on cases in the late afternoons because the courts and attorney offices located in the Eastern Time Zone close one to two hours before my office closes. Most of our family members reside in the Eastern Time Zone.  This causes problems when trying to communicate or set up family get togethers.  Our family uses physicians and dentists located in the Eastern Time Zone - again scheduling problems arise.  Shoals is a rural community with few if any stores.  It is much closer for us to drive to Bedford or Bloomington to shop than it is to go to Evansville.  Again however our lifestyles have become complicated by trying to get to the stores and restaurants before they close.  I vote for Eastern Time Zone for Martin County.  My life is complicated enough without having to deal with who's in what time zone or calculating how many hours need to be added or subtracted for travel time to reach my destination on time.
docketTitle: Standard Time Zone Boundary in Southwest Indiana
title: Lynne Ellis

commentText: Caps on passenger compensation for involuntary re-scheduling due to overbooking should be eliminated leaving the airline liable and exposed to litigation from the passenger for compensation for whatever damages they caused to the passenger. A confirmed ticket is a contractual agreement. Default on a contract and you are liable for whatever damages you caused tangible or not. No re-scheduling time rules should remain. Who is to say how much damage a passenger incurs as a function of delay time elapsed. There is no acceptable delay time that exempts either party from defaulting on a contract. If the passenger is late on arriving at the gate is the passenger re-booked on another flight at no expense? How late can the passenger be without incurring cancellation of her ticket? In overbooking the airline is willfully breaking a contract and therefore liable. Let the airlines figure out how to avoid liability: compensation for voluntary re-booking no overbooking ... it is not the passengerеХs problem. She purchased a ticket and entered into a contract that must be respected by both parties.
docketTitle: Air Transport Association of America, Inc. - Petition for Rulemaking
title: Ever J. Barbero

commentText: Airlines should NEVER be allowed to "overbook" the seats on a flight. If any other industry did that sort of thing they would be hauled into court for breach of contract consumer fraud and probably half a dozen other things.  I would like to recommend the following plan as one fair to all travelers and one which would still allow the airlines to maximize their profits:  Instead of over-booking flights and thereby misleading all passengers into a false sense of security with regard to their travel arrangements once all seats on a plane have been booked airlines should be allowed to sell "space available" tickets at full-fare prices.  The space-available ticket purchaser(s) should then be put on a "stand-by" list based on the time they purchased their tickets and told up-front that the flight was full and what their position was on the stand-by list. In fact a space-available ticket holder could be put on "stand-by" lists of all flights to his/her destination leaving over a 48 hour period if he/she so agreed. Under this plan everyone holding a regular ticket would be given a boarding pass FIRST and space-available ticket holders would get any remaining seats. Those holding space-available tickets would know from the outset that there was a chance that they would not be able to board a particular flight but that in the event no seat could be found for them on that flight or on a slightly later but still acceptable flight their full ticket price (minus PERHAPS a very small handling fee - but this should never be more than about $25) would be refunded as soon as the last flight for which they were on stand-by took off without them.No one would ever have to be involutarily bumped.  The only people who might not get to fly would be those who had waited until the last moment to purchase tickets and they would have no cause for complaint because they would have been told ahead of time the conditions of their space-available ticket.  No matter how badly someone needs to fly somewhere they have no cause to complain if there simply are no tickets available.  But when someone makes plans and purchases a ticket weeks (or even months) in advance in order to be in a certain place at a certain time but then get bumped because the airline oversold the flight and winds up missing the very event they were planning to attend being refunded the value of the bumped portion (up to a max of $400 - which might not even cover its cost) just doesn't begin to compensate for the harm they have suffered! For example if a man purchases a $1000 ticket to so he can attend a special sporting event in a distant city and then gets bumped off his flight and can't go until the next day the entire flight is now worthless to him - and he has also wasted whatever money he spent to purchase the sporting event ticket and possibly lost the value of a motel room as well.  A $400 refund is a slap in the face!  The fact that people remain angry about such events for years into the future ought to be evidence enough that such "involuntary bumping" is simply wrong and deceitful.  No other business would be able to stay in business if they treated their customers that way.  Airlines should not be allowed to get away with it either.  "Voluntary bumping" on the other hand should be allowed to continue. Since everyone engages in it voluntarily it doesn't hurt anyone and can even be a helpful.  I can see no reason whatsoever however why the airlines even need to be "involved" in such voluntary transactions.  In the event that more people want to fly that there are seats on a plane passengers holding a boarding pass should be free to negotiate directly with space-available ticket holders and even swap tickets with them if they desire. (e.g. "Sure I've got a regular ticket to on this flight and I can hang around another day or so. Pay me $200 cash and you can have my seat on this flight and I'll take your space-available ticket and hope to get on a later flight out... or if I don't I can cash in your space-available ticket for the full-fare amount you paid and catch a bus to whereever I need to go." OR "You say your mother is dying and you need to get to Chicago right away oh you poor dear you go ahead and take my ticket and I'll take your place in the space-available queue... no no you don't have to pay me any extra... you've got enough to worry about.") For security's sake (and I suppose to keep people from scalping airline tickets if that is a concern)  it might make sense to ensure that such free-market transactions took place only at the boarding gate and only between regular ticket holder and space-available ticket holders.  The only thing airlines really need to do is make an announcement that there are space-available passengers looking to arrange a deal and that anyone interested in negotiating with them should step over to a particlar area.  Once deals are made both passengers involved would go together to the ticket counter to arrange for the names on the tickets to be swapped out.Under the plan outlined above airlines don't need to lose any money and nobody EVER gets shafted. Airlines can still do their thing with regard to adjusting ticket prices to maximize profits - they just can't do it at the expense of someone they have already agreed (i.e. CONTRACTED WITH) to carry for a given price.
docketTitle: Air Transport Association of America, Inc. - Petition for Rulemaking
title: Beverly J. Angel

commentText: An efficient system for compensating passengers for overbooked flights would assign a dollar value to true costs related to the missed flight itself. The current system is an attempt at this with fixed compensation to passengers. While on average the current payment system may be less than sufficient compensation or perhaps more it largely absolves airlines of the true cost to an individual passenger.For instance a vacationer traveling from New York to Miami may bear a true cost of less than $200 for the inconvenience of overbooking. As a business traveler who often takes long trips both coming and going in a single day with a short window to meet with others in between flights the same delay could have a monumental cost.Using an adversarial model like arbitration or the courts as is typically used to determine financial loss and compensation in business-to-business transactions the airline would be forced to compensate me for this loss. The current system changes airlinesеХ incentives significantly encouraging them to take into account far less than the true cost of my losses.Because of the time and venue issues that would be associated with the use of courts to determine losses related to airlinesеХ behavior a system of arbitration is more desirable.Assigning to airlines the true cost of a passenger involuntarily removed from a flight would enable them to more effectively design their yield models while providing them with a market value for the cost of overbooking as an input into those models.As a practical matter since even efficient arbitration takes time involuntarily removed passengers should be offered a minimum payment such as the current $200 and $400. Beyond this they should have the right to submit written arguments to arbitrators under contract to the Department of Transportation. The airlines would have the right to reply followed by a judgment from the arbitrator. Since even the simplest arbitration process may be overly difficult for many travelers to navigate and because the losses for individual travelers (particularly vacationers) may be insufficient to bear the cost of legal counsel the system would need to allow for recognition of classes.One of the great lessons of the last 20 years is that the exposure of companies to the free market is not just that it provides benefits for consumers but that it also rationalizes corporate decision-making. The current system uses incentives that inherently create undesirable outcomes. Simply raising the compensation requirements would change very little.
docketTitle: Air Transport Association of America, Inc. - Petition for Rulemaking
title: Benjamin W. Shoval

commentText: The timezone issue in southwest Indiana is complicated...but need not be so.  Governor Daniels' decision push to place us all on DST was a good one.  However it then raised the bigger issue: which time zone will we observe 12 months per year?I grew up in Dubois County and will move there again in the spring.  I currently live with my family in Warrick County and work in Vanderburgh County.  My husband works in Dubois County.  As you can see we are one of the many families that straddle multiple counties and are greatly effected by the changes proposed.  Quite honestly we can live with any outcome.  The bigger question is "What solution brings the greatest good even knowing some will be inconvenienced?"Eastern Standard Time may not be ideal for all of Indiana.  However the reality is that 2/3 of the state (and much more of the population) is quite content with that time zone.  The Evansville region has in the past suggested that we should stay on Central because we are connected heavily to Kentucky and southern Illinois.  In fact few of our residents travel to these locations to work.  By far the flow is Kentucky and Illinois workers coming into southwest Indiana to work.  Though we appreciate their work in our state their convenience should not be placed above our own residents.I believe that Vanderburgh Warrick Posey Gibson and Spencer should join the 5 counties in southcentral Indiana in the move to EST.  There would at very least be a number of folks and companies inconvenienced by this move.  However the greater good of having all (or almost all) counties in the state observing one time would have many benefits including:  1. Stronger regionalism in southwest Indiana  2.  Better connectivity and unity to our state capitol and the rest of the state.  3.  Demonstration of a willingness to put others' preferences before our own for the greater good.Life is filled with difficult challenges.  As parents we try to teach this principle to our children.  As adults it is time for us to step up and role model this principle.Sue Ellspermann
docketTitle: Standard Time Zone Boundary in Southwest Indiana
title: Susan J. Ellspermann

commentText: As a Martin county resident we would like to see th counties remain in the Central time zone.We subscibe to the Evansville Courier and watch Evansville news channels.We also shop at Evansville often.We are more connected to the counties that have always been on Central time than to neighboring Eastern time counties. In 2005 we were told to call the court house and tell which time zone we wanted.The majority wanted Central.Most people are happy with the time zone so why do we have to go through this again?Betty Summers Loogootee
docketTitle: Standard Time Zone Boundary in Southwest Indiana
title: Betty Summers

commentText: I am definitely in favor of Central Standard Time. I would like to see the whole State of Indiana on the same time. Dr. Bob L. Doane 3718 Canyon Rock Court Evansville In. 47725
docketTitle: Standard Time Zone Boundary in Southwest Indiana
title: Anonymous

commentText: I support the proposed change for the Petitioning Counties of Daviess Dubois Knox Martin and Pike to be moved to Eastern Time.  While I live in Monroe County I work as the Public Affairs Officer at NSWC Crane which is located primarily in Martin County.  So daily my husband (who also works at NSWC Crane) and I encounter the difficulties of living in one time zone and traveling to and working on another time zone.  This impacts me personally in getting to and from work at strange hours and it always impacts me personally in that I have a grandson that my husband and I assist with who lives in Monroe County and on many occasions we need to pick him up from Day Care for our daughter who is a single mother continuing her education in order to improve her quality of life for herself and her son.  The change in time from one time zone to the other makes it difficult to get to the Day Care on time to get our grandson.I work many hours at my job and often do not get home now until about 9 or 10 pm Eastern time due to the loss of an hour when getting home.I also see the daily impacts on travelers coming to NSWC Crane (and to other activities located at Crane) for business.  They travel in to Indianapolis (on Eastern time) and then on to Crane (on Central time).  Although we explain the difference to them many times visitors are confused by the time difference either missing meetings or showing up early or late due to the change.  This causes disruption and much confusion.  We schedule many school tours at NSWC Crane throughout the year as well including an annual Science & Engineering Fair encouraging math and science.  We have schools from both time zones participating and it is difficult for the schools in the Eastern time zone to schedule and participate with the other schools.  This has caused a great deal of confusions as well.  These are just a few examples and I know there are many more and countless individuals who are sharing those stories with you.  Thank you for consideration of this change and hopefully for making this change soon!
docketTitle: Standard Time Zone Boundary in Southwest Indiana
title: Sue Webster

commentText: I have been a practicing lawyer in Tell City for over 30 years.  I have a busy private practice plus I am a part time deputy prosecutor.  My main geographical areas are Perry Spencer Dubois Warrick and Vanderburgh counties where I routinely go to court for clients.  It is much more convenient for my clients and me if all these counties were to continue on Central.  For years Perry and Dubois were on eastern for 6 months and then on central for 6 months.  It was confusing to say the least to schedule court hearings at that time.  Now with all of these counties on Central it is much more convenient and less confusing for clients to attend court hearings.  Even if Dubois is granted its request for Eastern  Perry should remain on Central from my perspective.    To reiterate the STATS Annual Commuting Trends Profile from 2005 of the 12353 who live in Perry County and work  3173 of them work outside Perry County.  The top five areas receiving workers from Perry County are Warrick County Spencer County Vanderburgh County Dubois County and Kentucky.  Only 971 of that number work in Dubois County and the remainder work in Central Time Zone areas.  Thus the vast majority of those workers work in the Central Time Zone and not the Eastern.  For their convenience we should remain on Central.     Finally I address the issue of grades K through 12 extracurricular schedules.  I had 2 children graduate from Tell City High School in the 1980's.  From 7th grade upward they were engaged in various extracurricular activities which required travel away from Perry County.  At the time Perry County was on the same time as Gibson Posey Vanderburgh Warrick and Spencer Counties from April until October. The remainder of the year Perry County was an hour ahead of those counties. Attendance at any event in those counties for the MAJORITY of the school year resulted in my children returning home one hour LATER than if all the counties were on the same time.  This caused students to study an hour later on school nights with one hour less sleep on those nights.  This was not a good situation for the students.  Presently Perry County is on the same time as those counties which is Central.  For those Perry County students who now have to travel to schools in the Eastern zone  while it is still inconvenient they will return home an hour EARLIER than the situation my children faced.  They will not lose the one hour on those evenings and it is in the best interest of all of our students in Perry County to remain on Central.
docketTitle: Standard Time Zone Boundary in Southwest Indiana
title: James G. Tyler

commentText: I am writing to support returning Dubois County to the Eastern Time Zone.  My wife and I own a small costume rental business.  The majority of our customers currently live in the Eastern Time Zone.  Also the majority of our suppliers are also in the Eastern Time Zone.  Since Dubois County was placed on Central Time we have seen a significant drop in business due to our customers not being able to get here at a reasonable time for them.  We also have seen a drop in business due to the fact that since we are on a different time zone than most of our suppliers it is very difficult for us to place special orders at the right time of day to get next day delivery.If we remain on Central Time there is a strong likely hood that we may go out of business.  I sincerely hope that you will return Dubois County to Eastern time before small business like ours are forced out of business!SincerelyDavid and Mary Sue Boeglin
docketTitle: Standard Time Zone Boundary in Southwest Indiana
title: Fun Time Costumes & More

commentText: It appears that if the DOT does make the decision to take these counties to Eastern that they will be revisiting this in a few years.  It is clear that a large part of the population wants to remain on Central Time and half of the Eastern Time Supporters believe we are not going to observe DST anymore.  We warned the DOT of this but apparently they chose not to listen.  Changing are counties will cause havoc with lawsuits of school times to lighting at bus stops.  The cause will go from the executive branch to the Judicial Branch so that maybe they will look out for the health and safety of the TRANSPORTATION of our children.  People will stay away from the businesses who would rather see our children in harms way rather then make the necessary changes to accomodate the time diffences with a few suppliers.  It is a sure thing that the commissioners will not be around for long and then we will use the accurate information that shows these counties belong on Central Time.  PLEASE GO OFF THE FACTS AND NOT THE OPPINIONS.  WE DO NOT ALL NEED TO BE ON THE SAME TIME.  WE NEED TO BE ON THE SAME TIME OF WHAT HELPS OUR OWN COUNTY OUT.  PLEASE KEEP KNOX COUNTY ON CENTRAL TIME WITH ITS NEEREST CONSUMER LAWRENCE COUNTY ILL.
docketTitle: Standard Time Zone Boundary in Southwest Indiana
title: Timothy P. Joyce

commentText: I would like Pike County to move back to Eastern Time.
docketTitle: Standard Time Zone Boundary in Southwest Indiana
title: Sue

commentText: I would prefer that Dubois County IN stay on the Central time zone.
docketTitle: Standard Time Zone Boundary in Southwest Indiana
title: Sue B. Habig

commentText: I am sick of  trying to decide what time I have to leave Crane to go to a doctors appointment.  I leave Crane at 3:30 drive 30 minutes and get home at 5:00 and I hate it every day.  Surely the state of Indiana can be on one time.  If Evansville and some of the counties close to Louisville KY want to be on KY time give those counties to the state of Kentucky and be done with it.
docketTitle: Standard Time Zone Boundary in Southwest Indiana
title: Sue Riester

commentText: TIME ZONE SUMMATIONThe time zone situation in SW Indiana has been a much debated subject since the Summer of 2005.Each of the five counties held time zone hearings.Im Martin county the commissioners had three and invited representatives from NSA Crane to come and none did.Many citizens of the five counties called into local court houses to vote on time zone preference and also attended the meetings in their local counties.The general feeling amongst the residents of the counties was that Cenatral time would be the best time zone for the five counties.The commissioners then voted to proceed in that direction.Originally the DOT did not include MartinDaviessand Dubois in the NPRM in 2005 to move along with KnoxPikeand Perry counties to Central.Upon further submissions of convenience of commerce evidence for these countiesa DOT time hearing in November of 2005 in Jasper Indiana in which local officials spoke of the need to be in the same time zone as each others county and the Evansville region to the south which was currently on Central time andlastly a reccomendation by Governor Daniels asking that the SW region of Indiana not be seperated since it is a "NATURAL REGION" the DOT moved the five counties to Central time on January 172006.Stating in their final ruling what we in the six counties which is mainly rural have more in common with each others counties and the Central time region to the South than any counties we border on Eastern time.Our counties are in the same econmoiceducation and workforce developement regions designated by Indiana.This was the correct decision by the DOT.   Almost immediately the Crane Employee Association having figured out they would have the majority of their employees in a different time zone cried foul.A representative for this Association showed up at a Martin county commissioners meeting in early February saying the NSA Crane would be hurt observing Central timea time zone Crane had been in line with the majority of the year for decades but still this was the Crane Employee Associations position.The Crane Employee Association ran letters to the editor in the Loogootee Tribune and Shoals News in Martin county to get inconvenienced citizens to pressure local commissioners for new time zone meetings.After accomplishing this a new time zone hearing was had at the 4-H building in which many Eastern time county Crane employees came to and some local citizens.The est crowd was around 300 at this meeting most were not from Martin county.Martin county has a population of around 10000 people.Hardly a GROUNDSWELL FOR EASTERN TIME".Martin county commissioner Mike Dant spoke to the NSA Crane commander and asked if the base would function alright on Central time in a sense he was asking would Central time hurt NSA Crane.The commander replied no.Indeed it has not hurt Crane.Central time has caused personal inconveniences for the majority of Crane's Eastern time employees but many have flex scheduling and all have a liberal leave policymuch better than private sector employees.Since more cross time zone boundary commuters will be burdened if the boundary is moved again especially to Toyota employees and the DOT noted this in the NPRM that the commuter numbers do not support a time zone change the boundary should stay where it is at currently.Crane employees are no more important than the employees form the five counties who commute to the original Central time zone or those from that region who commute to our five counties.Indeed this number is greater so it makes no sense to burden the majority of commuters to appease the minority.We have around 3400 citizens in our five counties commuting south to the original Central time zone and less than a 1000 commuting to the current Eastern time counties.These numbers speak for themselves.Martin county ended up voting to re-petition for Eastern time but no action would be taken until they found out what Dubois county would do.entries fill this docket about the Dubois county re-petition process and the intimidation and coersion tactics used against Central time supporting commissioner John Burger until he cahnged his vote to Eastern making the vote in Dubois county 2-1 for Eastern time.The rest of the counties then fell in line with the Eastern time position and the process started.The law firm Ice Miller LLP out of Indianapolis was hired to drive the Joint Petition through.They made their first filing last August.The documentation was weakinaccurateand misleading and was easily picked apart by the pro-Central time people who do their research and work on this issue after they get home from work and on weekendes.However Central time supporters have one advantage over Ice Miller LLP which is that they live in the region.There is no need for me to expand on the numerous Ice Miller errors for they are all documented in rebuttal documentation which is on this docket.The DOT cited regional connections in it's January 172006 ruling.CONVENIENCE OF COMMERCE EVIDENCE WHICH SUPPORTS CENTRAL TIMEHEALTHCARE AND HOSPITALS in the region including close by specialists in Evansville all support the region remainiong on Central time.MAJOR NEWSPAPER in the region is the Evansville Courier which dwarfs the Indianpolis Star in circulation in the five counties and contrary to the assertions of Ice Miller LLP does cover manymany events and news stories on the five petitioning counties.Scanned articles have been submitted to the DOT to show this to be true.COMMUTER NUMBERS As stated by the DOT in the NPRM the commuter numbers do not support a time zone change for the five counties.CELL PHONE SERVICE This is provided for the five counties out of Evansville and if the five counties are moved to Eastern time will cause a incinvenience because free minutes which are available at 9:00pm Central would then not be available until 10:00pm Eastern in the five counties.LOCAL SCHOOL CORPORATIONS There are fifteen school systems in the five counties and only a few have even bothered to submit for wanting to return to Eastern time.The Loogootee school system in their part of the Joint Petition mainly just wants to be in line with the other five counties which they are already.Mentioned by the Loogootee Superintindent is that the teachers are split in this school system about time zone preference.The Shoals school system in Martin county because it sends a grand total of 15 students to a vocational school in Lawrence county complains of a inconvenience because of this but the adjustments have been made and every student is managing to get to school on time.The Jasper school corporation which by the way is a member of the BIG EIGHT ATHLETIC CONFERNCE all untied in the Central time zone which will be split up if the bounday is moved causing a inconvenience in school athletic events states bascially they have education meetings in Indianapols a few times a year and because of the time zone difference these personnel attending have to stay overnight because they can not possibly get up at 4:30am to drive to Indianapolis.They should tell that to all the working people of SW Indiana many of whom get up that early every day.A study of all 15 school corporations atheltic activity of boys basketball which is the most attended by Mr.Rocky Byrd who did a COMPLETE breakdown not just five schools like Ice Miller LLP used shows the least inconvenience is for the five counties 15 school systems to reamain in the Central time zone.This submission is available on this docket.FACILITIES OF HIGHER EDUCATION The facilities most available to the residents of SW Indiana are Vincennes University(Knox county)Vincennes University Jasper Center(Dubois county)Oakland City University(Gibson county)University of Evansville(Evansville)University of Southern Indiana(Evansville)Ivy Tech(Evansville).Many students from Sw Indiana as well as western Kentucky and Illinois can easily commute to these schools.They are all currently in the Central time zone.So I ask the DOT why seperate them? Also two new Manufacturing Technology schools will be built in Dubois and Gibson counties which will be seperated if the time zone boundary is moved again.ECONMOIC PARTNERSHIPSThe five re-petitioning counties are all in the same economic region and in point of fact are located in the Evansville commerce region.They are also in Bureau of Economic Analysis region 54 designated the Evansville Kentucky region.These counties also have formed specail pacts with several counties in the original Central time counties to their south.Much has been made by the Westgate Crane Tech Park especially by several of the members who are on that board and have submitted to this docket and that most people believe stand to gain from this venture.The Tech Park is located in three counties MartinDavieesand Greene.Most of the developement so far has been in Martin and Daviess counties.This venture will add very little in the way of jobs for Martin and Daviess counties.One look at the Crane employees and where which counties they reside in will show the DOT this.The Tech Park will be the same way meaning most of it's employees will be from MonroeGreeneand Lawrence counties.Indded like the Crane base employees these people will pay property taxesshop and conduct business in their home counties.They will not be doing business in loogooteeShoalsor Washington or residing here.They never have and never will.The only gain martin and Daviess counties will ever see from this developement is possibly down the road some taxes from the property and that will be it.A newspaper article sometime back highlighted the fact that this venture will create around 700 jobs and as I stated the majority of these people will not come from Martin and Daviess counties.So while the Wesgate Crane Tech Park overall is a alright thing for the area it is no reason to change a time zone boundary.The buildings are being built and everything is proceeding.CLOSEST MAJOR AIRPORT The closest major airport to the five counties is Evansville and now that they will be offering connecting flights to Indianapolis this should satisy the convenience of commerce issue reagrding this situation.Very few everyday citizens from these five counties fly regularly.The business people from Dubois county from the major comapnies have company planes so this issue is resolved in my mind.FROM WHERE DOES THE REGION GET IT'S SUPPLIES OR PRODUCTSAccording to the Joint Petition just less than half of these supplies or products comes from other than the Eastern time zone.WHERE DOES THE REGION EXPORT IT'S PRODUCTS According to the Joint Petition two-thirds of the products exported goes to other than the Eastern time zone.Neither of the afore mentioned statements regardin imports and exports supports a time zone change.BUS AND RAIL SERVICE In my mind this issue has no importance to this rural region.It would in Washington D.C. or another major city but not here.RECREATION The biggest draw in this region and for the state for that matter is Holiday World in Spencer county.It's president supports Central time and many of it's employees would be burdened with a time zone change.This business receives over one million visitors annually and grosses near forty million dollars.The French Lick Casino argued by Ice Miller LLP in the Joint Petition is a 24hr a day seven day a week entity.Time zone is of no importance.Paoli Peaks also cited by Ice Miller is able to operate effectively apprx three months a year.Patoka Lake is a destination if studied would show most visitors to this park and lake will come from the Central time zone since to the northsouthand west of this area the immediate counties are all on Central time.Fishing tournament participants if from the Eastern time zone can simply make allownaces in their schedules since I am sure that is what participants from the Central time regions have done all these years in the five months they were not in line with our counties.Also if one just wants to go to a casino to gamble Casino Aztar in Evansville is very close by if one wants to be on the same time as their home countyalthough why this is a issue is beyond me since the French Lick casino and resort is open 24 hrs a day seven days a week.Travelers Workers from Carne going on travel contary to what they assert do not leave from Crane base which is on Central time when they go on travel.My relation works at Crane and travels frequently for Crane.These are planned trips and they leave from there home and since the majority of Cranes employees reside in the Eastern time zone if they choose to fly out of Indianapolis there is no problem.As for business travler coming to Crane and flying into Indianpolis being inconvenienced or not knowing what time it is or what time zone Crane is in.Somehow I suspect most of these people fly all over the United States even to states like Kentucky and Tennessee which have split time zones.I am sure eduacted people plan there trip in advance and adjust themselves to the time zone whether in a state with a split time zoneCentralEasternMountainor Pacific time.The argumet these travlers to Carne from out of state are some confused clueless group of people never has added up.TV STATIONS When taken as a whole this group of counties receives the majority of it's TV signals from Evansville.We have three Evansville stations in Loogootee which I and others have listed numerous times to this docket and we are the farthest northeastern county near the time zone boundary.However if someone prefers a Terre Haute news cast we have these availbale for residents at convenient times so they will not miss them contrary to what some on this docket have asserted.There is a 5:00pm and 6:00pm Central time Terre Haute news cast as well as 9:00pm and 10:00pm Terre Haute news casts in Martin county.The best severe weather reporting hands down comes from WEHT channel 25 Evansville AMS certified meterologist Wayne Hart.They will interupt programing for extended periods of time to track severe storms in this are.a few years ago a NEXRAD Dopplar radar site was constructed in Gibson county.The NPRM by the DOT noted the TV station informatyion was insufficient to support a time zone change.RADIO SIGNAlS The best radio signal strength comes from stations within the counties themselves or to the south in the original Central time counties.Contrary to Ice Miller LLP's assertions about obscure AM radio stations in Indianapolis being a hot ticket around here I nor anyone I know listens to said stations.I am sure there is something I have forgotten but these are just a few strong reasons regarding convenience of commerce as to why SW Indiana which is called the TRI-STATE because of ties to western KY and Illinois also in the Central time zone as to why this region should remain united.Doing so emphasizes our strong regional connections and allows for the benefits to be realized for all the counties and the region and allows the region to to better position itself to realize advantages in economicculturalsocial and civic activities thereby serving the convenience of commerce. The governor's office has taken to advertising in the Loogootee Tribune for Eastern time comments in which a scanned copy has been submitted to this docketand Michael McCully of the governors office contacting Pike county to have mis-information spread about possibly being seperated from the other four counties in regard to time zone in order to get some more pro-Eastern comments. We who support Central time feel we have submitted enough convenience of commerce evidence since this process began last Summer which we hope the DOT is giving consideration to.We feel the NPRM should not be granted for Eastern time for all of the reasons and evidence we have submitted in this process.The Joint Petition should be denied and no final rule issued.There are thousnads of businesses in the five re-petitioning counties and only a handful are submitting for Eastern time at the urging of local Cahmber of Commerces.A number of businesses are actully submitting for Central time so if they are doing well and managing why can't many of the global companies that are complaining?These businesses main complaint is not being connected to the Eastern time zone observing states which they have never been in line with the majority of the year anyway for the past decades!None of them have shown verifiable losses and every time they complain about Central time ther'e another newspaper article showin many of these businesses having record profit margins and even expanding while being on Central time.They have all been noted on this docket.RESIDENTS OF THE FIVE PETITIONING COUNTIESThere are over one hundred thousand residents in these counties but just a few thousnad have chosen to comment.If there is such a "GROUNDSWELL FOR EASTERN TIME" as asserted by the Joint Petition where is it at?It is not on this docket.If ther was such a GROUNDSWELL FOR EASTERN TIME  and if so many people were suffering great inconveniences on Central time doesn't it stand to reason given the media blitz and many links posted all over the internet to this docket that there would be more pro-Eastern time comments?This docket is running very close comment wise.I have read every one of them.There are probably a few more pro-Eastern time comments but given the assertions by the Joint Petition about the "GROUNSWELL FOR EASTERN" it"s pretty close.Since so few are commenting for Eastern time out of the hundred thousand plus residents of these counties it stands to reason they must either be happy with the current time zone or indifferent to it.Many of the pro-Eastern time comments are geared toward inconveniences of schedules and everyday life.These inconveniences will be transferred to a even larger group especially in regard to commuters should the DOT grant the Joint Petition and move the time zone boundary again. Take for example my county Martin a county with around ten thousand residents so far I think maybe 70 -80 comments if that.Most of these comes from Shoals on the Eastern edge of the county and although there are more for Eastern time it's no landslide.I submit this is not enough of a GOUNDSWELL FOR EASTERN TIME in my county or any of the other four to move this time zone boundary again.The number of residents complaining in these five counties works out to less than 1% of the total county population in each county.I do not what the DOT thinks about this but that doesn't add up to a "GROUNDSWELL FOR EASTERN TIME" to me!I am aware the process is not about popular opinion on time zone assignment but after all the Joint Petitionasserted this "GROUNSWELL" exisited not we who support Central in fact we have constantly stated to this agency it doesn't exist and in my opinion this has been proven correct.The people and special interest groups who pushed this re-petition effort are a narrow band oif people.Some are influential business leaders and citizens who are used to getting their way.Many ignored the process in the Summer and Fall of 2005 the few that didn't did not like the fact that they did not get their way and the commissioners and the DOT to a extent have granted all of these people a "do over" proceeding if you will.I would ask that the DOT not destroy the quality of life of the citizens of SW Indiana especilly the number of cross time zone boundary commuters which is a greater number of inconvenienced commuters if the boundary is moved again by rewarding these people with the tactics they employed to get us to where we are currnetly in this process.These tactics have been well documented on this docket.Lastly I will address the fact the entire congregation of a church was submitted to the DOT under the church's letterhead as supporting Central time.Several of these people have submitted to this docket that they did not give permission for this I nor any other Central time supporter I know condones this action if true.However the other side in this debate has sunken to much lower depths in trying to get Eastern time approved for the five counties and they have been numerous and documented to this docket.Dubois county4Centraltime.com can advertise or do whatever they wish to promote their cause.This is democracy and it's a whole lot better than lies from the governor's office or advertising by the governor's office for Eastern time comments.The governor is supposed to support the local decision and citizens decision not his preference.The time zone must be decided by local citizens and their commissioners.All local citizens not just the few who are complaining about Central time.Eastern time supporters are free to do what the wish and in fact have had several email campaigns to do just that.If they wanted to start a web site for Eastern time more powere to them.But make no mistake about it the power players politiciansspecial interests and a paid for Indy law firm is already a powerful force for we everyday citizens who support Central time to go up against.I am at the end now and the debate is at a end for the moment.I believe it will never go away.The county commissioners and other officials and state representatives asked Senior Council Kaleta and the DOT in a Novmber 2005 Jasper hearing to be place all of their counties in the Central time zone with the Evansville region and it's Central time counties.The DOT granted this request on January 172006.They got waht they wanted now it's time to give it a chance.These counties all voted to re-petition by May of 2006 after just a few months of being in the Central time zone because a vocal minority and special interests pressured them to.By the way if Perry county is added to any of the afore mentioned catagories in regards to the region remaining in the Central time zone it's a even stronger case for Central time.Moving the boundary will accomplish nothing.It will just inconvenience even more people.So for the last ime I respectfully ask the DOT to deny the Joint petition and leave things as is.The counties have not provided enough evidence to warrant a time zone boundary change.Please leave all six counties untied in the Central time zone.RespectfullyPhillip NorrisMaritn county resident
docketTitle: Standard Time Zone Boundary in Southwest Indiana
title: Phillip Norris

commentText: My husband wishes to express his strong appeal for Daviess county to go back to Eastern time - he feels he meets himself coming and going since he works in Farmersburg.  It makes for a pretty bad "family" life and time to spend with his family.
docketTitle: Standard Time Zone Boundary in Southwest Indiana
title: Patricia L. Kelsey
