commentText: I believe that all animals of this world deserve our love and protection at all times including during air travel while they are being shipped as cargo. I definitely support the DOT‰ЫЄs decision to extend protection coverage to all dogs and cats and I want the rule to extend reporting requirements to all animals shipped commercially not just dogs and cats. I believe that reporting requirements are essential to inform consumers about the risks associated with transporting animals by air and people deserve this information so they can make informed decisions about traveling safely with their pets. I hate to say that I was unaware of how dangerous and deadly shipping pets as cargo can often be and I want all people to be aware so that their pets get the best care and love possible from the informed caretaker. Thank you very much for helping our beloved companions.
docketTitle: Animal Legal Defense Fund - Petition to Amend 14 C.F.R. Section 234.13 - Air Carriers Regarding Incidents Involving Animals During Air Transport
title: Hillary Sue Blaylock

commentText: I flew my beloved German Shepherd down here in September 1998.  She had been examined by my vet the day before her flight and was given a clean bill of health.  My dog was very healthy never sick or injured. Only time she went to the vet was for her yearly check up and vaccines.  She was extremely friendly and when I went to pick her up Northwest Airlines used a forklift to move her kennel over to the pickup area. As soon as I let her out I noticed she was very stiff in one hind leg but thought it was because of the length of time she was in the kennel.  She was flown in the cargo area of the plane.  After about 3-4 days at home she was still stiff but also lame on her left hind leg so I took her to a vet clinic here.  They took xrays and sent me to a canine specialist for ACL damage.  She had severe damage to her stifle area and required surgery costing approx. $2700 the specialist opinion was that while she was in her kennel the airlines dropped her while moving her to or from a plane.  The damage done came from a significant event the Northwest denied it and even though I could have gone to court with the vet clean bill of health the day before she left and the specialist report I didn't have the money to go after Northwest.  Northwest told me that they would keep it delayed in court and cost me thousands of dollars if I went after them for the cost of my dogs surgery.  I will NEVER fly a animal on any airline as cargo AGAIN.  Since then I have never flown with Northwest I completely avoid them.
docketTitle: Animal Legal Defense Fund - Petition to Amend 14 C.F.R. Section 234.13 - Air Carriers Regarding Incidents Involving Animals During Air Transport
title: Michelle Angela Felczak

commentText: I have had experience moving my animals by airplane overseas. commentText: I have had many qualms about allowing my cat on an airplane as you just don't know what it's like and they won't even show you photographs of where they are loaded let alone actually look into the actual space. I think they should be required to show you live video that you can access on flight.  That would ensure decent handling of animals and proper safety codes. I also think that baggage handling of animals needs safety codes. I saw our cat's cage underneath FIVE huge bags as it was hauled back into the terminal.  He was terrified by the time I picked him up.  Little wonder!!It's time for all creatures not just pets to be treated with respect and care.  They are not concrete inanimates.  They are sentient just as we are.  Reporting all deaths is only the beginning for their deserved status.By the way in consequence of my doubts about safety in flight we don't go by plane any more when taking our cat.  I drive and take ferries.  It's safer.  I can leave kitty in the car in safety and also go and see that he is OK part way through the sail with an attendant with me.
docketTitle: Animal Legal Defense Fund - Petition to Amend 14 C.F.R. Section 234.13 - Air Carriers Regarding Incidents Involving Animals During Air Transport

title: Pamela Sue Green

commentText: Please amend the Department of Transportation's proposed rule to expand airline incident reporting requirements to include ALL animals not just cats and dogs. Air carriers are responsible for the safety of every animal that they handle regardless of species or 'purpose' as pet research subject etc. I support the DoT's proposal to require all covered carriers to provide in their December reports the total number of animals that were lost injured or died during air transport. I also support requiring carriers to add to those year-end reports the total number of animals transported in the calendar year. Reporting all animal numbers and incidents is in the public interest because it provides official documentation for consumers and the public regarding the safety and problems of transporting animals as cargo. Importantly it also keeps those responsible for the well-being of animals during transport accountable.
docketTitle: Animal Legal Defense Fund - Petition to Amend 14 C.F.R. Section 234.13 - Air Carriers Regarding Incidents Involving Animals During Air Transport
title: Comment on FR Doc # 2012-16024

commentText: Please amend the proposed rule so that airlines are required to file reports for ANY animal who is lost injured or killed while in their care and custody.  The animal‰ЫЄs status as ‰ЫПpet‰Ыќ ‰ЫПcommercial shipment‰Ыќ or otherwise has no bearing on an air carrier‰ЫЄs responsibility to ensure that that animal is handled humanely and arrives alive and well at the final destination.  While the rule as proposed is an improvement over the current coverage‰ЫУlimited only to pets residing in U.S. households‰ЫУit still fails to cover such egregious situations as the deaths of 15 monkeys during an arduous journey from Miami to Los Angeles to China and back again.  I support DoT‰ЫЄs suggestion that the airlines‰ЫЄ December reports include the total number of animals transported in the previous year as well as a tally for the year of ALL animal losses injuries and deaths.  This more comprehensive year-end report will make the information that much more meaningful and accessible to consumers. I also support applying the reporting requirement to more airlines as proposed.  The public deserves complete transparency regarding the airlines‰ЫЄ records when it comes to handling animals. Making the airlines more accountable will encourage and/or motivate them to be more careful with their animal passengers.    Thank you for taking these comments into consideration.
docketTitle: Animal Legal Defense Fund - Petition to Amend 14 C.F.R. Section 234.13 - Air Carriers Regarding Incidents Involving Animals During Air Transport
title: Dona Sue LaSchiva

commentText: The Department of Transportation (DoT) needs to ensure the safety of ALL animals on airplanes. That starts with reporting and tracking 'incidents' so bad practices can be revealed and stopped.Please comment now through Regulations.gov to improve the system of reporting death and/or injury of an animal during air travel as cargo.Currently U.S. airlines are required to report only cases in which a family pet such as a dog or cat is involved. Regulations do not include animals shipped for commercial purposes including dogs from puppy mills birds for the pet trade or primates being shipped to laboratories.However the DoT is proposing to expand requirements to "include all cats and dogs transported by the carrier regardless of whether the cat or dog is transported as a pet by its owner or as part of a commercial shipment." Under these rules airlines would also report the total number of killed/injured animals as well as the total number of animals transported as cargo.This proposed expansion does not go far enough. All animals should be counted regardless of their 'purpose' or flight itinerary. Doing so not only allows consumers to make educated decisions when choosing an airline it also helps to keep those responsible for the well-being of animals during transport accountable. Different species of animals can have very different needs and some like primates require special care particularly during long journeys which are very stressful.Importantly a complete picture of such activities cannot be achieved unless the regulations are expanded to include all airplanes that transport passengers along with animal cargo regardless of size as well as those that only transport cargo.Last year AAVS documented the use and importation of primates for research and outlined the hazards associated with transporting these animals in its report entitled "Primates by the Numbers." Earlier this year a court case over the deaths of 15 monkeys made headlines
docketTitle: Animal Legal Defense Fund - Petition to Amend 14 C.F.R. Section 234.13 - Air Carriers Regarding Incidents Involving Animals During Air Transport
title: Comment on FR Doc # 2012-16024

commentText: The problem of animals shipped as cargo goes back decades.  My father was an air systems engineer for a major airplane manufacturer.  I remember a case in 1973 when several racing greyhounds were killed or injured while being transported as cargo in the hold of an airplane.  He had to calculate how much oxygen was available for the animals during flight and I helped him research the problem via reading articles in my university library and bring back copies.  There was a lawsuit as $$$$$ was involved.  That was 39 years ago and we are still seeing problems with this result.  Enough is enough.  Animals are not inanimate cargo.  They require air and water.  They need to be placed in the cargo hold in a way that their air supply is not blocked.  Cargo handlers just throw stuff in the cargo hold and to BLEEP with it.  I recommend regulations and training for cargo handlers and airline personnel.  The USA usually represents the best of humanitarian efforts in the world.  A little help for our animal friends in flight would be nothing less humane.
docketTitle: Animal Legal Defense Fund - Petition to Amend 14 C.F.R. Section 234.13 - Air Carriers Regarding Incidents Involving Animals During Air Transport
title: Cheri W. Astrahan

commentText: I have worked in the DBE program 20+ years.Personal Net Worth (PNW) Form and Related Requirements of 49 CFR 26.27The PNW proposal to determine if a person ‰ЫПdemonstrates an ability to accumulate substantial wealth has unlimited growth potential or has not experienced or has not had to overcome impediment . . . ‰ЫП is very subjective and would impose a real burden on reviewers.The ‰ЫПbright line‰Ыќ approach of using adjusted gross income as a basis to determine economic disadvantage would help many certifiers. Most certifiers are college graduates and not accountants. We have no way of knowing if all documents which should be provided are. President Obama recently announced support of tax changes for individuals with adjusted gross receipts of $400000 or more defining those individuals as ‰ЫПwealthy.‰Ыќ $400000 would be a reasonable standard for a bright line approach.US DOT has experts who specialize in certification denial appeals. Those experts should develop  training for recipients about where to look for items regarding personal net worth (and small business size) on U.S. tax forms. The guidance should reference specific lines schedules and forms.The spouse or domestic partner of an applicant should not be required to submit PNW statements. DBE certification requirements are very intrusive particularly for those working in the non-construction arena. Many businesses including those working on US DOT funded contracts refuse to apply for certification. If the bright line PNW approach is used it would be reasonable to require a spouse/domestic partner to provide the most recent three consecutive years of personal federal income tax forms only when the spouse or domestic partner is affiliated with the applicant firm.DBE Commitments/Awards and Payment Reporting FormRegarding comment about the ‰ЫПinability to break out woman-owned DBE participation by race; ‰Ы_.‰ЫП this would make an already complicated process more complicated.
docketTitle: Disadvantaged Business Enterprise: Program Implementation Modifications
title: Anonymous

commentText: I am 110% against the use of cell phones on aircraft for voice communications.In the close quarters onboard an aircraft at 34000 feet with the person sitting next to me or right behind me talking for 90 minutes to their best friend about how she hates Mary Sue Billings is no different than subjecting me to "water-boarding."I can't run I can't move I can't escape......I'm imprisoned in my seat for another 3 1/2 hours being forced to listen to the mindless prattle going on around me.  I can only conclude that inflight violence will escalate.  How could one conclude differently?If my fellow passenger wants to rattle on about how she hates Mary Sue Billings then she can use her cell phone to text her BFF.  (Please have the ring tone for an incoming text put in the vibrate mode.)  I am not opposed to inflight texting.  I am very much opposed to voice communication on a cell phone while the aircraft is moving.
docketTitle: Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft
title: Daniel

commentText: Please do not allow cell phone voice calls on airplanes.  My argument against it would be that a person has a right to do what they want ONLY if it doesn't harm others.  In such a small enclosed space other peoples conversations would inevitably be extremely irritating to the people around them.  Fellow passengers would have no option to get away from the noise if they found it unpleasant.  A compromise position would be to allow text messages only.
docketTitle: Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft
title: Sue Law

commentText: Please do NOT allow use of cellphones in flight.  I can not imagine anything else that would make flying more miserable!  As you know there is much ambient noise during flight and people naturally speak much louder on cellphones ("can you hear me now?").  If one person were talking then others around would have to speak even more loudly.  This would result in increased hostility toward other passengers and ultimately to the flight crew.  Things are bad enough nowadays with the general rudeness exhibited by so many flyers.  Two weeks ago I took a total of four flights in a week.   On each there were passengers seated in the rear that blocked traffic by trying to push ahead and stow their (huge) bags in the bins at the very front of coach.  This is so inconsiderate of nearly everyone else.  I paid extra to sit up front and don't appreciate having to struggle for space for my small tote bag against some oaf who should have checked his big bag as I did.I have a friend who works for Delta and know that the employees there are very much against it as are employees at Sun Country.  With people who work on planes thinking it is a bad idea that should tell you all you need to know!Thanks so much for your consideration.
docketTitle: Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft
title: Sue Keator

commentText: the use of cell phones for voice calls on aircraft is as objectionable and unnecessary as voice call use in any waiting room classroom medical office etc. where personal space is imposed upon by another person. most of us who travel on airplanes are not in the air for business and therefore there is no urgency to conduct business in the air. besides i suspect any business person flying either wants to use that time to catch up on sleep or can communicate via emails with their colleagues. personal cell phone calls are irritating to listen to on the ground much less in closed quarters with no escape in the air. i have been forced to witness loud and abusive arguments lewd "romantic" ploys disciplinary rants grocery lists laundry lists and too much idle chatter by individuals i don't know and disrespectful narcissists i don't care to know. additionally these conversations are not what any responsible parents would allow their children to hear given a choice.by allowing cell phone use on aircraft the airlines would be opening themselves up to a myriad of predictable negative  situations: violence theft lawsuits etc.. the consumer would of course then be handed the bills for "cell phone police" lawyers doctors etc.. imagine all of us in the air watching our individual little tv's without earphones... try it. see if you like it.
docketTitle: Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft
title: Marlene Wiedenbaum

commentText: This is such a bad idea. Having 300 people in a cramped enclosed space for hours on end with say 10% of them at any given time talking (loudly) into their phones would make flights unendurably noisy. It's important when you are forced to be cheek by jowl and shoulder to shoulder with a horde of strangers to be able to maintain a sense of privacy; allowing cellphone use would destroy this entirely. You would be always in the presence of at least one person shouting to make himself or herself heard above engine noise and the surrounding crowd. And these conversations would probably be long ones; the caller has nothing very much else to do after all.One of the least-liked "types" of fellow passengers is the loud talker whose conversation intrudes on the thoughts and quiet conversations of everyone within 3 rows and seats. Allowing cellphone use on flights would institutionalize this intrusion and to no real benefit. Cellphone use would provide entertainment and distraction from boredom not usually anything critical to anyone's well-being. The effect this rule would have on the mood of the planeload of people would be significant and negative. Think of yourself in this situation: you are sitting next to someone talking laughing discussing family matters all at a volume that can't be ignored. What do you do? You can ask them to talk more softly but they can't since the engine noise requires you speak up so you can be heard at all. You can ask them to hang up because they're talking too loud and you can't hear yourself think; they'll refuse since they're having a perfectly good time. Later you'll *tell* them to hang up; they'll refuse probably rudely. So you tell the flight attendant who has no legal basis for telling them to hang up and must therefore appeal to reason and fair play--never a winning strategy. So there you are sitting next to an ongoing noise source (or two or three) that will not shut up and cannot be compelled to do so. Imagine the frustration. You would certainly be wondering what you have in your possession that you could use to force them to quiet down; what do have that you could use as a cudgel?Now multiply by 300. Managing the mood of a planeful of people is an important component to running a flight. Allowing cellphone use on a flight will make this increasingly difficult. In any group of 300 individuals there are a couple who don't handle frustration well; this rule sets up a situation where those individuals are tested more than any of us would like.Finally this would do the airlines no particular good. They would feel obliged to install the cell equipment on their planes and then would have to bear the consequent decrease in nearly everyone's desire to fly. They would end up spending money to make people like them less.This rule would do a lot of real damage to the already marginal flying experience and would add nothing of real value. I urge the DOT to not adopt this rule.
docketTitle: Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft
title: John Deubert

commentText: We do not need people talking on mobile phones on aircraft. Passengers are seated very closely together and it would be extremely disruptive to have people having multiple phone conversations all around you.  Please do not permit voice calls on airplanes except in case of emergencies to preserve the sanity and privacy of passengers.
docketTitle: Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft
title: Sue Burnett

commentText: Dear Docket Clerk:These comments are submitted on behalf of the Central Contra Costa Transit Authority (County Connection). County Connection operates fixed route and paratransit service within central Contra Costa County in the suburban San Francisco area. Our service area is over 200 sq. miles with a population of over 500000. We provide over five million transit trips annually on a combined annual operating budget of just over 35 million dollars. I am writing to provide comments on the Office of the Secretary of Transportation (OST) request for comments on the Next Phase of the Regulatory Review of Existing Department of Transportation (DOT) Regulations published February 27 2014 at 79 FR 11051.OST has offered a number of options for managing this review process including simplyasking for specific rules in need of review focusing on a list identified by DOT in 2011 focusing ona specific operating administration or focusing on cross-cutting rules. We do not believe any ofthese options are mutually exclusive and that all have merit based on a wide range of factors.There are specific rules that standing alone are unduly restrictive and cause the regulatedcommunity to expend excessive time and money to achieve compliance. DOT should seekrecommendations on these specific rules to be reviewed.The 56 rules cited in the Federal Register should be explained in greater detail. The referenceto Attachment 2 of the Department‰ЫЄs 2011 final plan leads to a reprint of a routine Section 610 noticeand does not clearly specify which of the rules the Department identified as having potential savings.Once clarified we would encourage OST to seek additional information from the public and use thatinformation to prioritize its list.Since the impact of rules is often cumulative OST should pursue a modal review to ascertainthe overall regulatory burden on the regulated community and specifically to identify those areaswhere differing rules require the same or similar information to be processed and presented indifferent ways. This review should not be limited to existing rules but also those being developed.Similarly OST should focus on cross-cutting issues to eliminate unnecessary costs andconfusion. Buy America with many differing interpretations of compliance should be an immediatefocus. While the underlying statutes may differ the differences are exacerbated in widely divergentregulatory schemes and practices within the Department. Moreover projects that draw funding frommore than one modal administration require clear guidance on what rule applies. As the FederalTransit Administration crafts its safety program OST must ensure that the program can reasonablyco-exist with the Federal Railroad Administration‰ЫЄs program to avoid duplicative counter-productiveefforts.Within this exercise OST should also look to the various Circulars and other guidancedocuments that have become de facto rules through practice oversight and other modaladministration actions. While an underlying regulation may be benign the interpretation andenforcement of the rule is often cumbersome. We have found that review processes have tendedover time to enlarge regulatory requirements through the threat of adverse findings and these defacto rules carry the same potential for wasting time and money as formal regulations.Finally the Department should examine its rulemaking processes. Delay and uncertainty inthe regulatory process only compound the ill effects noted above. As an example OST proposedchanges to its regulations related to services for people with disabilities in 2006. Over eight yearslater the proposals are still pending. Federal courts in multiple circuits have found themunenforceable before they are finalized yet they are regularly enforced through adverse reviewfindings. This leads to confusion for agencies providing the services the passengers dependent onthe services and the state and local governments responsible for funding the services.Thank you for the opportunity to comment.Rick RamacierGeneral ManagerCounty Connection 2477 Arnold Industrial WayConcord CA 94520925-680-2050
docketTitle: Next Phase of the Regulatory Reviews of Existing DOT Regulations
organization: Central Contra Costa Transit Authority (County Connection)
title: Central Contra Costa Transit Authority (County Connection)

commentText: There has to be some way for the consumer to tell if a fare is legitimate and will be honored.  If the airline can choose to correct a mistake by voiding sold tickets but consumers can't the system is unbalanced.  Currently operators Norwegian Air Shuttle and WOW Air have entered the trans-Atlantic market with shockingly low prices.  The latter entered fares that were not mistakes of $99 each way.  Additionally there are business class fares currently in the range of $1200 to and from Europe on every alliance yet British Airways claimed that $1800 fares form Austin to Dubai were clear mistakes.  How can a consumer know that when they book a $200 ticket to Iceland that the fare is valid or that $1800 to Dubai is a mistake when competitive fares are still in that range?  Emirates also sold tickets (and does so frequently) in pairs for $899 from JFK-Milan that's less than $450/person all-in and United has fares to Hong Kong from Philadelphia for less than $550 today (5/20/2015).  Average consumers can't be expected to understand complex fare construction and know for example that YQ (commonly used fare code for fuel surcharges) are meant to be included in some fares (British Airways) and not in others (American Airlines). If the YQ is absent British Airways would call it a mistake fare but buyers of tickets on their partner American would not know to look for that identify the error and then avoid the booking because it had been mislabeled.  Airlines had carte blanche before CFR 399.88 was in place to choose when they would and would not be responsible for their mistakes.  They could choose to "honor" a fare out of goodwill or to avoid legal action but this is unfair to consumers.  If I as a consumer buy a product and make a mistake when I purchase it I don't get to choose whether or not to "honor" my original purchase but rather I am subject to the company's return policy which is non-uniform and can vary store to store and state to state.  I would not argue that the advent of resources in the frequent flyer community make these mistakes much larger than they were before however these same conditions exist elsewhere in industry.  Twitter blogs and forums exist in every niche community from "mom" groups to players of certain video games.  Dansdeals.com is a site where bargain hunters go to find great deals and occasionally price mistakes are highlighted on the site. However if an order is processed - mistake or not - in most states the vendor is liable for the price they agreed upon with the customer.  Why is airfare different?The title of this proposed rule: Transparency of Airline Ancillary Fees and Other Consumer Protection Issues will do little to resolve the murky waters of airline pricing if carriers aren't held accountable for what they sell.  I would argue that not only should they honor their mistakes but the legislation should be extended to cruise lines buses trains and hotels.  There are certainly bad actors on both sides of this transaction.  Some purchased tens of thousands of dollars worth of airfare some of which they would not even fly for pennies on the dollar during the United Danish Kroner issue and that seems unfair to the airline.  But is it not the responsibility of a business owner to make sure their merchandise is accurately priced?  What would stop a gas station owner from changing the price of a gallon of unleaded from $2.99 to $.29 and then once someone has already filled their car and there is a line around the block claiming that the price was not valid and demanding the rest of the price.  "You should have know that was an error" the gas station owner might say except that every now and again gas stations get people in the door by dropping their prices for a brief time to incredibly low rates.  Airlines can be bad actors too.  Recently several American carriers were found to have price fixed routes to Seoul or settled out of court on compelling evidence.  This isn't the first time this has happened and it is unlikely it is the last.If I were to hold up signs with prices and routes (as listed above) without showing the airline's name could you tell if it was a mistake?  If not how can a consumer and should they be liable for conducting thorough route analysis to determine that this carrier would go low but not that low? Finally we live in an era where Twitter forums and other online presences can compound an issue for any business - airline or otherwise.  That does not mean the DoT should allow them to no longer be responsible for the mistakes of their employees or antiquated technology.  Whatever choice is made regarding this CFR it should be forced consistently and without prejudice.  If the rule stands then United should be (in future situations) required to honor tickets bad actors or not.  Consumers will continue to be on the hook for their mistakes too.  But the way the rule stands now (unenforced) is ineffective.
docketTitle: Transparency of Airline Ancillary Fees and Other Consumer Protection Issues
title: Kyle Stewart

commentText: Sent via email to: SecretaryI am opposed to the U.S. DOT proposal that allows states and local governments to impose geographic hiring requirements on contractors performing federally funded contracts. My company builds transportation projects that receive federal assistance from the Federal Highway Administration (FHWA) and/or the Federal Transit Administration (FTA). Local hiring preferences force me to discriminate against some of my workers by laying them off because I have to hire new workers from the jurisdiction with the preference. My workers are well trained and highly skilled. These skills allow our company to offer the taxpayers a high quality construction project that is built safely at the lowest possible cost. Because of the need to lay off some of my workers I may choose not to bid on projects with these requirements. This limits competition and can increase project costs.I understand the motivation to force contractors to hire unemployed individuals on federally-funded projects; however this is not the way to accomplish this goal. Training programs that provide individuals the skills needed to have a successful career in the construction industry is the better way to accomplish this goal. I urge you to not allow local hiring preferences to be used on FHWA and FTA funded projects.
docketTitle: Geographic-Based Hiring Preferences in Administering Federal Awards
title: Sue Sheridan

commentText: I support critical infrastructure resilience and the U.S. governmentМўеЫеЄs 2008 decision and announcement to establish an eLoran system as a complement and backup to GSP. This decision was supported by a very thorough review of the options by the Institute of Defense Analysis that was eventually published in 2009 (http://rntfnd.org/wp-content/uploads/Inst.-Defense-Analysis-Report-to-DHS-DOT.pdf). I believe the analysis done then is still valid and urge the federal government to promptly implement this decision.
docketTitle: Notice of Request for Public Comment
title: Sue Curran

commentText: We are writing to you today to introduce our organization All Wheels Up Inc. a non for profit organization which was created to solely advocate for the crash testing of wheelchairs for commercial flight purposes by the FAA.   Our Organization would like to work with you as well as with airline manufacturers on the future designs of new airplanes to be wheelchair accessible. We are specifically concerned about power chairs in which the passenger is unable to transfer themselves or in which traveling in a standard airline seat would risk their physical health and safety.Currently neither the Department of Transportation's Air Carrier Access Act nor the ADA resolves the needs for those who are dependent on wheelchairs and commercial flight.  The ADAs requirements for public transportation providers are generally the same whether they are public agencies or private contractors.  Standards apply to facilities and vehicles.  Unfortunately the airline industry has been excluded from having to make revisions to existing aircraft or from having to currently make any advancement in designs for future planes going into production.  We are requesting that the airline industry as a whole come together to address the lack of progress in this area and address the needs of the disabled flyer who uses  a wheelchair and can not be transferred or travel safely in a regular seat.All Wheels Up Inc.is here to be liaisons of information from the wheelchair industry rehabilitation regulations industry as well as providing financial data to show you how safe and profitable it will be for wheelchair users to travel commercially.    We are also a professional organization that understands things do not change overnight. The reality is that at the end of the day a big business like yours wants to know the dollars and cents. So what is the big picture and how do you benefit?   First of all we are not asking you to retrofit existing planes. This would be a huge expense. What we are asking is for you to look to the future and set the ground work for the future of aviation accessibility. And secondly with the increasing number of people using wheelchairs each year the airline industry will realize significant revenue exponential. As an industry you are not just excluding the one person who is disabled from flying  but you are losing the revenue of the approximately four additional seat sales.  A disabled person rarely flies alone. They travel with their families as well as and in many cases with a care taker or nurse.  Do you want this this family of four plus one care taker driving to their next destination due to how difficult it is to fly?  if you get just half of the population that are in power chairs that currently does not fly to fly  your revenue would increase in the multi million dollar range. In 2008 one particular airline spent over $1 Million in wheelchair repairs.   This figure also does not include the expenses that airlines outlay every year to disabled travelers in lawsuits free tickets and additional items to prevent lawsuits.SolutionThe next step:  All Wheels Up has raised the funds and has done the research and will be conducting the first ever crash test of wheelchairs for commercial flight at an FAA approved Crash test facility.  We would like you to request the major aircraft manufacturers (Boeing and Airbus) to consider a design for wheel chair accessible cabins.  With this request the FAA has confirmed they will act upon our request to crash test wheelchairs.  Take note a large majority of the work and reports have already been conducted.  The FAA would only need to expand on the research already done from the company Q'straint whose restraining systems have passed the 20 G crash test while all air craft passenger seats have only passed a 16 G crash test. Due to this study alone the FAA is excited to work on the crash testing wheelchairs for commercial flight.  In addition hundreds of wheelchair models have already undergone extensive crash testing by the RERC  WTS (Rehabilitation Engineering Research Center on Wheelchair Transportation Safety) due to the WC18 regulation funded by the NIDRR (National Institute on Disability and Rehabilitation Research).  These tests conducted show all wheelchairs have also passes a 20 G frontal crash test again surpassing the 16G crash test standard for commercial airline seats.All Wheels up and like minded companies have the solution. All we need is you to take the next step with us. We look forward to you having further conversations with us regarding crash testing wheelchairs for commercial flight.Michele ErwinAll Wheels Up Founder and President917-414-0897
docketTitle: Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel; Consideration of Negotiated Rulemaking Process
title: Comment from Michele Erwin

commentText: I believe more stringent regulations must be put in place to curb the abuse of passengers who claim animals as emotional support animals. Specifically I am aware of individuals from Canada who used an online service to obtain paperwork for a faked psychiatric disorder. They then traveled to Aruba registered feral street dogs as ESAs with the online service and then forced the airlines to fly them for free to the U.S.. These animals were advertised as "available" in advance of their trip and were then sold after arriving in Canada. In no instance did they travel TO Aruba with an ESA. Over a six month period at least 12 different animals were claimed as ESAs. Some adult dogs were even transported in cabin putting passenger and crew at risk.The airlines were made aware of these activities but are generally unable to deny transport even when presented with clear and documented evidence of fraud. It is certainly a misuse of flying ESAs when it is done simply to transport a "personal pet" when there is no real or legitimate emotional need. In this case it is even more egregious because there is clearly NO "personal" connection with the animals they are defrauding the airline into paying the cost to ship them the animals are immediately being dispersed or sold and the intent is to ensure the airline cannot deny their transport. Airlines must have the ability to deny transport of ESAs when there is clear evidence of fraud without the fear of lawsuits.
docketTitle: Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel; Consideration of Negotiated Rulemaking Process
title: Comment from Susan Busch

commentText: I have a disability and have been using service dogs for over 10 years to assist me with my disability. I am aghast that DOT is thinking of requiring third party medical clearance for flying with any type of service animal. This makes no sense. Many people with disabilities do not see their doctor regularly about their disability. For example someone who is missing a limb from birth doesn't need to go to the doctor to verify that their limb is still indeed missing. Many people with disabilities are stable medically and do not see a doctor regularly. Other individuals on state aid may have to wait 9 months or more in order to even see a doctor (like I had to) and they may not get the doctor to approve their assistive device as other things are more pressing during the quick 15 min doctor visit. For most of us we aren't rich and a visit to a doctor can be quite expensive. Additionally most doctors are fearful of lawsuits and refuse to write notes or fill out paperwork pertaining to my service animal.A decision tree or attestation provides credible assurance that the person is disabled and needs to use a service animal. Hopefully the decision tree or attestation would also include an educational component so that people can accurately fill out the form and know what their rights and responsibilities are in air travel. Majority of people don't know this.People with disabilities should not be treated as if they're presumed guilty until proven innocent. Please respect us as able to make decisions for ourselves about what we need to assist us. It would not make us feel so discriminated if you would treat us like a normal human being.
docketTitle: Nondiscrimination on the Basis of Disability in Air Travel; Consideration of Negotiated Rulemaking Process
title: Comment from Patricia Heath

commentText: I have a disability and have been using service dogs for over 10 years to assist me with my disability. Many people with disabilities do not see their doctor regularly about their disability. For example someone who is missing a limb from birth doesn't need to go to the doctor to verify that their limb is still indeed missing. Many people with disabilities are stable medically and do not see a doctor regularly. Other individuals on state aid may have to wait 9 months or more in order to even see a doctor (like my husband) and they may not get the doctor to approve their assistive device as other things are more pressing during the quick 15 min doctor visit. My husband was using a wheelchair for 9 months before he was able to see a neurologist. commentText: Department of TransportationDocket No. DOT-OST-2016-0208DOT solicited comments to help "determine when the clock stops running" before passengers are entitled to bag fee refunds. Refunding Baggage Fees for Delayed Checked Bags 81 Fed. Reg. 75347 75348 (Oct. 31 2016). First this comment argues that the policy best for consumers is to stop the clock once baggage arrives at the final destination airport. Second it argues why this rule would survive a potential Chevron challenge.It would be in the best interest of consumers to stop the clock once baggage arrives at the destination airport. I focus on one reason: it would least increase baggage fee prices. The clock can most plausibly stop in three situations: when bags are delivered to (1) the passenger's person; (2) the passenger's permanent or temporary residence; or (3) the destination airport. The first two present such substantial delivery costs that airlines would often choose to refund the baggage fee rather than deliver on time. Accordingly airlines to compensate higher costs would likely raise baggage fee prices more under the first two options.This rule would likely survive a Chevron challenge. If "Congress has directly spoken" to when the clock stops then DOT "must give effect to the unambiguously expressed intent of Congress." Chevron U.S.A. Inc. v. Natural Resource Defense Council Inc. 467 U.S. 837 842-43 (1984). A challenger may say Congress was unambiguous;  "deliver[ed] . . . to the passenger" means what it says. FAA Extension Safety and Security Act of 2016 Pub. L. No. 114-190  2305(a)(1) 130 Stat. 615 640-41. But one cannot unambiguously determine what "deliver[ed] . . . to the passenger" means. Plain meaning would only permit the clock to stop once baggage reaches the passenger's person. This could produce absurd results imposing enormous costs on airlines while they race to find passengers wherever they are. It is a well-settled canon of statutory interpretation that absurd results can make a statute's otherwise plain meaning mean something else. If delivery to the passenger does not mean delivery to the passenger then the statute is ambiguous. And an agency's interpretation of an ambiguous statute need only be a "permissible construction." Chevron 467 U.S. at 843. Because courts rarely find agency constructions of ambiguous statutes impermissible and because stopping the clock once baggage arrives at the destination airport would both promote consumer welfare and comport with a plausible understanding of baggage delivery this rule would likely survive judicial review.
docketTitle: Refund baggage fee for delayed bags
title: Comment from Daniel Rios

commentText: When I book travel I often use comparison websites to search and purchase airline tickets.  I rely on the convenience of finding all my options on one screen.  Plus when airlines know their fares will be listed next to their competitors they will be more likely to offer a competitive price. It's come to my attention that some airlines are trying to make it harder for me to see all my options by restricting certain websites from publishing fare and schedule information. They shouldn't get to pick and choose who can share information that's already publicly available.  We need more transparency in the marketplace not less.
docketTitle: Exploring Industry Practices on Distribution and Display of Airline Fare, Schedule, and Availability Information
title: Comment from Sue Davis

title: Comment from Sue Dupuy

commentText: Absolutely not! It will cause chaos hatred and violence on the already cramped airplane.  It will cause accidents and bring many law suits.
docketTitle: Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft
title: Comment from Sue Anonymous

commentText: Air travel is a miracle and a scourge. The minor but incessant annoyances experienced by air travelers--fussy babies unnecessarily fragrant food the passenger in front of you who insists on reclining his seat fully-- are the stuff of bad stand-up and dull dinner conversations. When you trap a couple hundred people in claustrophobic quarters for hours at a time small grievances are amplified and tempers flare and it is in the government's interest to protect American flyers from unnecessary hardship while they are unable to deplane. The proposed measure is perfectly within the Department of Transportation's purview and I support its adoption. I recognize that this measure is not an outright ban on voice-calls but rather would require airlines to disclose their policy regarding them. This is a reasonable expectation to impose upon carriers that would increase the ability of the consumer to make well-informed choices about which carrier to patronize. I also appreciate the limitation of the rule's effect to airline carriers that are not small entities thus avoiding any undue burden on smaller businesses. However in response to the request for comment on a possible full ban of voice calls on commercial aircraft I must insist that any full ban of voice calls would be a drain on government time and an unnecessary imposition on airline carriers.It should not be taken lightly that international carriers that permit voice calls have not been inundated with customer complaints. The "Comments on the ANPRM" section of the proposed rule document admits to this fact. Its rebuttal that American consumers expect a voice-call-free cabin however pays no respect to the ability of American consumers to adjust to technological change. In today's world when most Americans carry some mobile device with them Americans expect to be digitally connected at all times. Airlines' move to offer in-flight wifi has been met largely with enthusiasm if some frustration when it does not function properly. This should be an indication that Americans do value staying connected while travelling. It is also entirely possible that the majority of consumers would use the ability to make voice calls considerately. After all people playing music aloud from their mobile devices is not a common complaint for air travelers despite the fact that most have devices capable of such action.Perhaps the most notable reason a full ban is not necessary is that this proposed rule would already disincentivize airlines from allowing voice calls; if only those carriers who permit voice calls on flights are required to disclose their policy to consumers prior to the purchase of tickets the carriers may avoid any costs associated with doing so by simply prohibiting voice calls to begin with. In this way the rule would maintain what the proposed rule document considers the status quo-- that voice calls are not allowed on flights-- making an outright ban on voice calls appear even less necessary.The proposed rule is acceptable however because it still allows for carriers to make the ultimate decision on whether or not to allow voice calls as they are perfectly capable of doing. If the benefits of permitting voice calls are something that appeals to consumers airlines are perfectly able to allow them though they may be more apt to attach an additional charge for the service to offset the costs of conforming to this proposed regulation and informing consumers of their policy in advance. The technology currently available would allow for carriers to restrict voice calls during certain times like at take-off and landing or during sleeping hours--all measures which would assuage major passenger concerns about disruption and lost sleep. The proposed rule does enough to preserve the status quo that there is no need for an explicit ban and market forces are sufficient to moderate voice call use without more serious government regulation.Government regulation restricting voice calls is simply not needed at this time. If as the proposed rule document suggests an increase in airlines' technical ability to allow voice calls leads to a higher incidence of people actually making voice calls while in the air further restrictions in the form of federal regulations may be prudent. Even then though it is entirely likely that airlines themselves will be able to resolve any mass consumer dissatisfaction by simply limiting the times during which voice calls are acceptable. While I recognize that government action banning voice calls may be necessary in the future for now let the individual airlines--and societal bounds of propriety-- sort out this issue.
docketTitle: Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft
title: Comment from Jaden Young

commentText: Allowing the usage of cell phones for calls during flights would be a monumental mistake. Even before takeoff you see people who are speaking loudly on their phones - even during the flight attendant safety speech. Many people even enter the aircraft while on the phone - crooking their neck to accommodate their cell phone while banging you or your seat while they struggle with their luggage in one hand and their bag in the other - oblivious to the chaos and spectacle they are creating.Secondly many people engage in vulgar language when on a call even when strangers and children are within earshot. Many times their voice volume cannot be modulated without many times incurring the wrath of the caller. Even worse I have seen many people hold court on their phone with the speaker phone on so that the WHOLE plane can hear about "how bad Aunt Martha's bunion surgery turned out" "what groceries they need to buy for the party" or can you believe how hot the new secretary is?". Most people don't care.Moreover many flights are made during early morning or late at night when travelers are trying to catch up on the rest they missed in accommodating their early/late flight. Incessant phone chatting would only add to their fellow travelers discomfort and dissapointment. There are VERY few calls that MUST take place on an air plane while in flight. To impose this burden on travelers who are already constrained and annoyed by the latest airline-imposed fees for baggage food seat and luggage restrictions - flying has become less about enjoyment and convenience and more about bearing the brunt and expanding ones capacity for enduring the experience. Adding incessant noise from possibly dozens of people chattering away in differing volumes different languages and differing ideas as to their choice of words and congeniality to the plight or concern of their fellow travelers feelings comfort and peace will be the straw that breaks the camels back - and could even lead to more disruption in flight caused by people fighting about this situation. I am convinced that the airlines desire to add the availability of "in flight phone calls" is not driven by a desire to offer their customers a "benefit" but simply ANOTHER way for them to gouge out even more incremental income by making them use the wifi systems on their planes for said phone calls. Please use solid thoughtful judgement and do not allow this comfort and peace altering change to occur.
docketTitle: Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft
title: Comment from Greg London

commentText: As a frequent flyer and frequent communicator I'm willing to give up the right to use my phone in flight to preserve peace and quiet as too many folks on their phones do not regulate their tone language or amplitude and will create an atmosphere of noise that will disturb everyone around them.  Please reject the idea of allowing in flight use of cell phones as everyone can get on the internet and write notes.Allowing this will also create conflict in the skies that will be difficult for airline personnel to enforce if phones are allowed and those who do not control the language or tone will rightly fight they have every right to use the phone even if passengers don't approve of how they do it.This will turn into a huge problem and create litigation and safety issues.
docketTitle: Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft
title: Comment from Ronald Mills

commentText: As a retired flight attendant I am horrified by the possibility of people using their cell phones for calls inflight.  The cabin is already a hot bed of short tempers and discourtesy.  This will only make it worse.   But most important is the horrifying situation that could occur in case of an emergency.....can you imagine 300 people making calls instead of listening to the flight attendants and evacuating the plane?    Inflight phone calls is a horrible idea for safety reasons and for simple human ability to enjoy a (somewhat) peaceful flight.   Flight attendants have enough to do now without having to deal with passengers who are disturbing those around them.
docketTitle: Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft
title: Comment from Sue Lindstrom

commentText: Do not allow any voice calls. Many years ago there was technology on some flights to allow calls using headsets built into the back of seats. I witnessed a very loud call that disturbed DOZENS of people around the caller who had to yell to be heard. Flight attendants and others politely asked him to quiet down. He said he could barely be heard on the other end. He also said that he had been trying to reach this person for weeks and had to negotiate and close the contract or lose his job...The flight crew had to intercede. The irate caller handed the headset to the captain who was verbally harassed by the caller on the other end who threatened to get the pilot fired...Are we going to have conflicts on flights with people claiming freedom of speech? Unless you provide an old fashioned telephone booth on the plane so calls will not impact others this will not work. I would have to bring ear plugs for my children so they would not overhear any rudeness or something as innocent as a discussion on Santa. Who can i sue when a stranger talking loudely ruins the illusion of Santa for my child? What price can the legal profession attach to that? Despite the idea that the market will decide and I could pay extra to take a flight on a voice free flight the availability of flights limits me. In a public setting like a mall if an overheard conversation offends me i can leave. I cannot leave a flight in mid air. Allowing voice calls is a very bad idea that will lead to conflict and thus violence on planes. The plane cabin environment stress level is already high and allowing voice calls will dangerously escalate it. Text and email is widespread and available as an alternative.
docketTitle: Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft
title: Comment from Stephen Obrien

commentText: Having flown commercially well over several million miles over the last 50 years allowing verbal phone communications wouldbe a major disaster waiting to happen!!!  Most people talk much louder on their cell phones than normal face-to-face dialog.  Being next to anyone talking on their cell phones is bad enough but in airliners it would be ludicrous.  My personalexperiences being seated near passengers using the outdated seatback phones was bad enough.  I watched numerousverbal arguments and one actual physical brawl over this issue over the many years of flying.Another issue is the unintentional/accidental breach of personal confidential proprietary etc. information. I call it the "nosey neighbor" problem.  There could be some interesting lawsuit implications... Only SILENT use of mobile devices should be allowed!!!
docketTitle: Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft
title: Comment from Larry Donaldson

commentText: I am commenting on DOT-OST-2014-0002.  Do NOT allow passenger cell phone use on any airline carriers domestic or international.  It is an invasion of privacy not only for fellow passengers being subjected to listening to nonsense that could wait till landing but also for the caller.  I do not want to hear the one-sided superficial blather.  There would be no difference if it was a short or long flight it would still be obnoxious and distracting. Most passengers bring things with them to occupy their time  (work books etc) or sleep. It is optional if we chose to speak with our seatmates.   I have no problem with those who use their cellphones as we taxi to the arrival gate to arrange pick up because soon I will be away from them.
docketTitle: Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft

commentText: I am totally for the proposed ruling to not permit the use of mobile phone calls during a flight at any time. Thank you.

commentText: I propose that wireless devices for voice calls on aircraft be banned.  We travel often and are very annoyed at having to listen to other people speak loudly on their cell phones.Thank you.

title: Comment from Sue Petru

commentText: I strongly object to allowing the use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft.  The atmosphere on aircraft is already a stressful environment with very little personal space.  Allowing voice calls will subject passengers to additional stress and will lead to the elimination of what little personal space remains (the person next to you is already practically sitting on yourlap shoulders rubbing and there head within inches of yours).  Allowing voice calls would also increase passenger on passenger or worst passenger on flight crew violence resulting in possible injuries lawsuits and flight schedule disruptions due to diversions.Over the years I have flown for business leisure as well as for family emergencies.  There has never been a time where I couldn't wait at 2-4 hours to contact someone.  If someone feels that they are so important they can't be out of contact for 2-4 hours they can take a flight with a stop or utilize private/corporate aircraft.I urge you to allow the air traveling public to retain what little personal space and privacy remains and NOT ALLOW THE USE OF MOBILE WIRELESS DEVICES FOR VOICE CALLS on aircraft.  Thank You.
docketTitle: Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft
title: Comment from Harold Carter

commentText: No - no voice calls on airplanes.Concerning the consideration of wireless calls on aircraft NO.  This would be an infringement on the non callers rights of quiet enjoyment and they would be subjected to the callers side of the phone call.  The non callers would have no ability to leave the area of the call to get away from the call or to enjoy a peaceful flight.This is a very bad idea and will only lead to confrontations lawsuits safety issues and potential physical confrontations in the airplaneNow if the question was to enable texting perhaps as that would not directly affect others on the plane.

On a plane...We have no place to go no place to get away from the constant loud chatter of many cell phone users. Keep it at that.

title: Comment from Sue Glader

commentText: The use of cell phones should be restricted on commercial air flights. However it is not the place of the Department of Transportation ("DOT" or the "Department") to impose this restriction. Airlines - operating in the free-market - should have the ability to decide their own policies on the use of mobile wireless devices on their aircrafts. The proposed rule of requiring sellers of air transportation to provide advance notice to passengers if the flight allows voice calls is just and will actively prohibit unfair and deceptive practices in air transportation.The Advanced Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (ANPRM) issued by the Department in 2014 was met with 96 percent of commenters opposed to allowing voice calls on airplanes. This overwhelming majority of opinion clearly demonstrates the public sentiment against the use of voice calls on commercial flights. Airlines that ignore these statistics will find themselves struggling to sell tickets. All domestic airlines are aware of this consequence since they currently do not allow the use of voice calls on their flights even though there is no federal restriction prohibiting it. Thus there is no reason for the federal government to issue such a regulation banning voice calls if the airline market is already regulating itself on this matter. However if a commercial airline were to allow voice calls the airline should alert the consumer prior to purchasing a ticket. There is no room for debate on this issue as it directly falls under 49 U.S.C. 41712. This code states that an airline cannot be "deceptive or unfair" in its operations. The overwhelming majority of consumers do not support the use of voice calls on flights. Therefore in not alerting a consumer that a particular flight allows voice calls the airline is deceiving the consumer into the purchase of a ticket. The information gap between the airline and the consumer is deceptive and unfair and would be grounds for prosecution under 40 U.S.C. 41712. Not alerting a passenger in advance that the flight they are taking allows the use of wireless devices to make voice calls puts them in an unfair position. Such a passenger would find themselves stuck on a flight that they would never have boarded. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has very strict regulations on the ability to get on and off an aircraft. If a consumer unknowingly gets on an aircraft that allows the unlimited use of voice calls this puts the consumer in a situation that has the potential to cause emotional distress and increase levels of "air rage." Air rage has the ability to cause widespread disruption on an airplane so much so that it can disturb the pilot and potentially cause the cancellation of a flight. One of the most extreme examples of air rage recently occurred when a passenger on a plane had an emotional breakdown due to Ivanka Trump being on his flight. The air rage became so prevalent that the distressed individual had to be escorted off the plane causing the flight to be delayed for many hours. This same problem could easily occur from disturbing phone calls. These types of situations could be avoided if the airline alerts its passengers of special circumstances having to do with a flight including the ability to make voice calls. Nevertheless I believe there is a strong difference between the allowance of voice calls and "inbound listen only" calls. Airlines should be willing to allow listen only calls and should not be required to alert consumers of this allowance. An inbound listen call is synonymous to listening to music or watching a video on an aircraft. If the consumer is participating in a conference call - with the use of headphones and does not need to reciprocate any information back to the call - I can find no difference between such actions and listening to a podcast or song. The proposed regulation states that the cost of such legislation would be $41 million to airline carriers between 2017 and 2026. Ticket revenue for airlines in 2017 is expected to be over $10 billion. Thus the cost of complying with this new rule would be a rounding error for airlines. Such a miniscule cost should not be a deterrent to the DOT in passing this new rule. On the other hand the costs of not passing such a regulation could be substantial. These costs would be comprised of lawsuits by airline customers who claim to have been emotionally injured by these unsuspecting calls. In summary I am fully in support of the proposed rule by the Department that would force airlines to provide advance notice to their customers if their flight allows voice calls. I also support the airline's power to decide on their own whether or not to allow the use of voice calls on their flights. Airlines should be able to conduct their business as they see fit as long as they do so in a safe fair and transparent manner.
docketTitle: Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft
title: Comment from Jonathan Fried

commentText: This is the reason we just elected a new president!!! We want less rules and regulations not more!! title: Comment from David Gaines

commentText: When I book travel I often use comparison websites to search and purchase airline tickets.  I rely on the convenience of finding all my options on one screen.  Plus when airlines know their fares will be listed next to their competitors they will be more likely to offer a competitive price. It's come to my attention that some airlines are trying to make it harder for me to see all my options by restricting certain websites from publishing fare and schedule information. They shouldn't get to pick and choose who can share information that's already publicly available.  We need more transparency in the marketplace not less.
docketTitle: Exploring Industry Practices on Distribution and Display of Airline Fare, Schedule, and Availability Information
title: Comment from Sue Myers
