commentText: Eld's. So all say they are safer! Well if you look at the numbers they are NOT safer. Yes the compliance rate has gone up but so has the ACCIDENTS on are highways. So i ask whats is more IMPORTANT SAFETY OR COMPLIANCE? I say SAFETY is more important. Yes some will stop to take a nap and still log as they didn't but they stopped cause there body was saying hay stop for a second and take a break or there waiting for traffic to lighten up and travel with less stress and worrying about what the car or even what the other truck driver may do. I do run an eld and i do admit i drive a 100% different on it than i would if didn't sit and star at a 14hr clock that counting down right in front of me. Also i feel it should be up to the companies if they use them or not. Cause its a gps unit so I would like to know how a person is able to be tracked without there approval or a court order. and if there's a court order they better right one for every single driver out here on the nations highway. We as truck drivers are the nations back bone and we all have rights also. WE ARE NOT AND AGAIN NOT A ROBOT!!!!!!! That is what an eld turns a person into is a robot. Everybody's  has different time clocks WE ALL ARE NOT THE SAME.    Are nation isn't ready for this mandate no matter how long is't been delayed already.. the coast of living is going to be through the roof cause somebody's going to have help pay for the install cost and the monthly fees that go along with this mandate. The mega companies all get these brakes on pricing and parts and fees cause they buy mass amounts at once. But what about the company that only has 5 truck or so how they supposed to afford it they cant. So slowly but surely the small guy will have to sell out or just up and close there doors. Those people worked hard to get what they have and just like that is all taken away. They mega guys just enjoy being BULLY"S and want to take over and think we'll want to work for them. they can think again. The mega companies need to stop the CDL mills and actually train there drivers and not just put them on the road in a couple of weeks and with in 6 months think that same driver can train. SAFETY START WITH TRAINING AND NOT PEOPLE JUST LOOKING TO FILL A SEAT. ATA DOESN'T AND AGAIN DOESN'T REPRESENT THE HARD WORK TRUCK DRIVER ALL THEY WANT IS THE SMALL COMPANIES GONE. WHEN IF CLOSE A FEW COMPANIES THAT THEY REPRESENT ARE HIGHWAYS WOULD BE SAFER AND LIVES SAVED. ITS ALL IN THE NTSB FINDINGS. LOOK AT THE NUMBERS!!!ELD'S SHOULD BE A CHOICE NOT A MANDATE!!!!

commentText: Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration  DOT-OST-2017-0069   [ELD] Electronic Logging Device49 CFR 395 Subpart BELD mandate $2 billion cost that will financially hurt and or bankrupted owner operators and small family run trucking companies. I have been an owner operator for 36 years safe accident free years yet I will be forced to install a federal govt. mandated electronic tracking device in my truck even tho I have not broke one single law. I have proven this in the last 36 years that I am a safe owner operator/driver. I am being punished for not committing a crime. FMCSA said ELDs are for safety if thats true FMCSA should be enforcing this mandate only on drivers and companies that are braking the law that is how the law is suppose to work here in the USA. It takes a court order to electronically track a criminal but not a truck driver. The $2 billion cost will come out of the owner operators and small family trucking companies pockets. I would have installed an ELD years ago if it was about safety and earning a better living its not its already causing stress and anxiety in my life. I cant take on any more cost with out profiting from it. The $2 billion mandate is no different then putting a $2 billion tax on the middle class the middle class will be paying for it they just haven't felt it yet. Repeal or delay this costly mandate H.R. 3282 Thanks
docketTitle: Notice of Regulatory Review
title: Comment from B Taylor

commentText: FMCSA docket DOT-OST-2017-0069The ELD mandate as written in 49CFR 395 subpart B is not going to do a thing to improve highway safety.  What it will do is cost billions to implement and a billion dollars a month in user fees.  As long as the device is only capable of recording when the vehicle is moved and only when it is moved that is the only part of the record that can be sure to be accurate. ON Duty. Off duty and sleeper berth time can easily be and are regularly falsified by drivers using elds. The agency claims 26 lives will be saved per year. You could save twice as many by pulling the operating authority of any of the top 3 mega carriers on the accidents per 10k miles traveled list. When your own stats show that cars cause over 80% of car vs truck accidents are caused by cars I believe you are 100% focused on the wrong drivers.  I honestly see no chance that the savings in lives and injuries will happen because your own stats show accident rates climbing the last several years and eld usage has been climbing at the same time. Speaking personally I have been using an eld for 18 months now. In my 22 year career I have never felt more rushed been more stressed or been less patient with either the general public or my fellow drivers.As for things that could actually solve a few of these issues lets start with driver training. There is no reason that mega carriers should be getting waivers for learners permit holders to drive a cmv unsupervised. NONE. The same carriers getting these waivers are turning out dangerously undertrained operators to use the same roads our families use. There should be a minimum number of driving hours logged AFTER being licensed before a driver can operate a tractor trailer alone. An apprenticeship program if you will.  Second the split sleeper berth provision in the current HOS is nearly useless as written. Requiring 8 continuous hours in the sleeper to use it means for me sleeping 5-6 hours then staring at the walls till the clock says it is ok to work again.  Most drivers I know haven't slept 8 hours at a time in decades. For most of us a split of 6-4 or 5-5 or 7-3 would actually work and allow us to do common sense things like stop and rest to miss rush hour or wait out a heavy rain storm. Coupled with a 14 hour clock that only a minimum 8 hour stop can pause the current regulation tie drivers hands and force us to operate in more risky conditions rather than allow us to make decisions based on years of experience and sound judgement.Last the "safety advocates" you bring into the rulemaking process seem to fall into only a few categories.  Groups funded by mega carriers looking to squash the small businessman groups funded by railroads looking to put all trucking at a competitive disadvantage and groups that sell hardware and services that the regulation would require looking to make a buck.  The ATA doesn't speak for drivers. They speak for our corporate overlords who want to track our every move but want to be able to say "we don't want to have to track you but the government makes us". What you seek to require is a level of tracking the courts don't allow to be used on convicted felons without a warrant yet we are charged with no crime. We are not criminals we are hard working family men and women. No one wants highway safety more than us. No one spends more time on those highways than us and we all want to live.
docketTitle: Notice of Regulatory Review
title: Comment from Patrick Valenti

commentText: FMCSA needs to focus on common sense solutions for driver safety and for the motoring public. Minimum training standards need to be enforced for all companies especially those with their own driving schools which need to be eliminated.  Along with mega carriers being able to self insure. Those three things would eliminate many accidents involving trucks. Many of which are due to smaller cars and inexperienced drivers. Furthermore if FMCSA is persistent in pursuing electronic logging devices there will be a federal lawsuit over our rights to not be tracked electronically since they have no warrant and we are not under suspicion of a crime. If FMCSA is serious about changing hours of service both to suit drivers needs and the safety of the public they need to eliminate the 14 hour call on our clock and go back to allowing split sleeper birth times. This eld mandate does nothing for safety and is nothing more than a blatant overreach of federal regulation and ATA funded theivery. If FMCSA is serious about safety then start passing common sense regulations. The current state of affairs is a joke.

title: Comment from Julie Hatter

commentText: I am co owner of a small family owned trucking company that has less than 15 trucks. We have a combined 60 years of trucking experience between my partner and myself.  With all this experience we cannot determine how the ELD mandate will increase safety at all!! or save ONE life.  this mandate is another example of big business trucking pushing their will on the entire trucking industry.  We have seen with the flawed CSA scoring system that the industry is not a one size fits all.  This mandate is putting undo burden and expense on small business owners to do exhaustive research and training in an industry that is already chocked full of regulations.     Every stat the FMCSA comes up with is created to fit their agenda.  The real stats should be taken from the small business' across the country that rely solely on themselves to practice safety thus ensuring a job for their families.    This mandate along with the self insured capabilities of the mega carriers will push many hard working groups out of the industry in turn monopolizing trucking over time.  This mandate infringes on my first amendment right of free speech as I can communicate my compliance of hours of service on paper instead of electronically.. I  feel that this mandate will bring numerous lawsuits to the courts as it infringes on  many constitutional rights of every driver.  aside from all the legalities of this ridiculous mandate ITS JUST NOT FAIR!!  tell me how you can lump a single owner op barely feeding his family into the same group as a multi million dollar carrier.  WAKE UP.  let america prosper and work.  SAFETY is at the forefront of every driver on the road.  In my opinion this mandate should be delayed 2 years and during that time the hours of service should be addressed.   please listen to the groups of working people

commentText: The ELD is a bad idea forcing DRIVERS to sleep and work by a forced clock is NOT the way to be safe. Everyone has different sleep patterns and no one rule can change that or make it safer. The ELD violates privacy rights as the supreme court themthemselves has ruled on per tracking without a warrant.  I think SELF insurers should be done away with so the DOT can see the real accident RATES of companies not just the ones they choose to report. This is a revenue problem that the large companies are trying to solve through the lobbying of the ATA (just look at their 5 yr annua revenuel reports) none of which have any experience behind the wheel of a semi truck. I mind you it all looks good on paper but at some point practical applicati9j has to take the place of information and the real world application does not account for all of the daily hurdles faced in the industry. There are also questions of safety and the ability to be hacked as the University of Michigan pointed out in a study done where they were able to control the trucks wirelessless while the driver was driving.  This could be the single largest threat to the US in a way like no other the scenarios are endless and very disturbing to think about. More truck WITH ELDS WRECK THAN WITHOUT them which was also proven by the DOT data. You want safety then correct the environment the drivers have to work in. Correct the class D DRIVERS abilities and make test more thorough to pass and require more conditions to be set. The Class D DRIVERS have no skill to control or maintain when in danger nor do they understand the danger they put everyone else in.
docketTitle: Notice of Regulatory Review
title: Comment from Damon Sorrells

commentText: The ELD mandate is first of all a violation of my property rights as a Motor Carrier.  The Hours of Service should be placed upon the drivers and not the equipment.  It is amazing that the FMCSA has decided that without looking into the possibility of my equipment being hacked and controlled that they have required these wireless devices to be placed on our equipment.  Not only do you desire to have them placed upon our equipment creating a dangerous environment that is beyond my control you expect my company to pay for the ELD's.  Why do you want access to more information than needed?  You can accomplish an ELD program without attaching to our equipment ECM's then there would be no violation of my property ownership rights otherwise you are infringing upon my rights for property ownership and using the information for public use without any compensation for such.  This is a violation of Amendment 5 of the Constitution of the United States.I wonder why the FMCSA wants to track the ECM and actions of my equipment?  Should you not be wanting to just stay focused on the drivers and HOS issues.  It is the DOT officers job to inspect the safety and quality of my equipment not an electronic tracking device.  I would much rather have human eyes on my equipment vs electronic eyes.  Human eyes can see things that are dangerous to the motoring public that the ELD or ECM will never see.  ELD's in effect is not fixing the safety issues that run amuck on our highways.  Better training and cutting subsidies to the Mega-Carriers for their substandard training programs would be a better start.  When we encourage companies to put out a puppy mill style training program and give them exemptions for doing such along with government kickbacks in the form of subsidies we then know why we have the problems that we currently have.Let us talk about HOS for a second.  The current HOS is a joke to say the least.  Drivers should have the choice for flexible hours of service this will allow them to adjust their 11/14 hour day within reason.  Which driver is safer?  The one that runs 11/14 straight through day after day?  The driver that would be allowed to split their shift as follows 7 hours working 3 hours off 7 hours working 7 hours off.  What about this driver?  5 hours working 5 hours off 5 hours working 5 hours off.  I believe by allowing drivers the opportunity to pause their working clock as the environment allows will help keep drivers from running stressed and fatigued.  Drivers will make better decisions as to when they should run in rush hours conditions or weather conditions.  Not all drivers are alike the FMCSA along with their friends at the ATA seems to believe that making drivers prisoners in a box is the answer.  This is idiotic to say the least it would be like telling all Americans starting Dec 18 2017 everybody needs to sleep and work the exact same time or telling everybody that they must wear the same size clothes or they would be punished.  The FMCSA has been doing this for years without even acknowledging their own statistical reports.  Just what in the heck are we spending all this money for?  If you do not even pay attention to your own studies.There should be no exceptions to the rules regardless of company size.  Why are we running a skewed CSA system instead of showing the public the true accidents and Haz-mat violations.  It sure seems that the current ELD mandate HOS and system are rigged in the favor of the Mega-Carrier.  Spending money on studies that can be fixed with the true stakeholders involved would result in a safer industry.  Small Motor Carriers deserve representation and involvement with the FMCSA on these issues.  We would like to have an equal voice in the regulations that affect our industry.  I would prefer to work with the FMCSA instead of against them too bad they do not seem to feel the same.  See you in court later next year FMCSA.Summary:The ELD needs to be on the drivers and not the equipmentA flexible hours of service plan needs to be addressed that uses logic and safety as the foremostRequiring a better training plan for new drivers needs to be establishedThere should be no exceptions to the rules regardless of company sizeWe need to show the accident and Hazmat violations once again instead of the skewed CSA scoring systemWorking together willingly with the FMCSA would be preferred by the majority of small motor carriers vs. working against one anotherThe FMCSA does not have the right to violate property ownership rights of any citizen of the United States.  Why are they doing so?

commentText: The ELD mandate The FMCSA has not shown actual.proof that ELD'S are safer.Most of The ATA members Trucking Companies that have The ELD'S  when driving rush speed through truck stops construction zones and small rural towns....very unsafe...they are playing " beat the clock".I wish I could upload actual videos from The ATA Companies that Use The ELD'S from my 3 camera dash cam that I have saved on my hard drive videos the public would.love to see...most people I have shown them to shake their head...and ask why are they driving that WAY.BY THE WAY IT HAS BEEN PROVEN FOR YEARS THAT THE MAJORITY OF SMALL TRUCKING BUSINESS'S OPERATE SAFER . WITHOUT THE ELD'S THAN ALMOST ALL OF THE BIG FLEETS USING THE ELD'S. A VERY LARGE PERCENTAGE OF SERIOUS ACCIDENTS INVOLVING ATA MEMBERS COMPANIES USING THE ELD'S ARE PROVEN TO BE INVOLVED IN ACCIDENTS AS COMPARED TO SMALLER TRUCKING COMPANIES THAT ARE NOT UTILIZING THE ELD'S.    I'm an single truck Owner Operator small business owner with approx 1 million miles no accidents no Out of Service's for HOS I do not haul general freight and run odd hours ( not by my choice) to safely haul my customers freight  from remote areas to large metro cities throughout the The Lower 48 States.An another small BUSINESS owner I work.with has 48 trucks at approx $1000.00 a truck to install an ELD in.every truck that is  approx $48000.00 ....quite an expense that we both agree is not wanted or needed.....that's $48000.00 that be could put back his business to expand his operation.I DON'T KNOW HOW TO STRESS THAT I DO NOT NEED THE COST OF AN ELD THE MONTHLY FEES...I DON'T NEED TO TRACK MY LOCATION ( MY CUSTOMER'S USE GPS LOCATORS ON THEIR FREIGHT SO THEY KNOW WHERE I'M AT AS WELL AS THEIR FRIEGHT....).....AND I DON'T SEE ANY BENEFIT AT ALL WHAT AN ELD WOULD DO FOR ME. I'M ORGANIZED AD NOT MIS-MANAGED ........NOT MIS MANANGED LIKE MOST OF THE ATA TRUCKING COMPANY MEMEBERS.THE FINANCIAL LOSS IF INVOLVED IN AN ACCIDENT  THE RISK OF BEING PUT COMPLETELY PUT OUT OF SERVICE BY THE FMCSA....THE LAWSUITS...THE FINES.....ARE.JUST NOT FINANCIALLY WORTH IT  TO RUN FREIGHT ILLEAGALLY  BEYOND THE CURRENT HOS THESE DAYS....MOST OWNER OPERATORS DO NOT RUN BEYOND THEIR 11 AND 14 HOURS !!!!!BOTTOM LINE IS.:1) THE ATA members Trucking Companies need the ELD'S due.to their high driver turnover their disorganized manner in which they operate and their mis- managed scheduling of their freight movement..2) THE ATA MEMBERS COMPANIES HAVE STOCK OWNERSHIP IN.THE.COMPANIES THAT MANUFACTURE THE ELD'S.....MOST WILL FINANCIALY BENEFIT GREATLY IF AND WHEN ELD MANDATE GOES THROUGH. THATS WHAT THE ATA.WANTED IT MANDATED.3) THE ELD'S SHOULD BE A CHOICE NOT FORCED...THE ELD'S WILL NOT WORK FOR THE.MANY DIFFERENT  VAST TYPES OF TRUCKING OPERATIONS.4) THS ATA IS NOT MY VOICE NOR IS THE VOICE FOR MANY SMALL TO MEDIUM TRUCKING COMPANIES...5) THE ELD MANDATE VIOLATES SEVERAL CONSTITUTIONAL RIGHTS WHICH MOST SMALL BUSINESS OWERS DO NOT AGREE WITH.6) THERE ISN'T ENOUGH PARKING NOW EAST OF I-35 AS SOON AS THE ELD'S CLOCK RUNS OUT .for these drivers ..THERE PROBABLY WILL EVEN LESS PARKING AVAILABLE.THS ELD MANDATE SHOULD BE A CHOICE NOT A REQUIREMENT...JUST BECAUSE THE ATA GOT.IT MANDATED FOR FINANCIAL REASONS  not safety.reasons....IS NOT ACCEPTABLE.

title: Comment from Michael  Siegfried

commentText: This ELD system has the potential to be very effective and beneficial to the industry. But right "now" it is foolish to force this upon us.1) It is costing small business and owner operators a larger headache than mega carriers are having to face. Mega carriers brought ELDs upon their own heads by abusing the system and pushing their drivers too hard. We should not be punished for their criminal activities. The FMCSA following the ATAs bidding at this point is pathetic.2) This new ELD system not only can but certainly will introduce cyber security vulnerabilities to the network/transportation grid that will be used by our enemies to cause confusion and even paralysis of logistics and Hours of Service recording. At the push of a button viruses can be introduced into the system crippling it for days weeks months at a time. If you don't listen to what I'm trying to explain I would like to assure the FMCSA that they will be forced to observe it when competing nations like Russia India China and North Korea wreak havoc on the backbone of United States industry. And when it happens the American people will know you were warned and chose to move forward with this recklessness anyway.3) The ELD installation and operation itself comes with a sharp learning curve for some of our most experienced professional senior drivers and it is going to push many of them out of the industry by frustration and lack of technical knowledge alone. We NEED these drivers not only to keep this nation supplied and breathing but their skill in operating these vehicles needs to be handed down to the next generations. Why do ANYTHING that would force them out? This is irrresponible and again the consequences are not being considered here.4) You are setting the stage to be sued in Federal Court because of your unwillingness to listen to contradicting opinion on this matter by the people who matter most in it. This is not becoming of a democratic society. In fact this is not only compiling information on the activities of the American people it is also an invasion of privacy. I pay for this truck. It is my personal property and an extension of my home. The Constitution of the United States expressly forbids what the FMCSA is inflicting upon my person my rights and my way of life.5) Finally these ELDs add yet another twist of pressure to make driving commercial vehicles as much a pain as humanly possible. The corporate effort of the ATA is to gradually push human priority out of the operation of these trucks and introduce "autonomous technology" to fill in for a "driver shortage" that THEY created. And they are doing this to dodge liability in the industry reduce the money they spend on payroll and benefits and effectively increase their profits while turning our highways into a nightmare.Respectfully if the FMCSA doesn't want to be held 100% accountable for this when it comes to light (and in today's political climate it WILL come to light) then I suggest they stop playing the part of the ATA's lobby-tools and start cracking down on said companies of the ATA for an attack on American industry; an attack designed to further secure corporate monopolies and intentionally drive millions of citizens out of work.These highways are in our blood. These cities are our people. These trucks and supplies are this nation's backbone. The FMCSA can help us secure and protect these jobs and this way of life or the FMCSA can help the enemy destroy them.P.S. if you think the concept of cyber vulnerabilities against ELDs are far fetched just wait until you've got a million hacked robotic trucks on the interstates. Somebody had better start thinking with their brains on this issue instead of their wallets.

title: Comment from Damien Nelson

commentText: US Department of Transportation DOT-OST-2017-0069A truck Owner-Operator's place of business is also a home. A home based business.It is unreasonable to treat law abiding truck owners as criminals in their own home.   ELD mandatory use is an inappropriate use of technology to intimidate truck drivers and owners. The intimidation is from the supervisors of the loads being moved and the law enforcement monitoring the roads being used to transport the loads. The truck driver is at fault without protection. The ELD can be manipulated to the benefit of the accuser or the prosecutor. The driver has no ability to make edits. The systems are not universally compliant. It is reasonable to believe the rights of the truck driver and operator have been violated.The ELD devices are overwhelmingly flawed:1- Driver and motoring public at more risk with forced tired driving.2- Intimidation of drivers from law and work authoritative representatives.3- Violation of rights.4- Security risks with malware and hacking.5- Drivers safety when stopped Hacked info of commodities easier for criminals to locate valuable loads.6- Drivers safety when moving Vehicle components vulnerable to sabotage.7- Motoring public impediments due to forced parking along roadway shoulders off ramps and any wide spot.8- Driver freedom of choice to make common sense decisions regarding traffic weather or any other foreseeable hazards.Definition from Nolo's Plain-English Law DictionaryA search and seizure by a law enforcement officer without a search warrant and without probable cause to believe that evidence of a crime is present. Such a search or seizure is unconstitutional under the Fourth Amendment (applied to the states by the Fourteenth Amendment) and evidence obtained from the unlawful search may not be introduced in court. Definition provided by Nolo's Plain-English Law Dictionary.

commentText: I beg for inclusion of the following article appeared in yesterday's WashingtonPost succinctly linking a death to the current legalized system of cheap"involuntary denied boarding".  I am requesting a waiver of the deadline forcomments as such death precipitated by the rules being addressed in thisDocket took place after the first comment period closed. In addition I petition the DOT to stop allowing "involuntary denied boarding":airlines should be held to the same standards of any other business includingcontract law and customer protection. If an airline wishes to overbook economic damage should dictate how much tocompensate fliers whose contracts have been unilaterally breached.The death of Carol Anne Gotbaum should energize everyone at the DOT to make thesituation right for flyers to come.Washington PostA DEATH FORETOLDWhy Flying Now Can KillBy A.L. BardachSunday October 14 2007; Page B01 I am haunted by the death of Carol Anne Gotbaum.I didn't know the mother of three who died shackled to a bench in the Phoenixairport on Sept. 28 en route to an alcohol treatment center in Tucson. I don'tknow beyond what I read in the newspapers what troubles weighed on her. But Ido know this: Based on my own recent flight experiences hers was a death foretold.There's every reason to believe that Gotbaum would be alive today if she hadbeen allowed to board her flight to Tucson and take her rightful seat. While hertragedy has been a Page One story in many newspapers few reports have focusedon the fact that the airlines involved US Airways and its subcontractor MesaAirlines are notorious for overbooked flights. According to the New York TimesUS Air had revenue last year of $11.56 billion. Of that $1 billion was theresult of diligent overbooking.The stressful often incendiary situations created by overbooking infuriateperfectly healthy well-adjusted passengers. It's not hard for me to imaginethat an emotionally fragile vulnerable person like Gotbaum could have feltabsolutely desperate.Gotbaum wasn't late for boarding. She didn't forfeit her place by ignoring theairline's procedures. Her only mistake was showing up at the US Airways gate andbelieving that her paid-in-full reserved-seat airline ticket meant that shewould actually have a seat on the plane.We made the same mistake. In May I was to give a speech in Washington. I wasrecovering from a health problem so I asked my husband to accompany me on thetrip. A plane ticket was purchased for me on US Air. It wasn't a cheap ticket;together the cost of our flights came to close to $1500.Bob and I had never flown US Air before and we just laughed when the friend whodropped us off at the Santa Barbara airport barked "Don't do it. It's the worstairline in the history of aviation." But then we saw the long snaking lines atthe counter which was attended by just two employees.When we finally reached the counter a half-hour later the ticket agent told usthat the plane had been overbooked and that there were no seats for us. Iexplained that I had an appointment in Washington and was also dealing with ahealth issue. To our surprise the staff who seemed exhausted and overwroughtwere not especially sympathetic: The flight was overbooked they said andthat's all there was to it.What I didn't know then but learned later is that many of US Air's flights aresubcontracted to the ultra-economy Mesa Airlines. Both Mesa and US Air are basedin Arizona and Mesa we would learn is famous for its penny-pinchingunderstaffing ways. My husband and I as well as Carol Gotbaum were dealingwith Mesa personnel although the airport signs were for US Airways.Initially we were told that we were being denied boarding because we had boughtour tickets on the Internet. But that wasn't true. Then the counter person saidthat we were the last to check in when in fact there were half a dozen peoplebehind us -- also with reserved seats. Finally one staffer leveled with us andsaid: "Look they [US Air] overbook all of our flights." Not only could we notget on our flight but the next flight was also overbooked and the one afterthat. There was simply no guarantee that we'd be able to get out that day.Other passengers stepped up to help. Three people who were traveling on vacationoffered to switch with us preferring to get a free plane ticket forvolunteering to be bumped. But we watched incredulously as the Mesa counterpersonnel talked each one out of switching with us. Much the same thing happenedto Carol Gotbaum.A great deal has been made of the fact that she was on her way to an alcoholrehab center but no one has come forward to say they saw her drinking that day.The only difference between her and us was our reaction. We didn't lose controlbut we were plenty steamed. When we learned that all the flights had beenoverbooked my husband confronted the counter staff while I sat down and cried.That's why I can imagine the desperation the situation would evoke in someonewho was ill disabled or distraught. I only had to get to Washington for aconference; Carol Gotbaum's health and life depended on her getting to Tucson.We eventually made it to Washington after Mesa/US Air dispatched us to anotherairport 100 miles away in a speeding taxi. The experience however stayed withus for a long time afterward especially as we experienced more overbookingproblems -- as well as lost luggage delays and rerouted flights -- on every legof our trip to and from Washington.At various airports I interviewed any US Air/Mesa staffers who would talk tome. On one flight segment we sat with several Mesa/US Air staff members and apilot and heard quite an earful. This small group said that to increaseprofitability Mesa understaffs all its sales counters baggage staff and otherpersonnel and slashed health care and pensions while US Air overbooks allflights and often issues duplicate seat assignments. We learned that the staffand the pilots were virtually at war with Mesa's chief executive JonathanOrnstein. We listened as one flight attendant told us that they have schemed anddreamed of "flying over his home and dropping the lavs" referring to theairplanes' toilets. The pilot told us they were terribly underpaid andoverworked and that flying conditions were unsafe. Some pilots he said madeonly $19000 a year and did not have adequate training.Other staffers told us that many US Air/Mesa personnel were dispirited andoverworked which often led them to vent their frustration on passengers in asort of "kick the dog" syndrome especially in Phoenix. One flight attendantsaid she had once seen five people arrive a few minutes late at the Phoenixcounter and be denied the right to board even though the flight attendants andpilot were willing to allow them on. In this rare case the plane was notoverbooked and the passengers' seats were available. Still the counter staffwouldn't let them board.Some of what we heard from such disgruntled personnel was later confirmed in theNew York Times. On May 30 the newspaper ran an article looking behind thescenes at the airline practice of overbooking in which US Air figuredprominently. It quoted a US Airways official as saying that employees called insick because they didn't want to deal with overbookings and a Boston gate agentcomplained "You know you're going to be yelled and screamed at to the point youhave to call the police."But what about the passengers? US Air has said that it gave away Gotbaum's seaton a connecting flight because she arrived at the gate with only 25 minutes --instead of 30 -- to spare. But she had already checked in for that flight atJohn F. Kennedy airport in New York. You don't have to check in again in theconnecting city as I understand US Air's regulations. The rules as posted onthe airline's Web site also state "Reservations are subject to cancellation ifyou are not checked in and at the departure gate at least 15 minutes prior todeparture." Gotbaum was still covered. She'd left 25 minutes to spare.Still she was denied her reserved seat on the 1:30 flight. Nor did they allowher to board the next flight at 2:58 -- which of course was also overbooked.Finally Mesa's counter personnel refused to let willing passengers switch withthe clearly distraught Gotbaum. When she began to weep and protest they calledthe police who handcuffed her arms behind her back and dragged her away to aholding cell. They left her chained alone to a bench crying inconsolably. Notlong after she was found dead the chain shackling her to the bench stretchedacross her throat.Surely US Air/Mesa employees aren't bad people. They're doing their jobs --understaffed and underpaid -- in an industry with seemingly no oversight oraccountability.My husband and I didn't just get mad we got even. Upon our return to SantaBarbara we filed a complaint in small claims court for $7500 the maximumallowed. US Air settled with us in June.Carol Gotbaum's family may be getting ready to sue too. But it's too late for her.bardachreports@aol.com
docketTitle: Air Transport Association of America, Inc. - Petition for Rulemaking
title: Anonymous

commentText: March 9 2009 Hon. Ray LaHoodSecretary of TransportationU.S. Department of Transportation1200 New Jersey Avenue S.E.CORRECTEDWashington D.C. 20590Subject:Comments of Aviation Consumer Action Project on NPRM‰ЫПEnhancing Airline Passenger Protections‰ЫќReference:14 CFR Parts 234 253 259 and 399Docket No. DOT-OST-2007-0022RIN No. 2105-AD72SUBJECT:The Aviation Consumer Action Project (ACAP) opposes the subject NPRM (Item 1) as an unlawful delegation of DOT authority and responsibility to regulate airlines in the public interest by delegating this function the airlines themselves.  As written it is an anti-consumer regulation that would take away existing common law tort rights of airline passengers for false imprisonment and negligence in situations of long confinements on the tarmac of 3-11 hours that airlines now subject approximately 300000 passengers a year to and substitute an unenforceable contract cause of action.  ACAP supports Items 2-7 of the NPRM. Dear Secretary LaHood:The Aviation Consumer Action Project (ACAP) was founded in 1971 as 501(c ) 3 nonprofit organization that acts as voice for air travelers on issues of safety security and airline consumer rights and interests.  It has held longstanding membership on the FAA Aviation Rulemaking Advisory Committee (ARAC) and the Aviation Security Advisory Committee.  We have testified before Congress on the issues in this NPRM and filed comments with DOT.  I have been executive director of ACAP since 1997 and as an attorney have represented ACAP individual consumers and Flyersrights.org (fka the Coalition for an Airline Passengers Bill of Rights) in the federal and state courts on the issues addressed in this NRPM.1.  Putting Contingency Plans in the Contract of Carriage.This NPRM (1) is a last gasp Bush Administration/Airline Industry effort to turn over DOT regulatory authority to the regulated party.  It would lead to a multiplicity of unenforceable ‰ЫПstandards‰Ыќ and ‰ЫПplans.‰Ыќ  Some airlines already are using a 4 to 6 hour guideline for tarmac confinements.  As there is presently no federal standard state common law standards for negligence and false imprisonment state criminal statutes involving unsafe operation of aircraft and wrongful imprisonment or reckless endangerment and possibly constitutional protections against unreasonable seizure are the only legal protections airline passengers have against indefinite tarmac confinements.  Most airlines now have or claim to have contingency plans to deal with flight disruptions of more than 2 hours.  But they are vague and commonly ignored (e.g. American Airlines has a contingency plan that is supposed to be activated after a 2 hours of delay but it was been found by the OIG to have been ignored and violated repeatedly in a Sept. 2007 report of its 12/29/06 mass diversion and stranding of over 100 flights involving over 10000 passengers).  Such plans are vague and there is nothing in them that a airline passenger can really enforce in a contract action.  Such plans placed in the contract of carriage would just be another way for airlines to absolve themselves of responsibility for long tarmac delays diversions and confinements.These confinements of 3- 11 hours now affect approximately 300000 passengers per year and have led to a national outcry and the formation of a national grass roots organization Flyersrights.org with over 24000 members.  The claims of the Air Transport Association that tarmac confinements have declined are false or at least unproven.  The DOT BTS only recently began collecting these statistics in 2008 and has had to remove the data presented by the airlines as ‰ЫПcorrupted‰Ыќ and therefore unreliable.The proposed regulation would wipe out existing legal protections and in our view would lead to more not less tarmac confinements as each airline would be in effect be able to write its own rule.  Such an unlawful delegation of DOT regulatory authority  would no doubt be challenged in court.   The age of self-regulation and deregulation whether in the financial industry air safety food safety or airline consumer protection is over.  It has been thoroughly discredited by scandals and disasters over the past two years and even rejected by many of its former advocates.  The Obama DOT must reject the mantra of former DOT Secretary Peters that the ‰ЫПmarket‰Ыќ will solve all consumer problems.  Senator and Candidate Obama endorsed airline passenger rights legislation that would outlaw tarmac confinements of over 3 hours which this NPRM would clearly not do.  When an airline passenger brings an action in state court  the airline almost invariably has it removed to federal court on grounds of federal preemption.  The defendant airline will then file a series of motions to have the case transferred to its home state often far from the consumer passenger‰ЫЄs residence.  The cost of such litigation far exceeds the individual claims for ordinary delays or tarmac confinements.  The airlines are generally successful in having such lawsuits dismissed discouraged or abandoned.  Indeed a review of cases under CCH Aviation cases shows that virtually the only breach of contract cases brought under the contracts of carriage successfully involve cargo shipments by commercial shippers.   You can view the many technical defenses Recent cases involving passenger strandings which include  Ray v American Airlines Inc. US DC WD AR 08-5072 Hanni v American Airlines Inc. US DC ND CA 08-732; Harper v American Airlines Inc. US DC ND AL 08-________ (filed 12/29/08); Biscone v JetBlue Airways Corp. NYS SC Queens Co. 3776/2008.  The motions to dismiss or transfer or for summary judgment filed by the airline defendants can be viewed online at Public Access to Court Electronic Records (PACER) or the electronic dockets of the New York State Uniform Court System web site.Under the Class Action Fairness Act of 2005 (CAFA) (perhaps better described as the Consumer Class Action Elimination Act of 2005) nearly all state consumer class actions (which involves any case with a potential total claim over $5 Million) are removed to federal court where the bar is so high for certification that very few consumer class actions have ever been certified since this statute went into effect.  In the 5th Circuit which is the home of American Southwest and Continental Airlines none have been certified.  As to the issue of tarmac confinements only one 1999 case against Northwest Airlines has been certified as a class action to our knowledge and that occurred in Michigan state court involving confinements of up to 9 hours of 4000 passengers prior to the enactment of CAFA. Only through class actions in federal court or in local small claims court is it possible for airline passengers to judicially enforce breach of contract to tort claims that do not involve serious physical injury or death.  And since a class action requires that many passengers be involved with common facts and law only mass stranding events would normally qualify.Some airlines already provide for compensation for delays and associated expenses of overnight lodging in their contracts of carriage but these provisions are not as a practical matter enforceable and are frequently ignored or avoided entirely by airlines coding nearly every delayed or canceled flight as weather or FAA Air Traffic Control related.  There is no effective oversight by DOT and no fines of substance for airline violation of their own contracts or customer service plans or contingency plans or internal policies and none seems likely in the foreseeable future.The NPRM if adopted would mean domestic US airline passengers would have rights inferior to those provided to international passengers under the Montreal Convention of 1999.  Under Art. 19 passengers may recover damages for delay of up to  about $6400 on a near strict liability basis.  An airline to avoid liability has the burden of proving that it took all reasonable steps to avoid the delay or that the delay was impossible to avoid.  Damages include compensation for inconvenience as well as out of pocket losses and this treaty overrides the limitations or exclusions commonly found in domestic airline contracts of carriage which make promises in those contracts largely illusory.  Should NPRM (Item 1) be adopted in any form it should include provisions in domestic contracts of carriage a) requiring payment of litigation expenses of the passenger should s/he substantially prevail in the lawsuit b) be no less favorable to domestic passengers than international passengers c) should specifically authorize suits in state as well as federal courts d) authorize class actions where appropriate with the consumer class representative receiving a reasonable sum in compensation his time and representational responsibilities of the class payment of class notification expenses by the airline defendant plus treble damages or minimum compensation of  four times the ticket price and e) have a hard 3 hour passenger right to deplane plus delay compensation of $10 per minute for on ground confinements over 3 hours. Only with such pro-consumer provisions will airlines have an incentive to change their existing practices of ignoring passenger complaints and claims with impunity or offering only token compensation such as discount coupons or restricted vouchers.Items 2-7.  ACAP has long advocated for Truth in Scheduling regulation as a first line of defense against congestion delays caused by over scheduling by airlines.  These proposed measures are in line with our recommendations and would address the No. 1 airline passenger complaint:  flight delays.   As scheduling has been decontrolled airlines now have incentives to unrealistically schedule flights at popular times for competitive reasons which in turn leads to unnecessary congestion at major choke point airports like NYC and Chicago.  These regulations should allow consumers to avoid chronically delayed flights should eliminate deceptively scheduled flights and help relieve congestion delays at choke point airports. We generally support the comments of Flyersrights.org .    Very truly yourss/Paul S. HudsonExecutive DirectorAviation Consumer Action Project4411 Bee Ridge Road #274Sarasota Florida 34233(410) 940-8934Acapaviation@yahoo.com  PS This is a corrected version of my comments.  Please disregard the earlier version submitted earlier today.
docketTitle: Enhancing Airline Passenger Protections
title: Aviation Consumer Action Project

commentText: Rules concerning how people are chosen to be bumped from a flight are to vague.  No rightful advantage is given to those who have made and paid for a reservation months in advance.  A person can just walk up and buy a ticket on a flight and bump someone making a connection coming 2000 miles away that made and paid for a reservation 4 months earlier.  Procedures should follow first come first serve.  Conecting flights should be given priority as the Carrier has those connecting at a disadvantage - they are forced to wait....  They cannot leave the airport and go home.  Please read the complaint filed with the FAA against Delta Airlines.REF: DELTA TICKET NUMBER 0067978004211 Complaint - Delta Airlines bumped me off this connecting flight from Memphis to Charlotte today 9/16/12 allowing a person that had purchased a ticket the day of the flight with the words SEARCHING FOR A TICKET on the ticket while denying me a seat from a reservation made and paid for four months earlier in May. I would like to know if there are any laws or rules concerning how passengers are chosen to be bumped. Is the date a reservation is made and paid for of any value or weight when an airline choses which passenger is bumped from a flight. Is there a rule or law governing "Bumping"Delta just let someone walk up to their counter and take me and my daughter's seat that we paid for four months earlier and we had to wait seven hours for the next flight. Are you the agency to talk to on this - If not what government agency is????Have the courts ruled on any cases regarding the "Bumping" of passengers.Please give me some advice and direction on how to be reconciled to this treatment. They gave us a $400.00 credit to fly Delta but I don't fly much.Michael HooverBelmont NC 28012704 825 8672

title: Michael Wayne Hoover

commentText: I love the concept of this Family Airline. I believe they have a great businessplan and will be servicing many companies as well as families.  Their choice ofaircraft as it pertains to their vision is quite compelling.  To be able to takeone product and have multiple profit centers such as : cargo carrier food andbeverage in flight for sale entertainment and wireless access are also moneymakers.  They will definitely blow the failing airline companies away in fares. The only request as a consumer is that we the passengers are not treatedlike cattle as is the case of SW airlines.  I have flown with them for theirlower rates but you get what you pay for horrific customer service and boardinglike cattle.  SW over books all of their flights and as a handicapped person Ihappened to be in the bathroom while my cattle group was called ( I have abladder disease) and was told my seat was given away even though my co- ownerand a manager of my business were there they refused to accept that I was inthe bathroom and gave my seat away after being at the airport 2 hours earlychecking luggage getting a cattle boarding pass  and was treated very poorly.In fact we had to file a police report as my partner in business was physicallyassaulted by their boarding pass collectors.  He was just trying to make mycase I was only gone 3 minutes and was not allowed passage.  Instead I wasrouted through Reno and had a 4 hour delay  it was  supposed to be a non stopflight to Portland OR. in 2000. My partner in business was upset by this poortreatment and wrote on the barf bag on the way to Reno that "SW Airlines Bites"and attached it to his shirt. In Reno they deplaned him keep in mind we shouldhave been to Portland long ago at this time and called the police who refusedto arrest him as no crime was committed.  The customer service manager put himunder citizen's arrest and the police had no choice but to take him to the Renosheriff's office.  I deplaned to go bail him out his first and only arrest(quasi as it was a citizen's arrest)  We attended a court hearing in Reno and hewas acquitted immediately as he posed no threat this was pre 9-11.  It cost usover 3000 dollars and we intended to sue and then 9-11 happened and we figuredit would be difficult in the state of high alerts to get a jury trial that mighthave seen his writing on the barf bag as a threat. what a joke.  They kickpeople off for the content of their t- shirts since that time.  Please allowthis family airline to operate as I believe that their business plan is soundand that they would never treat a passenger as we were treated. I have anincurable disease I am handicapped and covered under ADA and they gave my seataway because I had to urinate prior to what could be a long wait for take off. This is well thought out with alternative means of profitibility and as long asthey don't cattle herd the passengers and treat the passengers with one ounce ofrespect they will be my new carrier and my company's.Thank you for your time and please let this company try to beat thecompetition SW is cheap and illegal in their behaviors I will never fly withthem again.  Assigned seats would be nice and double booking should be illegalif someone has purchased the ticket checked in their baggage and were there inplenty of time.  As a matter of fact the people in the last herding made it onbut not me.  ADA discrimination is wrong and SW will go down at some point andtime due to their despicable behavior especially if I have another choice suchas Family Airlines.  Let them enter the market please it is much needed.  It isnot like you get fed on SW but at least on Family Airlines you have theopportunity to purchase food which is really helpful to hypoglycemic customers.  Kindest RegardsGretchen D HarrisManaging PartnerREH Enterprises WA2
docketTitle: Family Airlines Incorporated - Certificate - Interstate Scheduled Air Transportation
title: Gretchen D. Harris

commentText: A far greater emphasis must be given to public transit pedestrian and bicycle transportation provisions. Bicycle and pedestrian provisions are particularly lacking all across America. Until these are in place Americans will have no choice but to drive everywhere even for the over 60% of trips that are 5 miles or less. Many of these trips could easily be replaced by bicycling and walking. America has done well providing for SOV travel. It's time we focus our resources on completing our transportation system with transit pedestrian and bicycle provisions. This should also include maintaining our current SOV provisions rather than building more.
docketTitle: Refocus. Reform. Renew A New Transportation Approach for America
title: Sue Knaup

commentText: The Honorable Mary PetersSecretaryU.S. Department of Transportation1200 New Jersey Ave. SEWashington DC 20590RE: Docket DOT-OST 2008-0252Dear Madam Secretary:Having been furloughed from American Airlines nearly six years and facing the potential of having my rights to return to work expire I am urging you to seek job assurances from American Airlines when considering their application for anti-trust immunity with its   partner British Airways.While other carriers have received anti-trust immunity this one is unique.   American Airlines still has thousands of workers on lay off as a result of its DOT approved merger with TWA and the events of 9/11.These workers deserve to have consideration and assurances they will remain on the recall list in exchange for any immunity granted by the Department of Transportation.I urge you to ensure that any agreements reached include provisions and oversight to protect the interest of these workers in this time of economic uncertainty. Sincerely Karen MarshallFurloughed AA Flight Attendant

commentText: October 14 2010The Honorable Ray H. LaHoodSecretary of TransportationU.S. Department of Transportation1200 New Jersey Avenue S.E.Washington DC 20590RE: Docket OST-2000-7182Dear Secretary LaHood:This letter expresses support for the application of AirTran Airways Inc. for two available Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport (DCA) slots being allocated in Docket OST-2000-7182 to provide nonstop service from Sarasota Bradenton International Airport (SRQ) to DCA.The Sarasota Bradenton area has only one daily nonstop on a regional jet to Washington DC even though it is the sixth largest destination market from this area.  I personally commute to DC regularly to practice law in the United States Court of Federal Claims.With over 750000 residents and our prime location as a leisure destination for tourists SRQ can certainly support additional service and it would be a great help to theTourism industry in this region which suffered a significant impact from the BP oil spill.This new service would also mitigate the negative economic impact the recession has had on the community and the airport.We ask that the slots be awarded to AirTran for utilization to SRQ.Thank you for your consideration.SincerelyJennifer Anne Gore Maglio Esq.

commentText: n December 24 2012.  Key Points Related to DBE NPRM Docket # OST‰ЫТ2012‰ЫТ0147‰ЫўPaperwork and Disclosure Burden:  The NPRM proposes significantly increasing the paperwork burden on DBEs by requiring new disclosure requirements and longer more complex forms.  While we commend the move to require universal use of standardized application and personal net worth (PNW) forms without modification the proposal to significantly increase the paperwork requirements for DBEs is unacceptable.  Our organizations have heard many reports of firms that never get certified and firms that choose to leave the DBE program because the paperwork burden is too great.  There is not sufficient evidence that those who are intent on defrauding the program will be persuaded to act honestly by imposing additional paperwork requirements on all DBEs.  Instead US DOT should aim for a net decrease in the time spent by DBEs to fill out application and PNW forms and a net decrease in the time required by Unified Certification Program (UCP) staff to review and verify the forms.  As a result of such a change UCP staff could focus on monitoring and enforcement of DBE program requirements.  To this end we urge US DOT to:oConsider which new information and documentation is most needed by UCP certifiers and those at US DOT who must review certification appeals.  Ensure that other paperwork requirements or disclosures are reduced or eliminated to result in an application process (and annual no change affidavit process) that represents a net decrease in time spent on paperwork by both DBEs and recipient certification staff.    Spousal PNW forms or annual PNW forms should not be required.  There are other far less burdensome ways to collect this information.oRelease the methodology used as the foundation for the paperwork time estimates included in the NPRM and all methodologies used to calculate paperwork time estimates for any final rule.  oImplement the suggestion of Robert C. Ashby (co
docketTitle: Disadvantaged Business Enterprise: Program Implementation Modifications
title: Harry C. Alford

commentText: The fact is that these requirements are discriminatory towards companies like mine.  I am a white male so you know what I mean.We do most of our work through DBEs HUBs and WBEs - that is we do all of the work and run it through their business.We can hardly get a straight up contract anymore.It is to the point where I either sue the federal government for discrimination or give my company to my retired wife.  I don't have the resources to sue so my company is soon to join the bandwagon of disadvantaged businesses.
docketTitle: Disadvantaged Business Enterprise: Program Implementation Modifications
title: Robert Fisher Fly

commentText: With respect to paper work and disclosure burdenthe government should collect and disseminate best practices for collecting and investigating allegations of fraud and program noncompliance.  Additional paperwork requests should be targeted toward those firms that are suspected of seeking to defraud the program at the time a problem is detected not imposed on the vast majority of DBEs who are honestly seeking to comply with all program requirements. It is extremely costly for legitimate minority business to  appeal deals because he/she hires professional license holder to handle tasks he/she can not due to a lack of license. In addition the government should release the methodology used as the foundation for the paperwork time estimates included in the NPRM and all methodologies used to calculate paperwork time estimates for any final rule.  With respect to good faith efforts in addition to asking firms to identify DBEs they intend to use verification of payment to those DBE's should be required before final payment is released.  This will reduce significantly the number of firms that bait and switch.
docketTitle: Disadvantaged Business Enterprise: Program Implementation Modifications
title: Sandra Baynes

commentText: I am writing to appeal this proposal to terminate funding. I will present this in two phases first why the decision should be reversed and secondly what caused Miles City to be considered for termination.1. Miles City has only one reliable commerical transportation into and out of the city. Our present commerical bus has been suspended by DOT.  If we were to lose EAS that would mean no reliable tranmsportation.2. There are many Disabled Veterans who need hospital care in Denver or SLC.  If we lose EAS they have no transportation for these well deserving veterans same goes for the elderly .3. 7 months out of the year we have the possibility of winter conditions which makes it a saety hazard driving to Billings4. Loss of EAS would dampen our econmic development in the future with coal and oil just starting to expand.Wht caused the problem for Miles City1. We have 3 outgoing flights two to Billings and one to Glendive.  The one to Glendive no one would ever ride. If this was not considered as outgoing we might make the requirement.2. there are no compatible flights out of Miles City to connect with other carriers resulting in less people to fly as they would have to stay overnight in one of the connecting hubs which increases the cost.3. If the numbers were looked at in 2011 we had approximately 1094 outgoing passengers The first year this other carrier took over we droped to slightly over 324 riders.  What casued this we all are intelligent enough to look at the numbers outgoing flight times and connecting flight times to determine why Miles City numbers have dropped.4. The decision should not be based on one year by a different carrier but based on years past performance with all carriers involvedI strongly request that Miles City be given a chance to show with compatible flights good connection times at the correct hub we would be successfulYou must do whats right for Montana our area is to large to compare with any other areas.
docketTitle: Essential Air Service at Glasgow, Glendive, Havre, Lewistown, Miles City, Sidney, and Wolf Point, Montana
title: David Wheeler

commentText: Allowing the use of cell phones on airplanes during flight sounds like a nightmare. It's already bad enough being squashed into seats without sufficient room to be comfortable dealing with screaming kids and surly adults listening to audio from the movie music and games from the people who turn it up loud enough to hear outside their own headphones  and all the other nightmares that go with flying nowadays. This will send things over the edge. We don't need idiots talking constantly on their cellphones (yes they do talk louder on phones than in person) hearing cellphones ringing multiplied by however many people want to use them. I rarely take a plane anymore because it is just so uncomfortable already - if cellphones are allowed I will reconsider travel plans even more. Amtrak is already much better - lots of space in the seat a quiet car the ability to walk around at will. Air travel has no appeal and cellphone use will make it worse.
docketTitle: Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft
title: Anne Lance - Comments

commentText: Please do everything possible to prevent voice cell phone calls during air flights.  If allowed air travel would be miserable.
docketTitle: Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft
title: Sue

commentText: The idea that people will be able to have voice calls on commercial flights makes me want to never fly again.  It's bad enough that seats are closer together and planes are fuller than ever but imagine being trapped in a center seat next to someone for hours while they chat.  "Hello!  Can you hear me now?  Hello!"  As the Corporate Travel Director of a large corporation and the President of the Los Angeles Business Travel Association I strongly oppose the use of voice calls on ANY commercial flights.  I urge the DOT to spare the traveling public and the flight crews from what is surely to be a disaster in the making if voice calls are aloud.  Imagine the onboard arguements fights and resulting lawsuits from angry passengers.  It is just not a good idea.  Let people text.  That is how people communicate more and more today.  Voice calls have no place on a commercial aircraft.
docketTitle: Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft
title: Sean Parham

commentText: I support opening American airspace COMPLETELY to all of the world's airlines and especially the three large Gulf carriers: Qatar Emirates and Etihad.  They offer far superior service to US legacy carriers and if they are allowed to compete openly in the US it will raise the bar for every airline and create more competition that will benefit consumers.  American Delta and United are operating in an oligopoly and enjoying record profits as a result.  I fly more than 150000 miles every year with about 66% of it domestically.  I would love to have the option to choose carriers that offer superior service and value.  The US carriers receive HUGE contributions from US taxpayers in the form of Federal dollars that help fund our airport infrastructure.  The US legacy carriers' lawsuit is anti-competitive anti-free enterprise anti-consumer and anti-American.
docketTitle: Information on Claims Raised about State-Owned Airlines in Qatar and the UAE

commentText: As CEO of Invest Caribbean Now (ICN) the private sector investment agency of the Caribbean we note with concern the application of Dynamic International Airways LLC to fly to Cuba. Given the track record of this carrier in the markets its entered since 2014 and the shoddy treatment meted out to its many passengers we urge the US Department of Transportation to continue to deny this application. Dynamic Airways has left Guyanese New Yorkers and returning Guyanese in the lurch at J.F. K. International Airport in New York since 2014. The latest incident occurred on July 31 2016 when dozens of Guyanese with pre-paid tickets and confirmation to travel were brazenly told the flight was cancelled after showing up at the J.F.K. airport in New York City to check in. Reports reaching ICN indicate that many of the passengers were members of the Guyanese Diaspora in New York City and had shelled out hard earned money to book travel months in advance to coincide with their vacations as Dynamic promoted specials to their country of birth. The passengers were turned away without much explanation and then told they could not be accommodated with new bookings for weeks. This is a pattern of abuse. Just take a look at the complaints filed with the North Carolina Business Bureau. Additionally this carrier without much warning just canned their Fort Lauderdale -Caracas route leaving passengers booked to return after Aug. 13 2016 in the lurch. This carrier should never be considered and infact should be investigated for its shoddy service and business practices. We hope the US DOT will take our comment into serious consideration in any appeals launched by this carrier.
docketTitle: 2016 U.S.-Cuba Frequency Allocation Proceedings
title: Comment from Felicia Persaud

commentText: Donald Pevsner is engaged in unfair and deceptive practices.  A law license is not required to file at USDOT but Donald Pevsner has chosen to call himself 'Esq' and 'Attorney-at-Law'Donald Pevsner does not have a current legal license. A consult of Florida records finds that Donald Pevsner has the status of 'inactive'In Florida Bar vs. Gordon 661 So.2d.Rpts. 295 the Florida Supreme Court said that only an active lawyer may use titles like 'Esq' and 'Attorney-at-Law'USDOT should dismiss Donald Pevsner's filing and report Donald Pevsner's bad behavior to Florida Bar Discipline
docketTitle: Donald L. Pevsner - Petition for Ruelmaking and Enforcement Complaint
title: Comment from Anonymous

commentText: I wish to express my strong support for the approval of Norwegian Air International's Foreign Carrier Permit by the US Department of Transportation.By granting the Permit both the Irish and US economies will benefit significantly in terms of tourism and job creation. The new transatlantic routes from Cork will also open up opportunities for US and Irish companies and strengthen our already established links. Passengers from Ireland and the US will also benefit from the increased competition on transatlantic routes through greater choice and more competitive fares.Ireland has an outstanding reputation in relation to our aviation industry and our labour laws. This new service will grow transatlantic traffic in both directions.
docketTitle: Norwegian Air International Limited - Foreign Permit/Exemption - U.S.-EU Open Skies
title: Comment from Sue Uzande

commentText: As a company owner here in the Cork region it is a constant source of frustration to have to drive to Dublin airport to gain access to the US and beyond. Being in the power generation world all of my business is conducted outside of Ireland.I am hugely supportive of Norwegian Airlines commencing flights from Cork to the United States and the sooner it happens the better. Arriving back to Cork airport after a hard week of flights and business meetings would be fantastic and eliminate my most serious travel risk factor tiredness on the drive down from Dublin to Cork. I would appeal to everybody in the Cork and Munster region to strongly support this great initiative. This is a two way positive there are many US based companies operation in the Cork region. These flights will save the Irish based US companies thousands of dollars by being able to access direct flights to Cork and as we all say "time is money" Cork airport would be a dream for US business people it is new it is fresh and modern and very fast to get through inward and outward bound. The prospect of landing in Cork and being at your business in the Cork region within 30 minutes or as a Cork person being home withing 30 minutes of landing is a mouth watering prospect.  Denis McGrathManaging DirectorIGTSP Limited
docketTitle: Norwegian Air International Limited - Foreign Permit/Exemption - U.S.-EU Open Skies
title: Comment from Denis McGrath

commentText: Comment of the Chief Executive of Cork County Council Ireland -Strong supporter of Open Skies and the potential opportunity to grow tourism and business links between Ireland and the US through the granting of this foreign carrier permit to Norwegian Air International Ltd.Cork County Council governs the largest county in Ireland and is the largest Local Government body outside of Dublin City in the Republic of Ireland.The Council is responsible for leading the strategic economic physical social and cultural growth of Cork as the driver of the southern region of the State. We do so in co-operation with all national agencies such as Failte Ireland Tourism Ireland the IDA and with locally based stakeholders such as Cork Chamber of Commerce Cork City Council University College Cork Cork Institute of Technology and in particular with Cork Airport.Cork as the economic driver of the southern region of Ireland has supported and facilitated significant opportunity for commercial investment and opportunity for US businesses particularly from the east coast for many years. Being the location of choice for many global household corporate names US based companies in Cork are some of the leading international companies who are clustered around metropolitan Cork. With a spirit and history of entrepreneurship and trade Cork has developed into a thriving hub of global growth sectors in ICT pharmaceuticals healthcare biotechnology food and business services. In all we have 137 multinational companies based in Cork. They are attracted by the talented people the value for money the quality of life and the successful businesses already operating here. Significant opportunity exists through continuing this approach of supporting existing US based companies to grow and those who will decide that their future is in Cork and this proposed direct transatlantic route to Cork Airport will be of significant benefit to the fortunes of both US and Irish based business opportunities.Specifically with regard to tourism development Cork is uniquely positioned within the country as the natural international gateway point for visitors to the South West and South East of Ireland. This coupled with our array of tourism assets our business tourism strength and our location at the start and finish of the both of the key national tourism experience brands the Wild Atlantic Way and Irelands Ancient East makes Cork a location of international appeal. Already Cork attracts 17-18% of total visitors to Ireland. Ambitious investment and growth plans are being progressed which are presenting Cork as the premier destination for US visitors to enable them to maximise their visit to our shores. This proposed transatlantic route direct to Cork presents the opportunity for US citizens particularly those from the east coast to have direct access to the most unique and compelling location in Ireland from which to explore and be immersed in the culture of these incredible tourism experiences. And of course the significance of the opportunity for the Irish Diaspora in the US which is particularly strong along the east coast and Massachusetts and Boston in particular cannot be forgotten. This proposed direct route to Cork is a major opportunity to support those who continue to have significant family cultural and heritage ties to our region. I therefore strongly support the granting of the foreign carrier permit to Norwegian Air International Ltd as the benefits to citizens and businesses on both sides of the Atlantic are considerable.CERTIFICATE OF SERVICEThe undersigned certifies that on 11th May 2016  a true and correct copy of the foregoing Comment of the Chief Executive of Cork County Council Ireland -Strong supporter of Open Skies and the potential opportunity to grow tourism and business links between Ireland and the US through the granting of this foreign carrier permit to Norwegian Air International Ltd. was served by electronic mail on the individuals identified below:dan.weiss@united.com chris.walker@delta.commlbenge@zsrlaw.comrpommer@atlasair.comrussell.bailey@alpa.orgjonathan.cohen@alpa.orgedw@ttd.orgclytle@portoakland.comkgeorge@broward.orgmrichardson@swapa.orgrobert.wirick@aa.comfrancis.heil@aa.comhoward.kass@aa.cominfo@airlineinfo.com jesse.elliot@faa.govnicholas.tsokris@faa.govjohn.chen@faa.govjohn.allen@faa.govanita.mosner@hklaw.comjennifer.nowak@hklaw.comnssparks@fedex.comgbleopard@fedex.comdberg@airlines.orgjcasey@airlines.orgkglatz@airlines.orgcc@eurocockpit.beejames@jamhoff.comEngleTS@state.govsshur@traveltech.orgeugene.alford@trade.govDavid.Batchelor@sesarju.euOttar.Ostnes@sd.dep.no John.Hanlon@ELFAA.com Robert.Finamore@dot.govBrian.Hedberg@dot.govCharles.Leocha@travelersunited.orgkeith@washingtonairports.com pruden@asta.org rdow@ustravel.orgTim Lucey Chief Executive Cork County Council.

commentText: I believe the proposed routes from Cork to Boston &  New York would have exceptional benefit to both the US and Ireland. Given the huge concentration of multinational technology firms in Cork (Apple Amazon Dell Etc OpenText Oracle) this could only serve to benefit continued intercontinental growth of tech industry to the benefit of all.For general public the appeal of traveling from the second largest city in Ireland to two major East coast cities will have untold tourism benefits which would also be reciprocated for the massive Irish-decendant populations in NY and Boston. And from a personal perspective as someone living in Cork my closest friend has just recently been married to a US citizen and they are expecting their first child. They will be living primarily in NY but splitting their time to Boston the wife's hometown. The addition of these routes would be immensely valuable in allowing me to continue to share in their life without the absurd 3+ bus travel needed to get to an Irish Airport with US routes.

commentText: I oppose the Dept. of Transportation s (DOT) tentative decision to grant Norwegian Air International s (NAI) application for a foreign air carrier permit. This decision ignores the clear labor protections negotiated into the U.S.-EU Open Skies agreement and puts the interests of corporations ahead of workers and the public. The DOT decision is a serious threat to good aviation jobs and the U.S. airline industry. It establishes a dangerous precedent allowing unscrupulous operators to circumvent strong labor laws in favor of cheap labor from countries with the lowest labor standards. Aviation workers tirelessly ensure that the flying public enjoys the safest aviation system in the world every day. Support this work. I strongly encourage the DOT to #DenyNAI.
docketTitle: Norwegian Air International Limited - Foreign Permit/Exemption - U.S.-EU Open Skies
