commentText: March 9 2009 Hon. Ray LaHoodSecretary of TransportationU.S. Department of Transportation1200 New Jersey Avenue S.E.Washington D.C. 20590Subject:Comments of FlyersRights.org on NPRM?Enhancing Airline Passenger Protections?Reference:14 CFR Parts 234 253 259 and 399Docket No. DOT-OST-2007-0022RIN No. 2105-AD72SUBJECT:The Aviation Consumer Action Project (ACAP) opposes the subject NPRM (Item 1) as an unlawful delegation of DOT authority and responsibility to regulate airlines in the public interest by delegating this function the airlines themselves.  As written it is an anti-consumer regulation that would take away existing common law tort rights of airline passengers for false imprisonment and negligence in situations of long confinements on the tarmac of 3-11 hours that airlines now subject approximately 300000 passengers a year to and substitute an unenforceable contract cause of action.  ACAP supports Items 2-7 of the NPRM. Dear Secretary LaHood:The Aviation Consumer Action Project (ACAP) was founded in 1971 as 501(c ) 3 nonprofit organization that acts as voice for air travelers on issues of safety security and airline consumer rights and interests.  It has held longstanding membership on the FAA Aviation Rulemaking Advisory Committee (ARAC) and the Aviation Security Advisory Committee.  We have testified before Congress on the issues in this NPRM and filed comments with DOT.  I have been executive director of ACAP since 1997 and as an attorney have represented ACAP individual consumers and Flyersrights.org (fka the Coalition for an Airline Passengers Bill of Rights) in the federal and state courts on the issues addressed in this NRPM.1.  Putting Contingency Plans in the Contract of Carriage.This NPRM (1) is a last gasp Bush Administration/Airline Industry effort to turn over DOT regulatory authority to the regulated party.  It would lead to a multiplicity of unenforceable ?standards? and ?plans.?  Some airlines already are using a 4 to 6 hour guideline for tarmac confinements.  As there is presently no federal standard state common law standards for negligence and false imprisonment state criminal statutes involving unsafe operation of aircraft and wrongful imprisonment or reckless endangerment and possibly constitutional protections against unreasonable seizure are the only legal protections airline passengers have against indefinite tarmac confinements.  Most airlines now have or claim to have contingency plans to deal with flight disruptions of more than 2 hours.  But they are vague and commonly ignored (e.g. American Airlines has a contingency plan that is supposed to be activated after a 2 hours of delay but it was been found by the OIG to have been ignored and violated repeatedly in a Sept. 2007 report of its 12/29/06 mass diversion and stranding of over 100 flights involving over 10000 passengers).  Such plans are vague and there is nothing in them that a airline passenger can really enforce in a contract action.  Such plans placed in the contract of carriage would just be another way for airlines to absolve themselves of responsibility for long tarmac delays diversions and confinements.These confinements of 3- 11 hours now affect approximately 300000 passengers per year and have led to a national outcry and the formation of a national grass roots organization Flyersrights.org with over 24000 members.  The claims of the Air Transport Association that tarmac confinements have declined are false or at least unproven.  The DOT BTS only recently began collecting these statistics in 2008 and has had to remove the data presented by the airlines as ?corrupted? and therefore unreliable.The proposed regulation would wipe out existing legal protections and in our view would lead to more not less tarmac confinements as each airline would be in effect be able to write its own rule.  Such an unlawful delegation of DOT regulatory authority  would no doubt be challenged in court.   The age of self-regulation and deregulation whether in the financial industry air safety food safety or airline consumer protection is over.  It has been thoroughly discredited by scandals and disasters over the past two years and even rejected by many of its former advocates.  The Obama DOT must reject the mantra of former DOT Secretary Peters that the ?market? will solve all consumer problems.  Senator and Candidate Obama endorsed airline passenger rights legislation that would outlaw tarmac confinements of over 3 hours which this NPRM would clearly not do.  When an airline passenger brings an action in state court  the airline almost invariably has it removed to federal court on grounds of federal preemption.  The defendant airline will then file a series of motions to have the case transferred to its home state often far from the consumer passenger?s residence.  The cost of such litigation far exceeds the individual claims for ordinary delays or tarmac confinements.  The airlines are generally successful in having such lawsuits dismissed discouraged or abandoned.  Indeed a review of cases under CCH Aviation cases shows that virtually the only breach of contract cases brought under the contracts of carriage successfully involve cargo shipments by commercial shippers.   You can view the many technical defenses Recent cases involving passenger strandings which include  Ray v American Airlines Inc. US DC WD AR 08-5072 Hanni v American Airlines Inc. US DC ND CA 08-732; Harper v American Airlines Inc. US DC ND AL 08-________ (filed 12/29/08); Biscone v JetBlue Airways Corp. NYS SC Queens Co. 3776/2008.  The motions to dismiss or transfer or for summary judgment filed by the airline defendants can be viewed online at Public Access to Court Electronic Records (PACER) or the electronic dockets of the New York State Uniform Court System web site.Under the Class Action Fairness Act of 2005 (CAFA) (perhaps better described as the Consumer Class Action Elimination Act of 2005) nearly all state consumer class actions (which involves any case with a potential total claim over $5 Million) are removed to federal court where the bar is so high for certification that very few consumer class actions have ever been certified since this statute went into effect.  In the 5th Circuit which is the home of American Southwest and Continental Airlines none have been certified.  As to the issue of tarmac confinements only one 1999 case against Northwest Airlines has been certified as a class action to our knowledge and that occurred in Michigan state court involving confinements of up to 9 hours of 4000 passengers prior to the enactment of CAFA. Only through class actions in federal court or in local small claims court is it possible for airline passengers to judicially enforce breach of contract to tort claims that do not involve serious physical injury or death.  And since a class action requires that many passengers be involved with common facts and law only mass stranding events would normally qualify.Some airlines already provide for compensation for delays and associated expenses of overnight lodging in their contracts of carriage but these provisions are not as a practical matter enforceable and are frequently ignored or avoided entirely by airlines coding nearly every delayed or canceled flight as weather or FAA Air Traffic Control related.  There is no effective oversight by DOT and no fines of substance for airline violation of their own contracts or customer service plans or contingency plans or internal policies and none seems likely in the foreseeable future.The NPRM if adopted would mean domestic US airline passengers would have rights inferior to those provided to international passengers under the Montreal Convention of 1999.  Under Art. 19 passengers may recover damages for delay of up to  about $6400 on a near strict liability basis.  An airline to avoid liability has the burden of proving that it took all reasonable steps to avoid the delay or that the delay was impossible to avoid.  Damages include compensation for inconvenience as well as out of pocket losses and this treaty overrides the limitations or exclusions commonly found in domestic airline contracts of carriage which make promises in those contracts largely illusory.  Should NPRM (Item 1) be adopted in any form it should include provisions in domestic contracts of carriage a) requiring payment of litigation expenses of the passenger should s/he substantially prevail in the lawsuit b) be no less favorable to domestic passengers than international passengers c) should specifically authorize suits in state as well as federal courts d) authorize class actions where appropriate with the consumer class representative receiving a reasonable sum in compensation his time and representational responsibilities of the class payment of class notification expenses by the airline defendant plus treble damages or minimum compensation of  four times the ticket price and e) have a hard 3 hour passenger right to deplane plus delay compensation of $10 per minute for on ground confinements over 3 hours. Only with such pro-consumer provisions will airlines have an incentive to change their existing practices of ignoring passenger complaints and claims with impunity or offering only token compensation such as discount coupons or restricted vouchers.Items 2-7.  ACAP has long advocated for Truth in Scheduling regulation as a first line of defense against congestion delays caused by over scheduling by airlines.  These proposed measures are in line with our recommendations and would address the No. 1 airline passenger complaint:  flight delays.   As scheduling has been decontrolled airlines now have incentives to unrealistically schedule flights at popular times for competitive reasons which in turn leads to unnecessary congestion at major choke point airports like NYC and Chicago.  These regulations should allow consumers to avoid chronically delayed flights should eliminate deceptively scheduled flights and help relieve congestion delays at choke point airports. We generally support the comments of Flyersrights.org .    Very truly yourss/Paul S. HudsonExecutive DirectorAviation Consumer Action Project4411 Bee Ridge Road #274Sarasota Florida 34233(410) 940-8934Acapaviation@yahoo.com

commentText: The letter below and attached is concurrence by 5 leading national consumergroups with the detailed flyersrights.org submission in this docket which Ihave endeavored to attach it to (if this somewhat clunky government webinterface works). Thank you for your consideration of our submission..On behalf of the groupsEd MierzwinskiU.S. PIRG--------------------------LETTER FOLLOWS AND IS ATTACHED -------------------------Consumer ActionConsumer Federation of AmericaConsumers UnionNational Consumers LeagueU.S. PIRGMarch 19 2009FAX (202) 493-2251Document Management FacilityU.S. Department of Transportation1200 New Jersey Avenue S.E.Washington D.C. 20590-0001Re:Notice of Proposed Rule Making:Enhancing Airline Passenger ProtectionsReference:14 CFR Parts 234 253 259 and 399Docket No. DOT-OST-2007-0022RIN No. 2105-AD72Ladies and Gentlemen:We the undersigned national organizations together representing hundreds ofmillions of consumers in the United States wish to have our views considered onthe proposed regulation under consideration by the U.S. Department ofTransportation on ‰ЫПEnhancing Airline Passenger Protections.‰ЫќIn general our organizations support DOT‰ЫЄs taking an activist role in issuingregulations that protect airline passengers during long tarmac delays thatassure that air travelers will receive timely and accurate information fromairlines when there are flight delays and that provide for the effectiveenforceability of DOT requirements directly by passengers in state courts onunderstandable provisions in airline Contracts of Carriage along with anactivist DOT enforcement program.  Thus we support the proposals in the NPRM butbelieve they should be strengthened.Specifically we are opposed to the DOT concept that would turn Federalregulatory authority over to individual airlines -- who would each decide howmuch protection to offer airline passengers stuck on airline aircraft atairports for many hours.  In lieu of setting minimum Federal standards forairlines to provide water food working restrooms comfortable cabintemperatures and an option to deplane when it is safe to do so DOT is proposingto let each U.S. airline set its own guidelines without any Federal review andapproval.National Consumer Groups 19 March 2009 Page 2 of 2Notice of Proposed Rule Making:  Enhancing Airline Passenger ProtectionsReference:14 CFR Parts 234 253 259 and 399Docket No. DOT-OST-2007-0022RIN No. 2105-AD72We support the recommendations of FlyersRights.org in the extensive commentsthey filed on March 9 on each of the sections of the NPRM.  Thank you for considering our views on this important consumer issue. Pleasecontact Ed Mierzwinski at U.S. PIRG with questions (edm@pirg.org or 202-546-9707).SincerelyLinda SherryDirector National PrioritiesConsumer ActionTravis PlunkettLegislative DirectorConsumer Federation of AmericaEllen BloomFederal Advocacy DirectorConsumers UnionSally GreenbergExecutive DirectorNational Consumers LeagueEdmund MierzwinskiConsumer Program Director and Senior FellowU.S. PIRG

commentText: Your slide show reminds me of the National Skills and Standards Board (NSSB) program.  The NSSB was on track to providing an actual framework of recognition for certifications before it sunset.  Currently the limitation of certifications is linked to the American Council on Education (ACE) reviews and the Council for Adult Experiential Learning (CAEL).  It will become apparent after your program progresses that the Technologist distinction is a rung in the corporate structure that is not well defined.  The attached document may provide some assistance with the politics surrounding the Engineering Technologist distinction.

commentText: Accessibility of air travel continues to be an important public policy objective but does not permit defective and misleading economic analysis. It is reasonable for DOT to phase in standards for website accessibility while minimizing industry compliance cost.  We recommend that DOT limit the scope of Level AA compliance to the pages associated with booking managing or changing a reservation and provide a minimum two-year window for implementation prior to the first effective date.  But DOT‰ЫЄs proposed changes for airport kiosk accessibility are unreasonable and unjustified. 14 CFR 382.57 requires airlines to offer individuals with disabilities priority ‰ЫПfront of the line‰Ыќ access to check-in counters and agents and DOT has documented no failures that necessitate further regulatory action.  Its proposed solution (full kiosk accessibility) raises important safety and welfare questions for the general public.  Our comments focus on six problems with the SNPRM.  First policies that drive consumers to online/kiosk transactions will result in loss of airline jobs.  Second there are inherent safety considerations for all passengers related to fully automated check-in by individuals with visual disabilities.  Third website and kiosk use by individuals with visual disabilities may be slower than interaction with a call center or airport desk.  Fourth fundamental errors in the supplied Preliminary Regulatory Analysis result in overstated benefits and understated costs.  Fifth implementation timetables proposed are unrealistically short.  Sixth it is impractical to hold airlines liable for accessibility of independent agency websites or to jointly and severally penalize airlines and airports for common-use kiosks.

commentText: I am hard of hearing and due to excessive background noise I find it impossible to hear and understand emergency announcements gate change announcements boarding calls etc. at airports.  This has caused me to either arrive at a changed gate at the last minute or even to miss a flight. There is often no visual system in place to relay the info either.  This situation could be addressed for the majority of hearing aid wearers like myself if airports and airlines were required to install hearing loops such as those in the Grand Rapids MI airport to include very prominent and suitable signage that would display the international symbol for hearing access alerting us to the presence of such loops.  This would allow us to turn off the mics in our hearing aids that are amplifying all of the noise while turning on the telecoils to hear only the voice broadcasting the announcement..There should also be visual presentation of this information at each gate and the entrances to each concourse via a scroll on a visually accessible screen placed above head height and again with the international blue ear symbol for hearing access prominently displayed.

commentText: RE: U.S. Government Notice  (DOT-OST-2015-0053)Commenter:  CAPT David B. MoskoffThank you for this opportunity to comment.  I am speaking for myself and not for any government entity.(a) A brief description of your application(s) of positioning navigation and timing services;Having served earlier in my career as a ship's officer primarily aboard U.S. coast-wise tankers I came to quickly appreciate the critical necessity for navigation positioning and the benefits of electronic satellite and loran systems.  I have learned first-hand how important it is to know your ship's exact location especially in shallow areas where a high speed vessel proceeding in excess of 20 knots can run into difficulty in a mere matter of minutes.  As a Master aboard these tankers my appreciation for accurate electronic positioning understandably became more acute.  As a private pilot with FAA single engine high horsepower rating as well as an avid small boat owner I know that electronic positioning is not just a concern for large tankers just off the rocky shores of the U.S. coastline.  Large ships that go aground on our shores can inflict severe consequences in magnitudes almost beyond comprehension.  The oil spill this past week off Santa Barbara is yet another grim reminder of the extreme and long-lasting damaging effects of oil to the marine environment.  The 2010 BP blowout of the DEEPWATER HORIZON in the Gulf of Mexico reached a cost to BP in excess of 42 billion US dollars by 2013.  A VLCC (Very Large Crude Carrier) also can spill significant amounts of oil.  These vessels come to our shores every day.  Vessels deliver dangerous cargoes besides oil daily via our environment.We are aware this wayward oil does not have to be the ship's cargo to cause serious harm since the engine fuel (bunkers) alone is carried in such large quantities that damage to a single bunker tank can have significant impacts as we have seen on numerous occasions off our shores and others.   If a CONUS eLoran system were implemented only to serve the marine transportation sector it would be a very wise investment for this use solely.  The known cost of a single medium size oil spill from vessel grounding may very well run into the same hundreds of millions of dollars that it is anticipated to cost to implement and run CONUS eLoran for 20 years.  Preventing one oil spill could pay for the system for 20+ years!  For comparison a single GPS satellite costs this type of money by the time it is designed bid built and launched.  As a complementary navigation positioning source eLoran would be a very worthwhile investment.  As many know the PNT acronym's most important letter has morphed from its early days assisting with positioning and timing to become the super-critical (T)imekeeper of the world.As a professor at a maritime academy I have a enhanced appreciation for PNT systems and particularly GPS due to the timekeeping aspects.  Since I use many parts of the U.S. critical infrastructure daily it seems fair to say that outlining "A brief description of your application(s) of positioning navigation and timing services" for me would not be unlike most other U.S. citizens who use electricity telecommunications and banking etc. every day.  This would be especially critical if "(b) the positioning navigation and/or timing performance required for a complementary PNT capability to support operations during a disruption of GPS that could last for longer than a day".Since the timing aspect of PNT has largely become more important than the positioning aspect and so inherently crucial to everything we do how could we not immediately implement a second system for timing in the form of eLoran? (c) availability and coverage area required for a complementary PNT capability;Coverage needs to be similar to GPS so the two systems can be universally and uniformly relied upon to support the same system and user demands at similar tolerances. Since GPS (and all GNSS including GLONASS Galileo etc.) are satellite based and eLoran is terrestrially based this would be the very best of partnerships.  The two systems GPS and eLoran are so very different in transmission frequencies signal power vulnerabilities etc. that they have quite different failure modes - what impacts one will probably not impact the other.  Please see the attachment describing the units used in the English Channel for years now that automatically switch from one system to the other during failures. To accomplish this uniformity between systems for both timing and positioning (about 8-10 meters?) coverage would need to extend throughout the Alaska/CONUS coastlines and include those "fringe" areas where present geometry of eLoran stations requires stations in Canada and Mexico some new. These areas like the Florida Keys Gulf of Mexico and southern California areas would seem to require two new stations in northern Mexico perhaps totaling 35-45 stations.

commentText: Re: DOT-OST-2015-0246 - "Amending the definition of 'Service Animals' that may accompany passengers with a disability on a flight.Name: Laurie A. Gawelko M.S. CEO and Founder of Service Dog Express LLC P.O. Box 591835 San Antonio TX  78259. Email: laurie@servicedogexpress.com Phone: (855)778-2364 ext.1.I received my Master's Degree in Canine Life Sciences from Bergin University for Canine Studies in 2012 and my undergraduate degree from Carnegie Mellon University in Social History with a minor in Psychology in 2005. After receiving my undergraduate degree I worked in many distinguished psychiatric research hospitals focusing on treating patients with a variety of psychiatric disorders. After completing my Master's degree I founded Service Dog Express LLC which to date has paired over 1000 Wounded Warriors and civilians with a multitude of disabilities with professionally-trained Service Dogs.  One of the issues that I have been consistently advocating for since the inception of my company is to have the ACAA follow the same regulations regarding the definition of 'Service Dogs' that the ADA announced in 2011. The ADA NO LONGER had a separate classification for "Psychiatric Service Dogs" - they were put under the all-encompassing rubric of "Service Dogs". Simply put the term "Psychiatric Service Dog" DOES NOT EXIST.  However the ACAA continues to disregard this change in terminology and airlines consistently demand documentation from those who fly with Service Dogs that aid those with psychological disabilities that they do not require from those who fly with Service Dogs for "visible disabilities" including mobility issues Guide Dogs Hearing Dogs and medical alert dogs (epilepsy diabetes etc.). This is in direct violation of ADA law and is an absolute infringement on the rights of those who have such issues as Post Traumatic Stress Disorder Traumatic Brain Injuries anxiety disorders etc. Based upon this blatant discrimination and failure of the ACAA to align themselves with the ADA I began working on a regular basis with then United States Senator John Cornyn Congressman Pete P. Gallego and State Representative Jose Mendendez to actively address this issue receiving letters of commendation from all.  In fact by the end of 2013 my work with Senator Cornyn had reached the point where he informed me that this issue would be drafted by him as a bill to be presented to Congress due to its extreme importance. Unfortunately as the political environment changed the issue was inevitably put on a "back burner" - but I have continued my correspondence with all of these previously engaged political figures as the issue continued to be unresolved. I also vowed to all of my clients with psychological disabilities that I would pursue this issue until it was resolved appropriately and in accordance with ADA Federal Law. Having participated in several research projects in which I was able to view the S.P.E.C.T. scans and PET scans of individuals with psychological disabilities it was and is very clear that these are CLINICALLY DIAGNOSTIC MEDICAL CHANGES in patients brains. Psychological disabilities are medical disabilities just like any other medical disability. Through my work with Wounded Warriors with PTSD Traumatic Brain Injuries and clients with other psychological disabilities who have professionally-trained Service Dogs it has come to the point in my company that ANY time a client with an aforementioned disability who needs to fly on a commercial airline has to book their flight say that they are flying with a Medical Alert Service Dog and I then without fail call the airline with which they are flying to confirm again that my client is flying with a Medical Alert Service Dog will require NO additional documentation of their "disability" and will not be treated any differently than any other person flying with a Service Dog.  Service Dogs for people with psychological disabilities perform tasks that do medically alert to changes in the chemistry of the brain by providing such things as deep pressure therapy (which immediately positively alters the client's brain chemistry) pawing to alert to a client if they are experiencing a panic attack flashback moment of disassociation "covering" (which is essentially providing a barrier between the client and any threat to the client's psychological well-being) and constantly increasing the client's levels of neurotransmitters in the brain and the levels of oxytocin in the brain that keep the client calm.  The ACAA MUST recognize that a Service Dog is a Service Dog no matter what the client's disability is - and each client with a disability should be treated equally and they should never be subjected to the utter humiliation and degradation especially of those who have served our country and suffer from PTSD or TBI by asking for paperwork documenting their private psychiatric diagnoses.  Thank you.

commentText: 'Designer puppies' farmed in appalling conditions by East European gang" It's not just Eastern Europeans. The majority of puppy farms in this country are run by British people and they are all disgusting. NEVER buy a puppy from a pet shop from anyone who is not KC registered and even then insist on seeing the puppy with its mother. Check out how they interact as it may not really be the mother. Ask to see around the whole of the breeding place so you can see how the parents are kept. Many breeding stock suffer terrible diseases through the conditions they are kept in.
